title: Sonos Play:5 - Ultimate Wireless Smart Speaker - Black
features: Experience pure, vibrant sound with Play:5, tuned by renowned producer Giles Martin; Control it with the Sonos app, Apple AirPlay 2, and more
3 custom designed woofers deliver rich bass while the sealed architecture eliminates reverb and echo
Pair 2 Play:5s in the upright position and each speaker smartly adjusts to mono for incredibly detailed stereo separation; Place a single Play:5 horizontally and it plays stereo sound automatically
Use the line in to connect your turntable or a friend's phone with the included 3.5 millimeter jack
Ethernet port: One 10/100 Mbps Ethernet port; Wire directly to your router to operate your Sonos if WiFi is unstable

reviews.reviewText:
Sonos has a problem with the Play 5. The wireless cards quit. One day you'll likely find that the device has disappeared from your system. That's when the fun begins.

First you'll spend 30 minutes on hold trying to reach customer service. This will remind you of your dealings with credit card companies or online retailers. They don't seem to care and it shows;)

When you get a tech on the line they'll have you open a trouble shooting app and enter the devices info. Then they'll ask you to get the device and plug it into your router via cable. At this point they'll confirm that the unit has lost its wireless card. Then they'll have you start a second help ticket in their app, and enter your shipping and device registration again while promising to send an RMA and exchange the device.

Then after a couple days you'll get an email. Asking you to enter your shipping address and the units serial #, yet again. At this point I'm guessing that you won't have the serial # with you so you'll have to return to the failed device and get it, again...

Then after a day or two you'll yet another email asking if you would like to drop your failed unit off at UPS or print a label. At this point a week has gone by and you'll start to wonder which government program their customer service is modeled after. Finally after boxing it up, exchanging emails like pen pals and shipping it off, all you'll have to do is wait. A week or so later your replacement unit will arrive.

It's going to require that you to dedicate some time to the process and keep a sense of humor while repeating the same information over and over...;)

reviews.reviewTitle: Nice product, horrible support, glitchy software
reviews.reviewText:
Had I rated this product earlier (I've had it for a year), I would have given it 5 stars. Nice sound, convenient, and their support setting it up was excellent. Unfortunately, the app has quit recognizing it. Going to the Sonos website, I found that even finding technical support was difficult, and clicking on any specific issue brings you in an endless loop. Tried to call, only to be told a one-hour wait, and no way to leave a call-back number as many support sites do. Once I finally figured out how to email them, I got a reply (a full day later) telling me how to upload diagnostic info, which I did. After hearing nothing back, I realized that I had to send ANOTHER email to support with my prior case number and the diagnostic number. You'd think that they'd get back to you once they have all the info.

As my product is just over a year old, my guess is that I'm screwed, though I need to find the warranty. I get having wireless problems, but the way their support has degraded in just a year is appalling.

Will update the review if/when I actually hear back from them.

2/19 update: Was going to change this to 4 stars, as they did replace my unit. Still curious what will happen when the wireless quits after the warranty expires, as they don't seem very user-serviceable. My new complaint is with their software. Works pretty flawlessly when using a streaming service such as Pandora. The issue seems to be when playing music from your own music library. I've copied all of my CD's onto a music folder on my computer so that I can play them on the Sonos. Probably every second or third time I try playing from this folder, the Sonos software can't find it. So, I need to remove the folder and re-add the folder before playing any music from it. This is a time-consuming practice; by the time it's complete, I'm no longer in the mood to hear the music I wanted.

reviews.reviewTitle: Two defective Play 5 units and terrible customer service
reviews.reviewText: Up until a few months ago I was a big fan of Sonos, loving the sound quality and ability to control the music through my phone or computer. But then the Play 5 I purchased about 1 year ago just stopped working due to a known issue with a defective wifi or network card according to Sonos tech support. That was bad but what followed was far worse. After attempting to fix the unit over the phone, they promised to send a new unit but for weeks it never came. Turns out the rep I talked to on the phone failed to tell me that I had to jump through more hoops including giving them my credit card so they could charge me for a new one if I failed to return the defective one in 14 days. So I jumped through those additional hoops and a new one arrived. A few weeks later that replacement Play 5 stopped working just like the first one. Remarkably, it had a defective wifi / network card according to tech support just like the first one! This time the customer support person, who seemed a bit embarrassed, promised to send a new one with overnight delivery. He seemed nice and concerned so I waited for the new one to arrive. But it didn't come for days. When I called back they said I had to jump through additional hoops on their website never mentioned on the call. Why would they promise to send me a new one the next day but not tell me about the additional steps I need to take to make it happen? By this time I was quite upset. I must have made 10 to 12 calls to Sonos waiting 15 to 25 minutes on hold each time. To make it right they gave me a 30% discount code for a new purchase. But that code was only worth about 10% compared to Sonos prices at a big box retailer. I can't believe such a strong premium brand that charged me $500 for the original Play 5 would treat customers this way.

reviews.reviewTitle: Caution: Serious problem with the SONOS wifi cards.
reviews.reviewText: Buyer Beware!!! Apparently, SONOS has problems with the wifi controller in the PLAY:5 system resulting in wifi connectivity eventually failing, leaving only Ethernet connectivity as an option. In the last 6 months, I have had 3 units RMA. Considering the price of these units and a one-year warranty, if the wifi fails, which appears to be very possible, you will be stuck with a brick.

I own three Sonos 5, six Sonos 1, and one Sonos Sub.
Overall I thgink they are expensive, for what they offer, but if you have the money, and do not want to spend a lot of time setting up complicated hardware the Sonos were right for you. Good sound. Easy Interface.
But the arrogance of Sonos of SOnos towards their customers is quite unique even compared to other IT companies, and is therefore ultimately leading to me selling my equipment.
1.) You will be forced to register with personal data to operate the loudspeakers, Privacy Policy (Aug / 17): "...As part of the registration, you will need to set up a Sonos account .. We collect: your name, phone number, email address, location data, your password, passwords hints and IP address" Why do you force me to give my name to use a speaker?
2.) As soon as a new firmware version is provided, you can no longer access certain menu items of the exiting firmware. The basic functions for listening to music continue to work, but certain advanced settings are no longer available until you update the fiirmware. For example, most annoyingly you can no longer add new speakers. Even advanced settings for your own local music library are no longer available. If you buy soft- or hardware, generally a company offers you not to install upgrades if you accept sticking with the current functionality. Sonos downgrades you to force you to upgrade your firmware.
3.) Now (August) a new firmwareupdate has come out. To download this, you will be forced to accept the new data protection guidelines as well. These allow Sonos to collect significantly more data than before, for example with regards to the built-in microphones, or Sonos recording what music was heard when / where / by whom. I don't want t discuss, whether the new rules are "good" or "bad", as everyone has a different opinion. But it is a fact that they are significantly different from the privacy rules when I bought my speakers just 6 months ago. And Sonos acknowledges that the Sonos speakers will ultimately cease to work if you don't accept the new privacy policy.
IN SUMMARY: I understand that Google & Facebook collect data, to privide their free service. But I think, when I spend 4.000 US$ on a hifi system, I should have the right to my privacy. And even more so I should have the right to the rules not changing after my purchase. Because what's the point of any privacy policy, if the manufacturer can blackmail me into accepting whatever he wants after my purchase.

reviews.reviewTitle: Awesome sound system, but make sure this is for you
reviews.reviewText:
I'm glad this is what I went with after months of researching and debating. First of all, and most important, the sound is great. I wanted something that filled my open concept downstairs living room and kitchen with high quality sound. I've used it to entertain for a party, to rock out to some good ole rock and roll, and for background music while making dinner, and it performs great at all levels. I have not had any of the intermittent issues that some of the low reviews mention. I have one of the higher speeds internet, but it's nothing special.

The app makes it easy to set up the system and I really liked the sound tuning option. I like that I can access multiple music sources like Spotify, Amazon prime music, Pandora, etc, from the app. Much better than having to go into every app to find what you are looking for. The user interface is more basic than the actual music apps, but it does what I need it to, which is search, find, play.

I don't mind not having a the Bluetooth option. It hasn't affected me, but I can see how some people find that to be an issue. I also understand that Sonos wants to keep their sound system a hi-fi system and the Bluetooth sound quality is not as good.

In terms of aesthetics, this is an elegant piece, and even my interior designer wife was happy with the looks.

The price point is high, so make sure you are willing to make the investment. My plan is to eventually grow my system, and that capability was another selling point for my needs.
My play 1s stay connected. The play 5 is a giant pain to deal with and constantly drops the connection no matter what I try. I do not recommend it.

I have had a songs system for many years now, starting out with the songs connect so I could use all my current setup and equipment. Three years ago I started getting the Play 1's, and those kept multiplying until I have a large herd of them around the house.

I had listened to the play 3 and old generation play 5 and thought for the most part the new tech in the Play 1's are superior.

Now enter the new Play 5 with all the new tech and more and better speakers. I initially got one thinking I could do a stereo pair and compare it with the Play 1. That was a no go. Sonos software does not allow this pairing. Only like with like. So now I had to order another one, ouch that was costly.

Now that they are all setup in a stereo pair and did the custom sound procedure that sonos developed, they sound great. I did a side by side with the paired Play 1's and here is my findings. They both sound great. They both have great bass response and highs. Where they part ways is the midranges, the detail, and the soundstage.

The Play 5's take what was good in the Play 1's and make it better. They are also a lot louder for when you really want to pump some sound. You don't need the sub with the Play 5's. I have one, but it is really not needed anymore. The sub still does well for sure, but its kind of like there is a baby sub in each play five and the sub goes, Hey Im Here Too... Hey You Still Need Me Right?

The Play 5's are big and very heavy. About fourteen pounds each. Solid as a rock. Each speaker inside the Play 5 has its own amp.

I am glad I have them, but it was painful buying two. You really don't need two for a pretty big room unless you want to pair them in stereo. The also can sense how you place them and the sound is changed automatically for vertical and horizontal. Horizontal does sound a bit better but I prefer the look of the vertical on my shelves. Also takes up less room and I did not have much to spare where I placed them.

A little side note for those who have connection or interference issues. Do not buy a bridge, those are semi worthless. The Boost is much better. And something they don't advertise is that the sonos connect has the most powerful transmitter that will cut through interference like a light saber. I was running my system in a long house without it and was having connection problems all over the place. Hooked the connect back up in the middle of the house and it took over the signal from the boost. No more drops. Did not even have the connect connected to anything other than the ethernet.

reviews.reviewTitle: Sonos Is No Longer Remotely Reliable - Avoid At All Costs
reviews.reviewText: We have several homes and have purchased scores of Sonos players and controllers over the years. I hesitate to think how much I have spent on Sonos. Sonos products always been somewhat buggy and never fully lived up to their potential, but we persisted because the concept seemed great. After years of frustration, however, I am officially giving up on Sonos. Sonos constantly updates its app and desktop controller to incorporate this or that "new feature," and more often than not, the upgrade brings new problems. Everything is incredibly buggy, and nothing is designed for any level of scalability. Testing seems to be non-existent. If you buy a Sonos product, prepare to be a human guinea pig. So if you are thinking about buying one or two players, perhaps you should consider Sonos, though even then, I would recommend you get something else. (Having 5 or 10 players brings major headaches, in part because a favorite recommendation of Sonos support is to "reset" all of your Sonos players, a process that can take an hour or more with multiple players.) So don't even think about a system consisting of 5 or 10 different players, and avoid the new Beam at all costs. Nothing will work seamlessly, and you will find yourself constantly fiddling, actually fixing things only if you are lucky. Sonos support is reasonably good, but if you have to spend hours online or on the phone with support every month or so, then perhaps the problem is really with the product. Be prepared for Sonos to blame your router, network and you for every problem, at least in the first instance, but at the end of the day, this company has lost its way, all the more so since the recent IPO. Sonos deserves to fail and should. Get a few HomePods or Google products. Not nearly as slick as Sonos, but way, way more reliable.
Sounds good until time for a warranty claim, then you cannot get in touch with that dept.

reviews.reviewTitle: Spectacular audio fidelity, simple intuitive software
reviews.reviewText:
I write contemporary instrumental music and use professional studio monitor speakers to mix the final songs. In addition they are mastered by a professional engineer. This gives me a very good feel for how well audio systems perform, by using my finished songs as standards. Regarding Sonos sound, the speaker default bass is definitely too high. That is easily attenuated with the controls on your computer or phone. After that change I can say with confidence that this speaker has remarkable fidelity over nearly the full range of volume. The frequency response is simply phenomenal. Volume is more than adequate for most purposes.

The software is very intuitive, at least on my iOS or Mac systems. Once plugged in, it took me 5 minutes to begin playing music from my Apple music account or from my personal collection. I was never confused as to what to do - set up is very straightforward and expertly guided.

I only have one speaker now but plan to buy another later on. I will update my review at that time.

This product last 15 months. We kept it on one table and never and moved it. We used it lightly at best and then inexplicably about a year and a half after spending $500 it just stopped working. It does not even power on. They have a 1 year warranty which is useless. I have heard others have had the same issue. I contacted the support desk and never received a reply back. Super disappointing to say the least.

reviews.reviewTitle: Work(ed) great for 2 months. But they are fixing the issue.
reviews.reviewText: At first I loved this product. I purchased for a client looking for a whole home wireless audio option. Product worker great for about 2 months. Just now the wireless card went out in the item. Looking online this has had a couple of issues with users. I reached out to support and they are sending a new unit to me to swap out so that is good and should be back to 5 stars as long as this was a fluke instance. If it happens again I may have to change this to a 3 star. But when it is working it is amazing.

Sonos used to have truly great customer service, but no longer. My PLAY 5 Gen 2 stopped working a month ago and despite hours spent trying to get it to work and seeking help from sonos support, I am no where! Very disappointed.

We were deciding if we should go with the PLAY:3 or 5 and decided to spend the extra money for the 5. There is no doubt we made the right choice. The sound is unbelievable for such a small device. Music plays clear, it come through with rich tones and can shake our little house. There is no lag from the internet. I read that the SONOS app was confusing and unfriendly but I would disagree. We were able to search for both our local radio stations and international stations right away. The app walked us through the set up and was extremely easy to.follow. We look forward to taking the speaker outside in the spring to see how well it does.
In the end, we would encourage others to buy this device.

reviews.reviewTitle: Dysfunctional app/ software makes system practically unplayable
reviews.reviewText: I own eight different Sonos speakers including two Play 5's. These are beautifully designed speakers. Sound quality is as good as one can expect from a system this size. The problem is that the speakers are practically unusable if you plan on playing music from your iPhone. The app is so dysfunctional as to cause endless frustrations. Tech support, which used to be responsive and well-informed, is slow to respond and clueless as to resolving issues. Until Sonos can figure out how to produce an app that allows for playback without constant 'cut-outs'/ lost connections and randomly switching tracks among other serious issues, then I would not recommend investing in this system.

I am have heard some of the best speakers money can buy and this little guy is well worth $499. For the size, the bass is deep and smooth. The highs are crisp and clean. Setup was a breeze and Spotify and Soundcloud music sync'd seamlessly. I highly recommend the Sonos PLAY5 and I am pretty sure you won't be disappointed.

reviews.reviewTitle: Sounds good easy to setup and looks nice BUT...
reviews.reviewText:
Sounds good, easy to setup and it looks nice and clean
Spotify and app that support Sonos seems to work ok

BUT
The App is really ugly and hard to use...
It does not support Airplay so that means lots and lots of music app will not play to Sonos. Sonos is going to support Airplay for Play5 so that's good news.
There is a App that let you play youtube on Sonos but is full of bugs. it hang it stop and it play other sounds that you did not select
Also some time it does not stop when I tab stop
It lets you play music on the phone but it does not have a music service to install in sonos app if you have Itune music

For these who care about power it use
Sonos 5 runs about 2.2w doing idle and 7.2w when is playing music

reviews.reviewTitle: Too high of a price for such poor quality of a product
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this speaker because I needed something that work sound great and work easily for streaming music from my phone and for listening to music from my record player. The latter was especially important to me and the fact that this Sonos speaker has a line-in port made this decision a no-brainer. And that's where this speaker majorly disappointed me.

When I connected my record player through the line-in port with a classic audio jack, the speaker started making this annoying hissing/static noise and it wouldn't disappear when I started playing music. It would actually get more audible the more I increased the volume. At first, I thought the issue was with the record player because I've had audio problems with different record players before. However, when I connected my phone through the line-in port, the hissing noise was still there. Then I tried using different cords and combinations of cords. Unfortunately, every time I selected line-in as the source, the hissing/static sound would resume regardless of the device/cord attached to the speaker.

I went online and read a number of articles and message boards in which people were describing the exact same problem. I played around with the EQ and with the line-in settings in the Sonos app to no avail. I reached out to Sonos' customer service team and they were of little help.

I have to say, when the speaker was connected to my phone through the wireless connection, the sound was flawless (hence the extra star in my review). However, reading all the other reviews on here, it sounds like that flawlessness has an expiration date as well.

Eventually, I decided to return the speaker. I wasted way too much time for a $500 product that's supposed to just work. This is a really expensive speaker and I am baffled at how poor its quality is. Besides, it's way too big and clunky - it looks like a giant brick on top of my credenza.

Anyway, feel free to try it for yourself and see if it works for you but be warned that there are will probably be issues with it. So, make a point to not throw away the box cause you might need it.

It has good sound but the wi-fi function went out after 5 months. When I called Customer Service (emails didn't work), they said it "happens a lot". Now in a fight with getting a replacement shipped to me, not to a FedEx location 200 miles away. I was about to buy another Play 5 for use in another room, but not going to now. Too bad, since the sound is good.

I say this as a person who has owned three Sonos devices and has been very happy with their performance. However their Line-in feature simply doesn't work. I was hoping to use Sonos Play 5 as a replacement for my computer speakers. It simply sounds awful. I have tried multiple aux cables, changing line levels, compressing the audio and every other possible fix suggested on the forums. I have also seen on the forums people being pushed to move towards their WiFi solutions. Which is perfectly reasonable except this has a line-in. This is a feature that was promoted and does not work. Sonos makes BEAUTIFUL speakers they look good and sound good, but don't promote something as a feature that doesn't work.

reviews.reviewTitle: Skip the 3 and go for the 5 !!!
reviews.reviewText:
This is a pretty awesome sounding speaker. I have the play 1's, sub woofer, playbar and just returned a Play 3 to replace it with this. It has a deep clear sound that carries nicely. I only have 1, so no stereo, but it still sounds great.
The price is definitely steep, but once you jump in to the Sonos ecosystem of listening to music at home, you realize you're paying as much for the software / tech end of things and it's simplicity as well as quality.
I like the software that controls this and my other speaker, but I do worry they could make a change / update I don't like or worse yet go out of business or something in which case most of my system would be worthless.
The Play 5 does have an input jack which somewhat insulates against that concern, but it would be a way overpriced product if that was the only way I was able to use it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Sounds great when it works, which is rare
reviews.reviewText:
Sounds great when it works. Spotify has lots of trouble connecting, and Sonos support was terrible. They suggested I check my DNS. Well, I was listening to Spotify on my phone, on the same wifi, when I wrote up the support ticket.

Pros: Speaker sounds really great when you can get it connected.

Cons: If you like fiddling with your phone for 30 minutes, this speaker is for you! Otherwise, it's connectivity is terrible.

I purchased 3 Play 5's in 2017. All three have now been set back to have the wireless card replaced. I'm happy with the sound of the speakers but the reliability has been horrible. Luckily they were all under warranty. When this happens after the warranty wears out I guess I'll be stuck with three expensive speakers that don't work. Very disappointing. The phone support has been execellent.

reviews.reviewTitle: Worthwhile Investment for a Good Wireless Speaker
reviews.reviewText:
I saw a lot of negative reviews so I had to chime in with a positive review.
Setting this speaker up was easy in addition to the two Sonos 1s I have. Sometimes in a rare while the system will lose the speaker which is annoying but it 95% of the time hooks right back up if I set it back up, one minus on versatility. The Sonos App on Windows could use a little improvement as I have to push the play button twice as the first time it will say it can't recognize the speakers, another minus on versatility. There used to be an issue with switching from Spotify App and Sonos App where the volume would come on full blast, so yes, the speakers are really loud, don't compromise sound quality for volume, and I am probably in need for another pair of ear drums. The Pandora and Spotify Apps work well and I can even play my own music, I don't understand how people can't connect their personal libraries up, worked just fine for me. I really like the Sonos 1 so if you are hesitant and forking the cash for the 5 definitely get a 1 to try out, most will not be disappointed.
These speakers are pricey but I have not have had an issue besides the aforementioned above. If you have the money, I recommend Sonos.
A negative point on Amazon for delivering this expensive product via Fedex, left in the middle of the day on my doorstep next to a sidewalk of a busy street. What happened to leaving a note saying come pick this up, or owner wasn't home?

We bought the PLAY:5 to replace a PLAY:3 in our great room. The PLAY:3 proved to be too small for that large space. The sound was tinny and flat, despite trying different room locations and speaker orientations. We moved it to our master bedroom and now we have perfect sound from the PLAY:3. Bottom line, the dimensions of the room really make a difference on the sound of Sonos speakers. The PLAY:5 is the perfect speaker for larger spaces. We now have Sonos throughout the house using a combination of PLAY:1, PLAY:3 and PLAY:5, each perfectly matched to the dimensions of the rooms.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Speaker Great Technology Really is Plug and Play
reviews.reviewText: I purchased a Play:5 a few weeks ago as a B-day present to myself, Wifey still doesn't know how much it costs :-). Anyway when it came 1st thing I noticed it is a little heavy so not something you want to be moving around a lot. I have a FiOS internet high speed connection along with the FiOS Quantum WiFi router with an extender running a mix of Apple and Windows products on the network. I set the the speaker up in my man-cave in the basement sound quality just completely blew me away I just keep staring at the speaker trying to figure how SONOS gets the sound quality out of such a small package. But what really amazed me I had the thing up and running in about 5 minutes I downloaded the iOS app on my iPhone - iTunes, Pandora & Spotify are my main music sources. Anyway after I loaded the app music just started coming out the speaker I'm like I didn't really do anything. The speaker is really "Plug & Play". Wife comes down to the "Cave" I had the music turned up fairly loud she looks over and said what's that, sounds good why don't you get 1 for the Master Bedroom? I just gave her the Big Eye Look she still doesn't know how much it costs.

Bought this from Amazon Warehouse Deals. Didn't work. Called Sonos. They ran a diagnostic on the speaker and discovered it had a bad wireless chip in it. From the looks of the shipping box and the labels on it, this unit had apparently had been shipped three other times.

I cannot complain about the quality of the product. However, my decision to purchase this and another speaker from the Sonos family was more about ease of use through the app and what music I could listen to. Recently support stopped to enable listening to music that is on one's phone; now you primarily can use this to listen to music through a music streaming service such as Spotify, or, oh yeah, Amazon Music. Many of us still have music that we've acquired over many years and do not wish to pay someone a monthly fee to listen to only a fraction of the music we've loved over a lifetime. So this has become a large annoying reminder of what I have lost convenient access to instead of a speaker system I can use to listen to my preferred music. I would never have bought these speakers if I had known they were going to change the format of the music I could listen to at their whim.

Well, I had two of these speakers for a little over 6 months. They work fine in general, until the most recent software update. Right after the update, one of the speaker could no longer join the untouched wireless network, while the other was fine. Back-and-forth with the tech support on their community webpage, not helpful at all. If you said you did something, the response would be "that's wrong. Unplug everything, restart the router, wait a few minutes, place the speakers to their original places...blahblahblah..." They just ignored the fact that one of the speakers connected without problems. So how the hell is the router the issue? Very disappointed.

Update: I called in to Sonos customer service and was told that the offline speaker actually needed to be replaced due to malfunction of its wireless card. The return and replacement process was quite easy and fast. I got my replacement speaker today. The customer service was satisfactory. But the quality of the product is a concern considering I only had the speakers for less than 7 months. I will up one star on the review ranking for their customer service.

great sound, as advertised. fills our whole living room with high fidelity. While I'm sure a two speaker solution will sound much more true stereo, I'm still quite impressed with the stereo image the Play 5 delivers. set up was easy and the app works great. apple airplay support adds to versatility. TWO CONCERNS: wifi connection, as others have mentioned, isn't robust, many inexplicable drop outs despite strong wifi signal. This needs to be rectified, like yesterday. Ridiculous for such a high end product that there isn't more of a buffer to mitigate and/or better connectivity circuitry. Second, and I imagine this goes hand in hand with the first concern, as others have mentioned, there can be syncing issues with video. I don't experience this with all video content websites, but with HBO NOW the delay makes using the speaker unusable for movie watching. As others have mentioned, this, too, is unacceptable in such high end kit, especially in a product thats been around for years now. Should have been fixed/solution offered eons ago. Yes, I'm sure the aux input probably mitigates this problem, although I haven't tried it yet. But theres just no point in having a wifi surround speaker that has such delay issues -- and the app doesn't offer a time compensation feature. These are considerable disappointments. I didn't try the Naim competitor but kind of wish I'd at least tried it out. So overall, I'm mostly pleased with the Play 5 and fingers crossed that these ancillary issues are addressed soon.

reviews.reviewTitle: Bang, Bang, goes the wallet! Boom,boom,goes the room!!
reviews.reviewText: I had two of the original Sonos 1 speakers before and loved them. The musicsources, premium and free, are great and you can always find something to listen to. Grimacing at the price tag at Christmas time, I nonetheless shelled out money for the big daddy of the Sonos group, hoping I would not be disappointed. I had read several reviews of horrible customer support and lots of instances with failing parts on the 5, but decided to chance it anyway because of the reported great quality of the sound. To keep this short, I have not been disappointed, and now the 5 rips out through the living room with plenty of awesome support from my older Sonos speakers in my bedroom and my office. I know this says it works with Alexa, but since I hate talking to technology and therefore wouldn't buy one of the things if you paid me, I will not comment on Alexa. Still, for the money this costs, I think it is worth it especially if you have other speakers that can support it in different rooms. PSSSSSSST. For even more content, buy a Google Chromecast Audio and plug it into the audio jack in the back of the 5. You'll be glad you did.

I've had Sonos Play:3 for about couple years and was extremely happy with the ease of use and the second. The new Play:5 is a HUGE upgrade. You can feel it in both the bass and the treble ends. The clarity of the sound seemed to be improved as well. For me - definitely worth the money to upgrade! Thanks Sonos for the awesome product.

Bought this as a test speaker before buying another, and was very pleased. At all volumes this speaker is distortion free with great musical, instrument and voice separation. Heavy, well engineered and made... a real first rate single or multiple speaker that will seriously rock any medium or large room or space. Set it up wirelessly with the Sonos iOS app in three minutes. Speakers are subjective, difficult to rate, and will sound different in different locations... so you have to place and tune these speakers carefully - let your ears be your guide! Packaging was superb and they arrived with Amazon Prime right on time. I’m a big Bose user in both cars, home theater, tv sound bars, computer etc., so direct comparison is pretty easy - the Play5 just plain rocks, and you won’t be disappointed.

reviews.reviewTitle: Pleasantly surprised - nice sound in a small package
reviews.reviewText: Pleasantly surprised - I come from a world of separates devoted to high end sound and found this unit to be quite impressive. Lots of sound in a small package - clean, clear, and ample bass extension. Mind you this is certainly not a replacement for a room full high end separates, but I do find myself using the Play 5 more than I thought I would. My favorite part is the interface - so much so that I purchased 2 of the Sonos Connects to run with my receivers. For those looking for a plug and play solution and don't mind the price tag this will suit you well.

reviews.reviewTitle: Beautiful room filling sound, easy to set-up
reviews.reviewText: I listen to most of my music through streaming services, but I also want to jump back into listening to vinyl and I was looking for a solution to combine streaming and LP listening for multi-room broadcasting for a 750sqft NY apartment. I bought a pre-amp for my LP player (Crosley c10) and decided to pair with Play:5 instead of a network receiver. I also got rid of my tv in favor of a projector (Benq ht2050a) connected to a Apple TV. I wanted to minimize the use of cables. AirPlay 2 on Play:5 allowed me to stream audio from the Apple TV with any sound lag, and the Play:5s worked seamlessly with my LP player. These speakers also sound great and fill the room.

my sonos was gone one day, no matter what we did it was not connecting. customer service is worst than the DMV or IRS hotline. just horrible experience and product. when it worked though it was awesome.

I used to be very positive on the product. But serious issues with connectivity have gotten much worse lately. The system consistently doesn’t connect with my iTunes library on my computer. Fine, so I turn to my iPhone. Right now it finished 2 minutes of playing and then cut out. And again. And again. Tried iPad. Nope. I have 3 of the 5’s and one simply stopped entirely. Replaced under warranty. And the next time it fails it’ll be on my dime. My WiFi is an eeros with two extenders. So seems unlikely to be a WiFi failure. Annnd, it just started playing as I’m typing this. Seriously unenjoyable way to listen to music.

I love my Sonos Play:5. The sound quality is amazing, and the ability to move it physically from one room to another without worrying about wires is so convenient. The other thing that is great about Sonos is the app. You can take music from a whole bunch of sources, like Spotify (if you have a subscription), Amazon Music, your own mp3 collection, etc and play them seamlessly. It's really really convenient, and I love it.

I also have the PlayBar and Play1's, so being able to group them and hear the same music in different parts of the house, or being able to move the music to whichever room you're in is really really cool.

It doesn't have bluetooth integration which is kind of weird, but I'm looking to add a bluetooth receiver to the aux in, and seeing how well that works.

reviews.reviewTitle: 5 definitely sounds the best of the three
reviews.reviewText: I have tried out all three levels of the Sonos Play speakers, and also have the soundbar for my TV. Play:5 definitely sounds the best of the three, without a doubt. The Play:3 sounds good as well, but the sound isn't quite as rich and big as this one is. The Play:1 I felt was not worth it, not good enough sound, compared to the other two. I had thought I might want it to easily carry around (like to the bathroom for taking a relaxing bath) or to travel with it, but it just didn't sound good enough to keep at all. So I kept the Play:5 for my bedroom, and the Play:3 for my kitchen, where I needed a smaller speaker for the counter. Very happy.

I will never have another need for another speaker this size in my life. This speaker alone carries sound throughout my house but I decided to go ahead and buy a couple of Sonos Play 1's and all I can say is WOW. I love the app that you need to be able to play any of your music from anywhere and I love the fact that you can connect them or use them separately. These are, by far, the best speakers I've ever had. I just may have to go buy another couple of 1's to make sure the inside and outside of my house is covered. And then next up will be the sound bar.

Really like the sound, the look is OK, nothing special. Setup is ridiculously archaic. You have to plug the speaker into your router with a cable. So...if your speaker is in one room on one floor, and your router is in your office, cart the speaker up to the office to plug it in. This is the only 'IOT' device in my house that requires a physical connection for setup. My ring doorbell/chimes certainly didn't. Surprising, since Sonus seems to want us to think they're 'cutting edge'...

reviews.reviewTitle: The sound is excellent. I purchased this because I wanted a speaker ...
reviews.reviewText: The sound is excellent. I purchased this because I wanted a speaker that could stream Spotify and connect to my turntable, which it does beautifully. Some of the earlier reviews have complained about Spotify compatibility -- that you had to go through the Sonos app to access your Spotify account. THIS IS NO LONGER TRUE. (I've only had this speaker since Dec. 2017, so I think some recent software updates have made the speaker easier to use). I almost exclusively stream to this speaker through the Spotify App -- I just tap "devices available" on my iPhone, iPad or MacBook and the speaker automatically appears via Spotify Connect because all the devices are on the same wireless network. The only time I use the Sonos app is when I need to change the setting to "Line In" because I want to play a record.

reviews.reviewTitle: No messing with bluetooth or powering on...it's just always ready to play amazing sounding music
reviews.reviewText: I know I'm late to the Sonos game, but $500 isn't really an impulse price. That said, I'm so glad I bought this. I'm not very technologically capable and I'm no audiophile but I have to believe you can't do much better than this for seamless home audio. The sound quality is amazing and it's not bad to look at. But the best part is that it's always on, always prepared to play whatever my heart desires. I just hit play on a channel or a specific song when the mood strikes and my new friend obliges instantly. It fills our entire first floor with sound easily--the highest volume is way too high actually (awesome). We have been transporting it outside for nice days because I just love it so much. I'm absolutely going to be buying another Sonos speaker for our basement and a dedicated one for outside (under a roof and appropriately weather proofed, of course). Can't say enough about how much I adore this speaker.

reviews.reviewTitle: Amazing sound but controlling it is absolutely nonsence
reviews.reviewText:
Bought this because it sounded amazing in stores! Little do you know it DOES NOT HAVE BLUETOOTH!!

It is only connectable thru wifi or aux cable, so taking it outside your home is a real headache.

On top of that you have to download the sonos app to use the speaker and that app is unresponsive at times so when you try to change a song or even turn the volume down the speaker does NOT respond so you have to unplug it.

What a huge limitation for such an amazing sounding device. It is the best sounding bluetooth speaker I have ever seen but it DOES NOT HAVE BLUETOOTH, instead a garbage wifi/app based software system, how stupid!

Great sound.+++ I have two Play:5 speakers in one room (stereo setup). But, not so easy to connect to wireless network. After 10 tries, and then purchasing a Boost it finally worked. At first, the Android app indicated that my Netgear WfFi extender was a problem and I needed a Sonos Boost. I purchased a Boost. It was still hard to set-up and now I believe the Boost was not necessary,(Caveat emptor) but not sure if I was misled by Sonos. Now I have a new problem: Amazon Music and SiriusXM will not set up. Tried several times, all failed. Pandora and Spotify worked perfectly. Overall, after a headache, what I have sounds very good. I am not going to jump any more hoops to get my missing music on the device.

I have had Sonos for over ten years at my prior house. they were great but can't compare to this new Sonos Play 5 gen 2. The sound is great! I have a large house and it fills it with quality sound. Don't be afraid to buy this one you won't be disappointed. I tried the Bluetooth speakers (Bose) using my iPhone and every time I got a call the speakers shut off. Not acceptable. The WiFi connection in my opinion is the way to go. It plays and plays and nothing stops it!

reviews.reviewTitle: Sonos make great products and this one is no exception
reviews.reviewText: Sonos make great products and this one is no exception! Very well packaged and high-quality fit n' finish. We have had our PLAY 5 for 3-4 months and it has played music >6 hrs per day in our great room with no issues. We often move it outside when we dine or have guests over for BBQ's and it just sounds great and gets a lot of compliments. It is very easy to control with your smartphone/tablet and is truly a 'plug and play' device. No matter where you move it to in your home as long as it can connect with the network just plug it in and it is ready to go!

This unit went beyond my expectations. It fills my medium size hose with music by itself but I'll definitely pick up another for some separation. I use Amazon streaming. You'll never run out of music.

Has my head been in the sand for this long? The packaging reminded me of how Apple packages there stuff which is fantastic. The craftsmanship is top shelf, the set-up was a breeze, and the sound quality offers deep basses, great midrange and crisp highs. I am not a true audiophile but this Sonos 5 sounds as good, or better, than my Polk speakers in my family room. I'm very impressed.

Well it took me a few minutes to figure out how to get my echo to to send music to the Sonos. I was actually on the phone with customer support and finally figured it out. Fair warning do not ask you're Echo to play this thing at volume 10 I just about fell out of my chair. The sound is rather amazing crisp clean and powerful. So for what it's worth it's worth all the bang for the buck.

reviews.reviewTitle: Super Addition to My Sonos System
reviews.reviewText:
Wow! I was amazed at the heft of this thing when taking it out of the box. That helps explain the clear, accurate, sound coming from this puppy. Though I have it in a smallish-sized room, it's easy to see (hear?) that it could easily fill a much larger room with great music.

If you are familiar with Sonos, you already know how easy it is to set up in a new, or integrate into an existing, Sonos network. If you're not familiar --- it's extremely easy!

The styling is slick/attractive, and the minimal controls are easy to use.

I bought this 'used' through the Amazon Warehouse and have not been disappointed...just a few minor scratches underneath the speaker, but so what? It came in the original packaging, meaning it was well-protected during shipping.

Bought one and was so impressed We bought a second so we could do stereo. They were easy to set up and have amazing sound. They replaced much larger Klipsh speakers and yet their sound is more true and rich. Highly recommend these speakers!

Sounds great, looks great, integrates flawlessly with the entire Sonos system as well as my Lutron Caseta system (used to control is with a Lutron Pico remote). I have two and put them in stereo mode. The sound is amazing. Pair it with a Sonos subwoofer for an outstanding listening experience!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great speakers with a few caveats
reviews.reviewText: Great speakers and easy to setup. The True Tone is fun to use but will not work in a noisy nyc apartment where you cannot control the sound of traffic and subways passing by. Also it’s worth noting that you need to buy two of these speakers if you want to pair with a sound bar and get surround sound. and finally, the Sonos packaging is terrible. It’s like they don’t intend for anyone to open their products.

Couldn't be happier. The sound that comes out of this single speaker is unbelievable. It seems to fill our large greatroom with sound with amazing bass response for such a small single speaker. For years I had a pair of large Cerwin-Vega speakers that were heavy and took up space. The ONLY thing this won't do as well as the CV's is blast out the windows of your house. The volume capability is plenty however unless you are throwing a street party. Worth every penny.

App needs constantly updating. Most recent update now requires latest iOS which older iPads can't run so if you've got an older iPad you're out of luck. ''Update OS or use a different device'' is the advice from Sonos. If you don't have a different device you've now got a $500 brick (and another $200 brick upstairs).

Do not waste your money with this company!

Wife loves the sound, detailed highs and lows, pros and cons are:

If you have a dual or triband wifi router that there are 2 or 3 SSID in the house, it has hard time connecting to the 2.4Ghz one, need to connect or wait for several minutes to finally get it to bring up the music library.

Also, no auto search of network devices, must type in the exact URL to find the music library server on my network, make it hard if I have a USB device that connects to my router's USB port.

The radio station works great!

reviews.reviewTitle: Sonos: More expensive than anything else but at least they look cool.
reviews.reviewText: Nice speaker. Sounds great! The aux-in jacks on the back are useful. I also like that every time I try to use it, I spend the first five minutes updating the software. That gives me time to sit and wonder "Do I really have my playlist as optimized as it could be?" So after 2 hours of sorting through things, I realize I never turned on any music at all and it's time to leave. But at least my software is updated each time.

Best speaker I have ever owned I bought at least four for friends and family my nephew told me it was the best Christmas present he ever had my daughter uses it every single day In her home. I rented a house in Annapolis Maryland for a trade show and the owner had one and every room of his house including his television set I simply downloaded his system to my iPhone and was able to play music in any room at anytime that I want

reviews.reviewTitle: SONOS PLAY:5 - Ultimate Smart Speaker for...
reviews.reviewText:
Awesome product, Sound QUALITY is TOP NOTCH....You'd have never ever experienced...Gone are the days of Bose....
Nothing like this on the entire planet earth for what it delivery, loud, crisp, clear and every single tone which comes out of this box.
Ain't going back to anything else other than Settling to SONOS Play5!!!

reviews.reviewTitle: the listening experience is markedly better. Playback using iPhone 6s is buggy
reviews.reviewText:
Sound is outstanding. Coupled with a second Sonos PLAY:5 for stereo effect, the listening experience is markedly better.
Playback using iPhone 6s is buggy, frequently skipping ahead a couple songs in the playlist. Once system was hardwired to LAN, issues improved and once iPhone was upgraded - playback skipping errors were almost eliminated.
Still no compatibility with AirPlay - so you can only play via Sonos app (quite good) and Spotify app.

Amazin', wonderfull.... another SONOS awesome product!.. The top controls are excellent!, letting you change the songs without the app. The same stunning sound or all SONOS equipments. Money well spent!.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great speaker. $h!t software if you have a lot of music.
reviews.reviewText: The sound from this speaker is really good: rich, clear, deep. A clear step above any wireless or standard computer speaker setup you could currently get. Not quite a proper hi fi but with two of these and a subwoofer I believe you would be close enough that you couldn't tell the difference. Downside is the software: more basic than iTunes and *very* flakey when it comes to connectivity/indexing. When it works it's great but I would say it fails around 15% of the time, at which point you get a generic error message. Usually will work again but could be in a minute, could be in an hour. Support will make you jump through the usual hoops (reboot, reinstall, etc.) but clearly the architecture cannot handle a large remote music library.

We bought two Play:5s into our large kitchen/family/dining room and the setup is amazing. It sounds great in the whole area. My wife was quite skeptical about the pricey speakers—saying I was buying it as a gift for myself only—but she totally loves them now—and admits it was a great idea to buy them for our family. They look great, too, nicely fitting into our style.

+1 for the guy who mentioned the wifi card issue. Make sure if you buy these that you spend the extra 20$ for 4 year protection plan because theres a high probability that the internal wireless system will fail within 1-2 years, which will most likely be after your manufacturers warranty is up. Ive had this happen to me twice now.

Sound is amazing but the speaker generally doesn't work. Can hardly get through a song without skipping it. Also the volume likes to fluctuate at random. It's just hard to use this speaker at all. Sonos support tells me the same thing that I see them telling everyone else, that it's wireless interference. Why is no other device on my network suffering from wireless interference? If sonos is the only thing having the problem, then sorry sonos, your the problem. They either won't fix it or don't know how. If these things are so prone to interference you would think they would and try and figure out a way to fix it. This is a product that you want to love but you just can't. Mine is being returned.

reviews.reviewTitle: Sounds great! Worth the money...for music.
reviews.reviewText: Sounds great with music but lacks the oomph needed for movies which is where the Sonos soundbar does all the sound. What would help tremendously is if users had control over the speakers volume independently. The ability to turn one or two speakers up to proper levels since the Sonos software does not do this well. The problem I’m having is the surround speakers are not loud enough to present surround effect.

reviews.reviewTitle: Setting up the Sonos 5 was easy. The sound is incredible
reviews.reviewText: Many of the other reviews already say exactly what I experienced. Setting up the Sonos 5 was easy. The sound is incredible, and the whole home Wi-Fi experience is terrific. I paired this with a Sono Connect Network Audio player for my Sony 7.1 surround sound in the basement, and it works flawlessly. There's no delay. I can have the same music playing on the first floor and the basement with the push of a button my phone. This is a well-deserved 5 stars. (Now they just need to connect it up with Alexa.)

I had a play1, loved it yet was skeptical of what to expect from the play 5. OMG, I’m so sold on Sonos and the quality of sound from their devices. Yes, it is addictive in that I think I need to add another play 1 to fill in different room. If you’ve got any doubts take the leap and buy it, you won’t regret it,

reviews.reviewTitle: I'm buying a 3rd one for upstairs!
reviews.reviewText: Awesome sound, amazing customer service, and idiot proof!

These speakers are great! I'm an avid listener, and I've always had a good sound system. I was skeptical about wireless speakers. But these are terrific. And two speakers, in stereo, are really amazing. Fill our large, high-ceilinged living room with sound. Easy to control from anywhere in the house. My wife, who is not technologically sophisticated, uses them constantly. These are wi-fi, not Bluetooth BTW. So you need a wireless router.

reviews.reviewTitle: Your music library at your fingertips with awesome sound!
reviews.reviewText:
Wow, flippin' awesome. When used with a connect server, all of the music from your PC is available anywhere in your house or anywhere you have Wi-Fi.

Not only is the Play 5 convenience super-cool but the audio is excellent! Better than Bose Soundock by a huge margin. Bigger of course, but the sound warrants the larger size. Very high quality product.
I am a huge Sonos nerd and honestly didn't even have a real need for this but I got it anyways because I had to have it. It is simply the coolest speaker out there. Sounds amazing and looks amazing.

reviews.reviewTitle: Sonos 5 is an amazing speaker. The sound is crisp and warm at ...
reviews.reviewText: Sonos 5 is an amazing speaker. The sound is crisp and warm at the same time. It is listening bliss. Why only 4 stars? Well, I want it to work through Alexa. But...Alexa keeps saying Living room speaker is off line and it is not. Quite frustrating. Sonos, what say you?

Great sound quality. Fills our entire single-level home with great sound- we have hard stone floors, so wasn't expecting much from the acoustics, but this is excellent. I purchased the Bose SoundTouch speakers for my office, and wish I would have gotten another of these instead.

reviews.reviewTitle: What a great product. From the moment you receive the package ...
reviews.reviewText: What a great product. From the moment you receive the package you know that this is a quality product. It took me literally about 3 minutes to get the speaker set up and added to my existing sonos system.

reviews.reviewTitle: these are insanely great speakers. Purchased several months ago and have been ...
reviews.reviewText: OMG, these are insanely great speakers. Purchased several months ago and have been using them at low- to mid-level volume and thought they were great. Neighbor is on vacation this week, so I thought I'd test them out. So crisp, clear and full, even at full, blasting levels, you seriously can't believe such sound could come out of such a small package. I bought two for stereo. Yes, they're pricey, but you really couldn't ask for a better wireless speaker system. Trust me, no sub-woofer is required for full low-range sound.

My family has been Bose all the way since before I hit puberty. This is my first Sonos product, I am floored by the quality of the sound. I urge everyone to tune it correctly on the app. The difference is quite noticeable.

Really struggling with connectivity. Songs keep skipping when using phone or dropping in volume when using laptop. The Sonos Boost and hard wiring direct to router have not helped. Amazing speaker, but frustrating listening experience.

We love our sonos. It's got some glitches playing music sometimes, but overall, great sound, easy to use and set-up. We tried a Bose system and it was not intuitive to use and was very limited in the streaming options. That got returned and we bought a second Play5 for our cabin in the woods. Way better than the Bose also in terms of audio quality (something that surprised me!) also.

DO NOT BUY!! After purchasing this item the speaker stopped working. Won’t power on won’t do anything. Contacted support and hassled with them for over two months. They are saying there is NOTHING they will do except give me a coupon to go buy a brand new one. So that means I throw this 600 one in the trash and go buy one at a discounted price? NO THANK YOU!!!! I will never buy another sonos system as long as I live. Their customer service is garbage and products are junk. Hope this doesn’t happen to you!!

reviews.reviewTitle: Sound quality is mediocre for the price
reviews.reviewText: The sound quality was not in the area of high fidelity. I have an older Bose SoundDock II hooked up to a connect in the kitchen and it has a better overall sound than this single Play 5. Will be sending ithe Play 5 back. The mid range is weak on the Play 5’s and the treble is also muffled some.

reviews.reviewTitle: Nice sounding speakers and good app
reviews.reviewText: Impressive sound and imaging. I bought a pair for stereo separation and am impressed. Occasionally they have dropouts when music server glitches but that is not the speakers fault.

So cool to be able to wirelessly play really great sounding music on this speaker. Only have one so far but plan to add other speakers to the system over time. Use this with my Amazon Echo to stream music from a variety of sources including my favorite local radio station. I also easily access music files on my Windows 10 desktop computer. Great product!

I highly recommend this speaker.

reviews.reviewTitle: If you love your music, you will be glad you bought this.
reviews.reviewText:
Received our first Sonos Play 5 on Wednesday and set it up in the bedroom; on Friday already back to purchase another one for downstairs. I've been listening to/loving music for decades, but I've never heard it like this--not even live.

You can hear every instrument clearly and completely. This must be what producers have in mind when they make recording decisions. I feel like I finally get it. Laura Nyro's piano, Bonnie Raitt's slide guitar, Boz Skaggs' growl--it's like hearing it for the first time again, only better. First play on it was Beyoncé's Lemonade. Oh, my.

If you love music and have the money, treat yourself and your family to this. It will make home a special place to be. Unfortunately, it makes it even harder to get up in the morning and leave the fabulous tunes to go to work. We're even thinking about using an inverter so we can plug it in for long trips in the car. Not sure we can go back to regular speakers. I'd give it 10 stars if I could.

Great wireless speaker! NOTE: you still need to plug into power, but no speaker wire to run. Sound quality is good as the Sonos speakers really fill up a room with great sound. I thought the Bass and Midrange was really good. No issues streaming music from around the house.

Positives:
- Great and clean design. Huge improvement from last generation. You can stand it up vertically or horizontally.
- Easy to setup.
- Great sound. Even better if you pair it up in stereo mode where you can hook up two speakers to separate the L & R Channels. However, even a single speaker sounds great as there are internal speakers that the software will separate.
- Setup software allows you to do a "sound check" on the iPhone app and will provide EQ settings that are optimal for your room listening experience.
- Streaming was great. No breakup of audio stream. I have seen issues with some blue tooth speakers, but haven't experienced anything negative with Sonos.
- Overall very satisfied with these wireless speakers. No need to run wires anymore. Now if we can do something about the power cord ...

Tradeoffs
- Overall Software. You must use the Sonos software to play music through the speakers. If you're used to using iTunes or whatever software you normally use, then you'll have to adjust a little. For example, Pandora or Amazon run within the Sonos app.
- Ability to stream anything to the speakers is a little problematic. For example, if you want to stream audio from a TV show you're watching on your computer to the speakers is not possible or at least I can't figure it out. You can however connect a physical line-in/out audio cable from your computer directly to the speaker to do that.
- One thing I noticed about the power cable design in the back is that it is a bit flimsy and easy to splice the outer housing of the, so be careful as you plug/unplug and pack the device.

reviews.reviewTitle: ... are listening to a streaming radio station or something like Spotify. I guess this should be obvious but ...
reviews.reviewText: The sound quality really depends on whether you are listening to a streaming radio station or something like Spotify. I guess this should be obvious but it wasn't to me until I subscribed to Spotify. You can't play the free Spotify on Sonos, only premium Spotify. Sirius/XM doesn't sound all that great. Neither do most streaming stations. That can be due to a number of factors like the bitrate the radio station streams at how and how they compress their signal. But now that I can play Spotify Premium on the Play 5 I think it sounds great.

reviews.reviewTitle: THE BEST SPEAKER IN THE MARKET
reviews.reviewText:
This is the best speaker. The audio quality is amazing. If you have lossless format (or Tidal Hifi) songs then you'll be blown away.

I am so glad I got it.

Using the speaker for a room that’s approx 15x15. This speaker is more than enough. A subwoofer is not needed. Heavy bass. Very clear mid levels. Super easy setup as well. Guess the only complaint is price. From all the speakers I was comparing, this was on the high side.

Nice design with the white speaker

Very good sound, especially when paired with a Sonos Sub. I deducted one star because the SONOS controller Apps ask users to sign into the Sonos website before using this product. This sign-in provides no value to me and is fairly obtrusive when using the Sonos App on several devices.

reviews.reviewTitle: Sonos: still better than HomePod in 2018
reviews.reviewText:
I like the AirPlay2 integration however, at the time of iPhone XS Max Launch, the Sonos software did not allow TruePlay so I had to configure with another iOS legacy device.

Also, when integrated with Sonos One & Alexa, the playback can be uneven i.e.: Flash Briefing plays loud on 5 vs One

Over the course of 3 years, I spent more than $2,500 on a whole-house Sonos system. Comprising three Play:5's, a Connect, a Sub-Woofer and a few other gadgets. Sound quality was excellent, installation simple, does everything it is supposed to do and then some. And that's the problem. Sonos recently updated their privacy policy, allowing themselves to collect voice information on my house and use it any way they want to (the latest Sonos have microphones in them). Excuse me? I am not giving you blanket permission to spy on me and my family.

Needless to say, I refused to acknowledge this and refused the software upgrade. In return, Sonos bricked my $2,500 investment. I cannot get squat out of it. The arrogance of this company, the disdain in which they hold their customers, is unprecedented. I sold all the material and bought into another technology.
Great clean full sound, it blows my Bose speakers away!!! Looking to add more in the future..

After buying one I bought two more and a sub so they must be doing something right. Sound quality is what you would expect from an integrated wireless unit of this price point.

My dedicated stereo amp does sound better, but honestly I use these more often because I have them positioned around the house in the kitchen, in the workout space, in the play area... and its very easy to send music from the phone to any and or all of them very quickly.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great until the wireless card stops working...
reviews.reviewText: Like many other buyers here I think the product is great. And like some of the buyers here (read the critical reviews too!) I had problems with the wireless reception, for me about 10 months in. Tech support determined it was the wireless card in the speaker itself and I was still under warranty so they shipped me a new speaker, but like the others this has happened to I am concerned when this happens again and I'm no longer under warranty.

The sound from this speaker deserves 7 Stars out of 5. However, Alexa does NOT work well with this speaker. We have to ask several times in different ways to get Alexa to push music to the Sonos. Also, it's hard to push a particular song to the Sonos from Spotify. Alexa always wants to use Amazon over Spotify - ugh. Also, the Sonos App is horrible. It doesn't work smoothly. It's difficult to find songs and albums and stations etc. Sonos needs to improve the contorls and interface. The totally have the best sounding speaker i've ever heard - I used to be a Bose guy. But the contorls and interface - esp through the smart phone and Alexa - are really really lacking. Where is Sonos with Google Home????

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Speaker, room filling sound, easy to setup, wish that it had access through siri.
reviews.reviewText: These Sonos Speakers are a great supplement to our in ceiling home speakers, we remodeled our home and we didnt put wiring in for speakers to to some rooms in our house, and the sonos speakers are great fit for the rooms where we wanted music but did not add speakers. the Play 5 fits well in our master bedroom and we have a couple of play 1's in our bathrooms where we didn't wire for speakers. setting up the speaker is as easy as plugging it in. then you can run the tuning app, where you wave your iPhone around the room for a minute while the speaker makes this really trip sound so that the speaker can acoustically map the room. its actually pretty cool. they work great, they have a simple interface, and they make it easy to play music throughout the house. these play 5's have microphones built in to them. I wish that I could control the sonos app with voice access, like " hey Siri, play sonos" but that is not available yet. hopefully it will be soon!
Sounds great, but too expensive, should be less than $450. I'm waiting for a sale or price drop so I can pick up a second one and use them in a stereo, left/right, setup.

What can I say... You get what you pay for... Amazing power and clarity!! I have had this for 2 years now and it has performed flawlessly. The app can be annoying with the constant updates, but it's not a deal breaker. Aux connection in the back, but no bluetooth functionality... WiFi Only. So bluetooth buyers beware... I have this tied to an apple music subscription and it works great. No complaints so far... Only stellar and clear audio. I'm a certified audio engineer and pro tools operator; and will be buying a second one soon to go stereo.

reviews.reviewTitle: The sound is the best out there
reviews.reviewText: I have been a Bose fan for years but I have to say the Sonos Play 5 can run circles on the Bose. this speaker has adjustable sound through the equalizer in the app. The sound is the best out there. Price, well if you want quality you pay for it. I just ordered two Play 1's to go wth this speaker.

reviews.reviewTitle: Sitting listening to some of the most beautiful music written while I write this review
reviews.reviewText: Sitting listening to some of the most beautiful music written while I write this review. I do not consider myself a sound aficionados but it sounds great to me. I especially like ease of setting up and use.

reviews.reviewTitle: Sounds terrific now and the room has a better feel all ...
reviews.reviewText: I replaced a stereo pair of Play 1’s with a 5 and a single 1 so I could get a bit more bottom end. Sounds terrific now and the room has a better feel all around as the 5 seems to be really transparent, can’t tell where the sound is emu sting from.

reviews.reviewTitle: I love the clear sound and the setup is incredibly easy
reviews.reviewText: I love the clear sound and the setup is incredibly easy. The app also makes finding music to play amazingly easy - from all the music I own stored on my computers and phone (the app just finds it) to all available streaming music. All in one place!
First sonos buy for me. Did it thru Alexa and saved $$. Love it.

I have had this product for 2.5 years. I am an electrical engineer and have high end stereo equipment and had same for decades. This is a great product. The software has worked fine for me. The sound quality is excellent.
Impressive. The sound is amazing. Worth every penny and more. If you want the best sound, buy it.

reviews.reviewTitle: it is like lisitening to a concert at home
reviews.reviewText: Play5 has much richer sounds than Play3, it is like lisitening to a concert at home! Great quantity and easier to set up!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great design and even better sound.
reviews.reviewText: Great design and even better sound. The speaker packaging and build quality are really good. But the sound from this unit is amazing. Clear mid-range and great bass. Definitely worth the money.

reviews.reviewTitle: Hands down the best smart speaker on the market...
reviews.reviewText:
Hands down the best smart speaker on the market... and one of the top 5 home speakers period (smart or otherwise). I love this speaker. I have it integrated with my Alexa (by way of Smartthings), Smartthings, Harmony remote, and my Smart TV. It's my music player, alarm clock, streaming audio, status announcer (e.g. "The front door is open", "The temperature is 72 degrees", etc.), it is the voice of my Alexa (by using line in and a separate bluetooth receiver), it is a secondary Siren for my smoke and CO detector and intruder alarm, it is my TV speaker, and it is decoration (I say this last part because I think it is a very nice looking speaker). Don't let the size fool you. It has some SERIOUS bass. Obviously it's not a sub, but as close as you can get without adding a dedicated subwoofer (btw, I used to be an audio engineer, so I know a good speaker when I hear one). And that kind of leads me into the quality of the sound. I didn't test the frequency response or the 1W 1M dB SPL, etc, etc... all that's on the spec sheet, I'm sure. But just the subjective opinion of a guy whose seen and tested HUNDREDS of speakers.... this speaker sounds fantastic. I might have bought it just for the sound quality even if it didn't have all the other bells and whistles. You will NOT be disappointed. The app could be a little better designed. And my only other complaint is that I wish that it would default back to the "line-in" when a transient signal comes in from another source. But I worked around that minor flaw using my Smartthings app and CoRE (a rule engine for smartthings). But you don't have to be all tech-y to use this. It's basically plug and play. Just sign in with your favorite music service from the app... or connect with your computer or phone through the app with a couple of clicks... or just plug something into the back... and you're off.

Only one other minor complaint was that I thought it was poor insight of Sonos to make a non-removeable logo. That means that if I want a stereo pair upright then they would look funny with the logo pointing the same way on both sides. But then I realized that it was me that had the poor insight. They put little rubber feet (the good ones that won't come off...ever) on all 3 sides... and I realized... what is SONOS upside down? Duh! So, it can easily be set up to look symmetrical when using as a stereo pair. Seems they thought of everything... even down to how their name would look.

I loved this one product SOOOOO much that I just bought a Playbar, a sub, and 12 Play 1 speakers to make a full on 5.1 and put more speakers all over the rest of my house.

I was skeptical that a relatively small package could deliver a good listening experience, but after reading reviews and hearing a good report from my audio pro friend, I took the plunge and tried the Sonos 5. I have been pleasantly surprised at the sound quality. Considering the functionality and sound, the Sonos system is superb at it's price point. I am very particular about my music listening, and would not buy a component without having it deliver excellent sound quality.

Get ready to troubleshoot. This isn’t plug and play and even with live support, no connection to Alexa. But it makes you feel like having all your friends over to celebrate something when it’s rockin.
Until Sonos stabilizes their software I do not recommend their products. Music stops playing. Not recommended to stream from Wi-Fi-connected device. Phono has to be grossly compressed.

I bought a Sonos PLAY:5 and a PLAY:3 for the downstairs and was so pleased that I followed up with another PLAY:5 for upstairs. It's such a pleasure to reach for my iPhone and have my music playing all around the house before my feet hit the floor in the morning. Both the PLAY:3 and 5 are great, but if you are trying to decide, I'd go for the 5 for the really full, rich sound it produces.
What a dream! I have two of these Play:5s, 2 lay 1's and 1 Alexa equipped play 1. Just received a Sonos sound bar to mount under my TV. This is a great product family

reviews.reviewTitle: Can't believe how much i enjoy music now with Sonos
reviews.reviewText: Can't believe how much i enjoy music now with Sonos. The audio quality is amazing from this size speaker. But its so much more than a speaker. I highly recommend to anyone how truly enjoy's music as a lifestyle and is always listening to something around the house.

As far as what people say about it being limited by having to use Sonos' software, as long as you have one of the paid streaming services (Apple Music, Spotify, etc) the software is great in my opinion.
