reviews.reviewTitle: We love it so much in fact
reviews.reviewText: I bought the Play:5, a Boost, and four Play:1s for my husband for Christmas, because he had been griping that we have tons of electronics but can't play music! Nothing works together. At first he didn't want it, but I set everything up (yup, me, a 59-year-old woman, it was that easy) and he was over the moon! Glorious rich music has filled our large two story house every day since. We played the complete Beatles set, and heard things we'd never heard before. Instruments, chords, singing - who knew it was there until Sonos! We love it so much in fact, we just ordered a Soundbar, Connect, and two more Play:1s. The comparability and flexibility of the system is what sold us too.

I would rate this product a 10 star rating out of 5 .:) All aspects of my experience with theThe Play 5 Speaker, exceeded my expectations. I was impressed starting with the Chat capability at the Sonos website where they answered my many questions real time ...when I purchased the product it was evident that this was a company that focused on quality from end to end. Quality is evdident in the details from the packaging to the App.
The app was awesome and the installation was elegant and sophisticated . The music sounds great from the Speakers...music sounds good with only one Speaker in the room but I preferred to have them paired...the ability to walk thru my house in the different rooms and listen to music is exactly what I was hoping for and there is no lag or echo between rooms ....it is easy to use the App to group or ungroup the rooms. You can even play a raido station in one room while listening to music in the other rooms. It is really amazing it is so flexible. I can play my Audible books by plugging in my Echo Dot and using the Line In feature from the App. I look forward to when Sonos and Audible are more closely integrated...and apparently there are plans to have more synergy with Amazon Echo and the Sonos speakers. Anyway...other than the fact I couldn't stop buying more until I had 2 in every room....I am very happy. Although I chose to use Sonos 5's in most rooms there is one room that I used a pair of Sonos 1's and they too sound great.....I have been very impressed!! I can understand why they are somewhat pricey but you get quality for the price.
This is a piece of art. Pure hi-if sound. I have several sonos 1, sound bar, but this sonos 5 is the best..

reviews.reviewTitle: good sound but need much more work...
reviews.reviewText: read many good reviews. hoped it was a out of this world speaker but once i got it and played with it for a week it was bit disappointing. here is how it actually works with amazon echo. echo act as a receiver but once it's hooked up echo the speaker on the echo turns itself off or it plays a separate stream. i think the separate stream is a bug. echo and sonos 5 WILL NOT SYNC. also the Sonos player on the droid phone is more to be desired. the volume doesn't go on until 50% and once it does it kicks in hyper drive. it's loud but given the control being your phone it's limited.i tried to hook it up to my cable box for my tv. Same thing. has to be controlled by phone app. EQ is really limited considering it's $500 per unit. it has only two tone control and stereo option i expected more. considering it's totally based on phone app it's a glorified speaker only. i rather spend the money on a Bose system with everything built in. Also if you want different music to play in different room using Amazon music you have to get a multi user account. there is only one speaker head set jack if you want to hard wire this to devise. it still needs work in my opinion. the new 5g wireless has issues connecting. perhaps i was expecting too much given that it's a external speakers for a devise. basically it's a computer speaker that is on steroids. would i spent thousands to hook up my house with it? i doubt it very much.

To me, it's important to have tech support, and you get that with the products from Sonos.

reviews.reviewTitle: Spectacular product with Superb Support and Functionality
reviews.reviewText:
I purchased my first Sonos speaker (Play 5) and I've had it for almost a week now. I say this is my "first" Sonos speaker because I expect to be buying more over the coming months. Before buying the Play 5, I had purchased a W9 speaker from Definitive Technology. The W9 has incredible sound. But the one I got was broken and would only connect by the audio jack. So it went back. I was also not impressed with the Definitive app and so I decided to try a different company. The Sonos app had great reviews and the more I read the more I decided that functionality is also very important. So I ordered the Play 5.
The Play 5 easily connected to my home network and to my iPhone 6. The Sonos app works great and it plays very nice with the Spotify app. The Play 5 also connected very easily with my wife's iPhone and iPad. But it would not connect to my older iPad. So I sent emails to Sonos discussing the issue I was having. After the first idea didn't fix the problem, they suggested I contact them and work in real time. I did that and I was EXTREMELY impressed with the problem solving capabilities of the tech I talked with. He connected to my network and quickly diagnosed the source of the communication problem in my home network. A firmware update to my router and everything was fixed and working great on my iPad! That's right ... the problem had nothing to do with their product, but they helped me identify the problem and resolve the issue with one 20 minute phone call. Now that's what I call super service!
So what can I say about the Play 5 sound quality? It's very very good. I must say, however, it is not quite as good as the sound I got from the W9. But I am still very happy with the quality. And the functionality and service more than make up for the tiny difference in sound quality.
I also have a Simply Smart hub in my house that provides lots of convenient automation. The Play 5 also works with this system and will play text to speech announcements to warn me of potential issues. Just icing on the cake that the W9 couldn't touch ...
So my recommendation is the following... if you want great sound, excellent functionality and support then get a Sonos Play 5. If you want the very best sound you can get at this sized speaker and price range and you don't mind the hassles of poor functionality then maybe the W9 is a better option for you. For me, I'm very happy with my first Play 5 and I expect continued satisfaction as I expand.

reviews.reviewTitle: Each SONOS speaker can be hooked up via a wireless mesh network they create via a very easy setup app (or program if you use you
reviews.reviewText:
The sound on these is truly remarkable. Each SONOS speaker can be hooked up via a wireless mesh network they create via a very easy setup app (or program if you use your computer), provided at least one speaker is hooked up to an active Ethernet port on your router or walljack.

I spent about a half hour fiddling with the sound to get it right for my place. Apparently Apple users get the distinct privilege of using TruePlay, while us Android users are regrettably left out.

I use them for Netflix, movies, music, as well as an array of games. They function wonderfully with each media. Unfortunately, they don't provide true surround sound unless the media you're using has that encoded. It still does a good job of splitting up a signal into surround, though.

Given their very steep price, I attached each to a nice surge protector.

So I bought Sonos play5 as Christmas gift for my wife.
When she found out how much I payed for it she almost had me return it, then she listen to this incredible sounds coming from the sonos box.
Two days later "honey, we need one for the basement". No objections.
Buy it, you will not be dissapointed.

reviews.reviewTitle: Bose has NOTHING on the Sonos! Best Speaker hands down
reviews.reviewText:
We were debating between this and the Bose system for our lake condo. Am I ever glad we went with the Sonos system! The sound from the Sonos Play 5 is absolutely incredible. The guests in our condo couldn't believe that much sound could come from such a tiny speaker. We have since ordered a Sonos Play 3 and a Sonos Play 1 for the rest of the condo. We want these speakers in every room!

Pros:
- Easy to setup
- Easy to control from a phone
- Incredible sound (vocals are crystal clear)
- Deep base
- Small speaker for decor purposes

Cons:
- App drops out every now and then where it loses connection with the speaker. This can be fixed using the Sonos Boost if you are having WIFI issues.

Here is my giant SONOS review it will have information on other speakers and such but this way you can make an informed decision on what to buy and how things work.

First off the SONOS system is AMAZING. Plug things in, hit the app and everything just finds each other. It took me longer to unpack the speakers than to hook them up. The packaging for these things is better than anything I have unboxed. They took the time to make sure everything fit and fit in the box perfectly along with the heft of the cardboard. So packaging gets an A+

Speakers:
PLAY 1 - great speaker, smallish size with a bit of heft to the speaker. This will be my only negative thing about SONOS and it's not really a negative but if I had it to do over again I would have spent the extra $100 for additional PLAY 3 speakers and not the PLAY 1.

PLAY 3 - this speaker kicks, it's highs are high it's lows are low and the sound is amazing. With two of these in a stereo set up they fill the room with sound and do sound great.

PLAY 5 - OK MAC DADDY - this is THE speaker but the price is brutal but again, this is THE speaker. I have two of these in a big room and it FILLS the room with sound. I would buy all PLAY 5's if money and space were not an issue. This is a BIG speaker with big sound and a BIG price tag.

AMP - I already had a great set of Klipsch speakers with a big subwoofer so I thought the AMP would be a good purchase. I was right. The sound through my speakers is amazing, my sub adds to the rest of my speakers so I can dial up the treble a bit to brighten the room. I was surprised that this amp would drive my speakers coming from a big Yamaha receiver but it does and does it well. The speakers like power so they work best at higher volumes but I'm also filling a big room with sound so it works well. I tend to run these when I am running another set in a near room for fill and the added punch of my subwoofer. If you have a good set of speakers the AMP is the way to go to use those speakers with your new set up.

SONOS BOOST - I went with this just because I thought a secondary network would be better, I can't say if it is or it isn't but I do know my music sounds great with no drops & all my other devices don't seem to care I have a few SONOS speakers playing at the same time.

All in all this is BIG investment, but well worth it for the ease of set up and the sound quality of this system. I have been an audiophile for years and this is not audiophile quality as I am streaming SiriusXM or Pandora but with some of my lossless music this system holds it own.

Even if you just pick up one speaker, this system will change your music habits but it is also like a dangerous drug, you'll want more and more. I'm up to 11 pieces of SONOS equipment so you know I love it, I just don't like spending all that money.

UPDATE: 10/29/16

We still LOVE our SONOS, we are building an addition on our house and new garage. Needless to say all rooms will be SONOS equipped. I am having the electricians add outlets so I can mount my SONOS and have the ability to move them. I am also adding outdoor speakers (NOT SONOS) so I am having the speaker wires run to a closet so I can put a SONOS AMP in there to drive the outdoor speakers.

Adding to the system with the additon, SONOS AMP, 2x Play5 for bedroom, 2x Play1 for master bath, 2x Play3 for family/great room, 2x Play5 for garage (yes my garage ROCKS, I had a Yamaha receiver w/4 speakers & sub in garage I'm tearing down) also adding a SONOS Sub for a little more low end (I have a Klipsch 1000w powered sub in my living room so will need more bass punch in the new part of the house).

Sadly I'm sure I'll add more as time and funds permit, kitchen remodel next summer and I'm deciding how and where I want to mount my SONOS so when I'm cookin' I can be rockin' also...

Someday there will be a "support group" for us SONOS junkies, I can't stop...

reviews.reviewTitle: My best purchase EVER! Well designed product, easy to use, easy to install, mind-blowing music quality.

reviews.reviewTitle: A Bit Pricey, But So Worth It!
reviews.reviewText:
I have tried several blue tooth and airplay speakers. The Bluetooth speakers didn't have much range and seem very limited. Airplay is just flakey and won't hold a solid Wi-Fi connection. After a couple of year's of frustration, I ended up wanting to throw a speaker through the window on Thanksgiving day,

After reading lots of reviews here on Amazon, I decided to try a Sonos Play:5 speaker. What a difference! This speaker truly sounds great (to my admittedly unprofessional ears). It was nicely packaged, appears well built, and most really packs a punch. It was so easy to set up. The app provides lots of source choices, including my iTunes library, most internet streaming services, and now Apple Music. They are unobtrusive in a room and might even be called handsome.

The Sonos app is so simple and flexible. Even my wife (who is a technophobe) loves it. The Trueplay feature works very well and is easy to use to tune the speakers to a specific room. We now have four of the Play:5 speakers (in two paired sets). We also have a Play:3 speaker and six Play:1 speakers spread throughout the house.

There is no easier way to add great-sounding music to every room in an older house.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great speaker can’t wait to populate throughout the house

Bought this one used and it works great. Its is a nice addition to my other play 5's and Sonos one's.

reviews.reviewTitle: I initially thought this was one of the greatest purchases I had ever made!
reviews.reviewText:
Third update:
I keep going back and forth with my review. I have had multiple contacts with SONOS regarding drop-outs in the middle of songs or complete disconnects. I am somewhat tech-savvy and have very upgraded router, extender, etc. and still the problems persist. These speakers are a POS!
Second update: After speaking with tech I now have my speaker system hooked up in the best way and it is working great. For me, it is not inconvenient to hard-wire two of the speakers to my router (instead of using Wifi) and this makes all the difference. I love SONOS.
UPDATE: When the system works, it is fantastic, but way too often the system crashes and it is really becoming annoying. I had originally scored this system 5 STAR, but now they are down to 2 STARs and falling. Below is my original review:

I have two of these in the living room for truly outstanding stereo sound. And it is so incredible easy (even fun) to set it up through the smartphone app. The app allows access to a computer music library as well as access to streaming music from all the major sources. There is even a way to set up the treble and bass and balance though the app. Sonos speakers in different rooms can even play from different sources at the same time. I feel so smug, having yet another use for my iPhone.
There is no need for such a setup in my TV room, where I already have all my surround sound components, but in other rooms, for example, my living room, which has a fireplace and where we particularly like to sit when not watching TV, this item is ideal. (Of course, Sonos also has a line of surround sound options!)

I have been a die hard Bose fan.....until I encountered the Sonos Play 5. We met at the store, and it came home with me. It was the moment we got home and all set up that I knew we needed to add more to the family. Within 2 weeks I ordered another Play 5 to join the party. I am amazed at the quality sound that comes from this, rich base and crisp clear sound. So easy to set up as just one speaker or group them together for surround sound. It's safe to say that I am addicted. I have two Play 5's and love them, I plan to add the sound bar and the sub woofer as soon as possible. These definitely rival the sound of the Bose systems, which I didn't think was possible. Invite your friends over, bust out the party lights, add some tunes to your Sonos playlist and you have yourself a party!!

reviews.reviewTitle: My wife and I are enjoying awesome sounds that fill our large home from just this ...
reviews.reviewText: This speaker is OUTSTANDING!!! My wife and I are enjoying awesome sounds that fill our large home from just this one speaker. Absolutely pleased!

The sound is awesome. God help you if you change the router, add a speaker, or want to utilize the remote on another device. I have to call customer support every time. Nothing is intuitive. If it’s working, the sound is really amazing.
Sound is fantastic and the single speaker can easily be heard everywhere in a large two-story home.

reviews.reviewTitle: Sonos has redefined home music and entertainment - unreal
reviews.reviewText:
We purchased ours on black Friday 2016 - but the better deals rolled on cyber Monday - FYI - Wait for the best deals! Hopefully I can save you a little.

I have to admit, radio around the house at different speakers which each speaker individually controlled through an App and controlled / played through wifi is genius. We have ham radio operators near our house, so any bluetooth speaker devices would randomly start blirting out ham radio stuff.. "..breaker breaker 1-9, this is cali 5-5-5, come in, do you here, over?.." It gets very old. I love music, and sonos speaker quality is unmatched. We hooked up the old LG home theater speakers to compare, and there is no comparison, you'll really appreciate sonos if you get to hear that comparison. We wake up every morning to the sonos alarm, which plays music of our choice at a prescribed time to get us out of bed (we use cell phones as back up alarms, too). If you like quality sound that can be precisely controlled in each room down to what song is playing, this system (play bar, sonos 5, sonos 1's) is for you.

reviews.reviewTitle: Decent, but lacking a few technical features the be considered state of the art.
reviews.reviewText:
Update: The Sonos community forms are not moderated and openly hostile to anyone who has any criticism. Those without unwavering loyalty need not join.

Cons: The software user experience is dated, there is no Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app, there is no Bluetooth receiver, there is not control on the speaker to turn the external audio input on/off- you have to launch the app, DLNA (Digital Living Network Alliance) is not officially supported, unknown if it contains a microphone to accept voice commands with a future update, you have to stay within the Sonos ecosystem if you want multiple speakers to be in sync- there is a 30 second delay between the speaker playing a local radio station and the station playing on my shower radio (some of which is an Internet delay), and Sonos doesn't have a portable speaker- preferably water resistant for use in the shower.

Pros: There is a 1/8" audio input, so you can either plug your audio source directly into it, or get an external Bluetooth receiver and plug it in, such as http://amzn.to/2csVOqh. Remote control from multiple devices, decent sound (but not as good as a traditional high end speaker), and looks good.

Odd: Wireless speaker requiring AC power. Heavier than it looks.

We have two speakers separated by about 25 ft up in the corners of a large room with a cathedral ceiling. I am overwhelmed every day at the quality and beauty of the sound.
It's hard to imagine being happier ...

reviews.reviewTitle: So Glad I Bought This And So Will You
reviews.reviewText:
This is one of the best buys I've EVER made for audio/visual gear. I have amazon Prime, Sirius/XM, Pandora and more and this sleek, well-built unit streams from these and many other sources seamlessly. It also has an app that plays FM radio stations, so I can hear radio too.

The set-up was about as easy as walking and chewing gum. The unit searches for a wireless network, then, using an iPhone app, guides you thru the set-up process, which takes all of a few minutes. Then....BAM...CLEAR, CRISP WARM sound caresses your ears. The sound gave me goose bumps, as I stared at it in wonder. I jammed-out to some rock-n-roll as I prepared dinner for myself and my gf, and once she arrived, changed the music to one an Irish music station, in honor of St. Patrick's Day!

Thanks to Sonos for creating this wonderful devise.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great sound. Expensive but well worth the money for the quality
reviews.reviewText: Well worth the money for the quality of sound that this thing puts out.

I guess I SHOULD have given Sonos Play:5s only four stars because of the ridiculous price they charge for this thing!
That aside, I'm extremely pleased with these speaker's sound quality, control software and overall functionality.

The Sonos products do what no other product does(AFAIK). They allow you to play music thru-out your living space wirelessly.
Further, you can select speakers(other Sonos products) to play different tracks simultaneously.
You can choose songs from your music library to form a cue.
Re:cue; you can change the song order, add/delete, SAVE etc. Like an ITunes playlist, only better.
You can adjust EQ via Bass/Treble control.
You can adjust volume or mute, pause/continue, cue fwd/rev, etc.
I'm able to play music stored on my PC, controlled by my phone/tablet. (you don't need music on each device)
TuneIn radio (comes with the software) has 100,000 stations to choose from. They play flawlessly.
You can do all this from your PC, tablet or smart phone. How do you top this?
SEVERAL people can perform all these functions SIMULTANEOUSLY. (which gets interesting when your child is home from college LOL)

If you ask me, it's a miracle! "Ah but, setup must be difficult!", you say.
Nope, setup was a snap. Once unpackaged and plugged in, I downloaded the software and configured the speakers in less than 30 minutes. REALLY! The software is simple and intuitive.

Cons:
Price
I wish they had a better equalizer program. The current one has a basic treble/bass slide bar.
I wish they had outdoor speakers. I wish they had wireless headphones.

Note:
Sonos product all require AC electric supply i.e. plug them in. They're wireless, not battery operated; which I think is a good thing.
My experience:
My highest priority was to be able to play music off my PC located in the 26'x26' kitchen/LR/DR open floor plan, over a set of decent quality speakers. The thought of integrating the whole house seemed wonderful, albeit unattainable. We listen to a variety of music, but mostly rock, jazz and jazz fusion. Occasionally, we like to blast it. How loud? "loud enough to NOT hear myself sing" LOL. I wanted to "hit it out of the park", so I wound up buying 2 Play:5s and Sonos Sub.
First, I set up the Play:5s to see if/how they would work. They immediately reminded me of Apple products with they're ridiculous gratuitous packaging. I mean the boxes alone must cost $25! LOL
As I said, the setup was a snap. I downloaded the app from the Sonos site*. It loaded quickly and I was on my way. Setup** was a couple of screens similar to pairing blue tooth stuff. What did take a while, was importing my 10K track music library(There's a serious issue here too! see below.)

As for sound quality, I'd rate the speakers as "very good", to "excellent". If one considers the size of the format, ease of setup and they are wireless, I'd say "excellent"! I paired the speakers as stereo and listened to flawless music stream for about an hour. The bass response was so good, I almost didn't open the sub. I'm glad I did! While a huge expense for a seemingly frivolous component, the Sonos Sub is amazing! It definitely adds another dimension to the system.

Several days later, I bought the Sonos starter set (2 Play:1s). I put one in the 12'x18' bedroom and one in the 24'x30' garage. Admittedly, these speakers do not deliver the sound quality of the 5's, but when you consider the size of the format, they absolutely rock!
I'm saving my $ for more Sonos products!

------------NOTES----------------------------------------------
*I downloaded the app from Sonos. There's another app on the google app site which is rated rather low. I don't know if they are the same.
**You need ethernet (hard wire) connection for the first Sonos product you install. Later, you can move remove the wire or move the speaker wherever you like.
***my ITunes PLAY LISTS did NOT import. The library is all there and the playlists titles are there, but the data within the playlists is erroneous and does not play. I'm on Sono's site attempting to fix this. WARNING, there appears to be NO real FIX at this time.
UPDATE: I found an esoteric file "fix". It will work short term. If you're good with your PC file system, you can do it too.
FLASH! I was contacted by Sonos support regarding this post. I'll update.

UPDATE-
I'm about 30 days into these products. I listen to them almost daily. ( just ordered 2 more P5s)
The Music stream(over my network) has been flawless.
I experienced 2 or 3 device "lockups" on my S5 phone, which were quickly averted with an app restart.
My ITunes playlist problem persists. Sonos has been very attentive, emailing me several times about it. They say the issue is in ITunes(I don't doubt them), but I can't find the playlist files in order to examine and repair them.
I WISH the P5s had more treble (brighter). I play them with the treble setting maxed out 100% of the time.
I WISH the software had a real equalizer, rather than the vanilla bass/treble adjustments.
UPDATE-
I purchased 2 additional P5s. Now I have 2P5s + Sub in one room(24'x24') and 2P5s standalone in another(20'x20' with lower ceiling). I'll say the standalones are still pretty impressive. In fact, the sub tends to be a bit over-the-top and requires adjustment on some songs. Generally for classical music I'll turn it up a notch, then have to back it off for rock music. It's interesting to hear the extra bass when listening to talk radio. The standalones are by NO MEANS lacking. Don't hesitate to get two P5s if you can't afford the sub.
Really impressed. Before it arrived I was considering getting a second one to make a pair for the bedroom. Not needed, one speaker fills the room. Alexa/Echo works great too!!
Great speaker

This is simple to sum up.

It's VERY good.

It's also VERY expensive.

Likely won't be my last Sonos purchase.

Replace old large speaker system.
Gets more use do to convenience.
Very nice

Awesome sound and great support from their tech staff. Was able to sync with Alexa myself, very easy. Issue was I have an ipod classic from probably 2009 that has approximately 60gbs of music on it. I was able to get an old Sonos 100 doc off amazon for around $80 but could not get them to work together. The firmware on the new Play 5 was not compatible. Many, if not most companies, would have used this opportunity to force me to buy new technology generating an additional sale. Not Sonos, they were pleasant and helpful and solved my problem quickly. It is hard to justify purchasing something this expensive if you really do not need/want really crazy speakers. A $20 bluetooth one could do the job for small get togethers.

I bought this for college. It is beyond worth it. I place it on my table and if the bass is slightly deep at a moderate volume I can feel vibrations. It is crisp and delivers powerful music. You can really crank it up too and just fill a room with loud while you enjoy some loud.

While I do not get to use it at max very often, medium to medium high already gives quite a rich, pleasant experience daily. Setting up without a private wifi system was a bitch though. Buy this with the two sided jack if you plan on using your phone or computer with this if you are on public/shared wifi.

I am definitely going to save up to buy the sub-woofers for when I move out and maybe another Play 5 just so I can feel real surround sound.

reviews.reviewTitle: This never has satisfied me for what I paid for this
reviews.reviewText: Bought 2 of these in Sept 2015, & a play 3 later on. This never has satisfied me for what I paid for this, & I have been very patient as it is now 2018. Go to Sonos site & download software onto desktop computer, was windows 8 & now 10, power up speakers to introduce to network & software. Problem is if you look at the on screen system, breath on it, turn on microwave, or stream video & change channel the system stops playing & does not respond. If you close & restart, then it has a problem loading selected music or playlist. When you do get to load up the que with music it can't find your system, speakers. Go back to site to update soft ware multiple times over 3 yrs with improvement. It just gets tired & stops.

I guess my expectations were higher based on other reviews I've read. I took a lot of time researching both on Amazon and on other websites and to me, the sound quality is just okay. The highs are very brassy and the lows are muddy. I had high hopes! The integration with IOS is terrible as well and the app is not very user friendly. Debating on whether or not to return the item or just live with it because of its convenient expandability and integration with Alexa. The styling of the speaker is attractive. Looks way better than the Sonos 3 for sure. Overall, is it worth $500? In my opinion it's overpriced; you are paying for the expandability, the name, and the partnership with Amazon.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not especially technically savvy mom installs Sonos players successfully and enjoys own music and Amazon Prime Playlists!
reviews.reviewText:
I am not especially technically savvy, but I have been feeling like I needed a better music option and I love the SONOS systems. We got a Sonos Play:5 for our very large eat in kitchen and one for the living room, a SONOS Play:3 for the master BR and the basement playroom, and SONOS Play:1 for the kids rooms. I have successfully linked it to our music on iTunes. I moved the iTunes files to our Apple Airport, which is on all the time. This was the hardest step of the installation. I have also linked the SONOS app to Amazon Prime Music because we can access that through our Amazon Prime shipping status (who knew...I didn't until recently). All of the SONOS players have good audio quality, though only the 3 and 5 are in Stereo. The 5 is larger and more expensive, but it has a better sound than the 3--but only where it really counts in your house.

We have been listening to a lot more music. If everyone is doing their own thing, I can program to listen to NPR radio in the kitchen while I cook dinner and put on different music in the kids rooms. I can control everything from my iPad or iPhone. When we are cleaning and want some up-beat music (highly recommend Amazon's disco playlist), I can play it throughout the whole house.

Again, the only tricky thing was moving my iTunes library from my PC over to the Apple Airport, but everything else has been wonderful. I highly recommend the Sonos players. If you're thinking about spending $500 on a speaker my guess is that my review is probably not the first you've read so I'll focus on what I learned after my purchase.

Yes, a single Play5 can fill a large room with spectacular sound. You don't need two speakers.
No, you can not stream sounds to the Play5 directly from your computer or TV. There is a line input, but that's just silly considering its a wireless speaker. You can play music that's on your computer.
Yes, the app is very easy to use and the speaker is easy to install. I think the entire process took me ~20 minutes.
Yes, standard wifi worked fine for me. I didn't need any additional hardware.

Love! This speaker packs a punch! Fills my home with great sound quality.

This is the first time I stepped away from the "traditional" speaker system. I recently moved and got rid of my giant speaker cabinets and other outdated sound components. I received the Sonos Play 5 in an amazing box; yes the packaging is impressive in itself. The speaker has some heft to it, feels well built, and looks good. Set up was simple, download the Sonos app and follow the directions, you must have WiFi because Sonos connects to your network. You tune the speaker by holding your phone in different areas of the room you will be in; the speaker is getting feedback and adjusting various outputs. Once set up you can pick from a multitude of streaming services to play, all of which are controlled by your phone. The sound is unbelievable! I have a very large living room with high ceilings and this speaker fills the room with rich, clear sound. The only downside, if it’s such a thing, I have to use an auxiliary audio line to play television sound through the speaker. You still use the app to control the television sound and you can’t use the television speakers simultaneously, as they are out of sync, think large stadium sound. I am completely sold on the Sonos system and will be purchasing additional speakers to place in other areas around my house. I have friends and family that use Bose and I would get this system over the Bose based on sound quality alone.

Very expensive... I thought this would be one of those buyers remorse purchases, but I have to say I'm loving this speaker! I'm not an audiophile so I can't personally comment on whether this is an eargasm inducing speaker or not. However, everyone who has come over and listened to it has commented how they can't believe that sound is coming out of only one speaker. While I'm not an audiophile, I am extremely techie. Sonos is the leader in the wireless, connected speaker market and it DEFINITELY shows when you look at the features:
- Windows, Android, and iOS apps all work flawlessly and instantly.
- I can connect to literally every music streaming service known to man.
- I can stream my music library off my home NAS or any other device on the network.

The only, and I mean ONLY complaint I have is the price. I'm definitely hooked on Sonos now, so I WILL be getting more speakers. Unfortunately, it looks like about 3k to get everything I want, so I guess I'll have to start selling drugs or robbing banks...

reviews.reviewTitle: Still trying to get sound from it....
reviews.reviewText:
Hour in to setup, not working yet. I'm very tech savvy... The instructions are silly. Plug it in, start the app, follow instructions. So since the app can't find the Sonos, fail. I was surprised there wasn't an obvious Google on this, most everything I found were people saying you should be using the "connect" for the "Sonos mesh network". I'm sure grandma looking for a bathroom speaker would be lost.

So the next step is to go to the basement to hardwire the thing and then try to connect that way. Then hope there are advanced settings to tell it about wifi, and then bring it back up here to see if it works. Time commitment is already boardering on something I could home rig.

Punchline... The aux in doesnt seem to work while it's in the unsetup state. So sad.

more: glutton for punishment I figure maybe it broadcasts a local net for me to connect for setup purposes. So I hit the button in the back and the pulsing green turned pulsing orange (no docs on colors or anything). I found a wifi called SONOS!!! But it couldn't find a Sonos on the Sonos network. :(. Experimentally I hit the button in the back and watched the network go away. So on it goes...oh I just hit the button again and pulsing orange turned blinked orange... Gotta go see if that's progress...

And finally... Click that "more option" and got instructions opposite from the quickstart. Attached for humor value. And now down to the basement...

reviews.reviewTitle: Sonos; has shortcomings but this speaker is the best yet
reviews.reviewText:
101216 Update: This issue will likely be solved with an update but since introducing the New model Play 5 into my existing Sonos system the music will automatically and randomly start playing on its own. It could also be an Android app issue as it only happens when I wake my S6 Edge to check calls/emails or (worst) when I am on a call..... that REALLY sucks to be on a professional call in your home office and music starts blaring! It will not stop either... every 10-15 seconds during the call it goes to play mode.

Back to review. New Play 5 review and Sonos summary. I'll keep the review short.... I did not want to spend $500 on yet another Sonos speaker but I have to admit the new model blows the old model away! The sound is crisp, deep bass and the highs blend perfectly... it is also louder than the older Play 5. If you're on the fence just buy it..... trust me folks, I know more than the generals do.

I have mixed reviews on the Sonos system in general, the platform is very buggy and clunky to operate. That said I am a believer in the philosophy of streaming music throughout the house without having to reconnect from BT speaker to BT speaker as you move about. The WiFi streaming is genius and does not seem to consume as much bandwidth as one may think. I have six Play 1's, a Play 3 and two Play 5 speakers (previous and current model). I was a little annoyed that the new Play 5 came out just a month or two after I purchased the previous model and I could not see dropping another $500 for the new model. As I am constantly trying to find the best location to place the speakers to get the desired sound I recently decided to add another Play 5. The setup now is Play 5 in the living room paired with two Play 1 (in-stereo) speakers, a Play 5 in the kitchen paired with one Play 1, a Play 3 in the bedroom paired with two Play 1 speakers and a Play 1 in my office. A Play 1 by itself does not do justice to the system but is a nice accessory to the Play 5 to fill out stereo surround.

i bought this and two play 1s to fill my house with music. setup was easy. the app just WORKS. i was concerned about running through a proprietary app, but Sonos has done it right. the app actually integrates all the music apps i use into one app, which is wonderful.

Sonos has re-invigorated my love of music.

I am very happy with this purchase. The sound from the PLAY5 really wowed me. I'm not exactly an audiophile but I can appreciate good sound and the PLAY5 provides it. What really impressed me was the power of this speaker when you crank the volume. The speaker is somewhat large but the when you turn the PLAY5 it really puts out immense sound with a nice bass. I also liked that the sound did not distort when turning it way up. In fact this speaker is somewhat too powerful for my living room home theater. When using it I primarily use it during the day or afternoon simply because it gets a bit too loud when the rest of the family is sleeping. This is not a bad thing!

The only criticism I have is I find myself having to pull the power cord out once in a while to reset the speaker when it looses network connectivity. I have my PLAY5 hard wired with cat5. I dont know why this happens but it doesnt happen that frequently. I also really enjoy the fact that the Sonos speakers integrate into my SmartThings smart home. Announcements are made through my Sonos speakers when a family member arrives home, and alarm is set off and many other events.

The price tag is a bit hefty for this but I guess you can say is warranted since the end result is you end up with a high quality product. This speaker sound quality definitely stands up well against my Definitive Technology speakers. I am very happy with this purchase.

Never before have I had a speaker output such pure high fidelity sound. This is sound that fills the room. The music penetrates you. The PLAY:5 makes listening to music a pure unadulterated joy. I was really on the fence about the $500 price tag but I am so happy to have purchased this system. I read a another review some where that said once you buy one of these your only regret will be not having more. After just one day of ownership I am already contemplating my next Sonos purchase. I don't usually use profanity but this is system that will make you swear at just how wonderful the music sounds. I am currently listening to music from back in the eighties all the way to present day. When listening to the PLAY:5 I hear things in songs I have never heard before. This is truly music the way it is suppose to be.

reviews.reviewTitle: If one Sonos is good, two is better...right?
reviews.reviewText: Well, I can't say that having a second one in my bedroom makes the sound experience TWICE as good as just having one, but let's just say I would not go back to just having one in the room. The sound is a little fuller, a little richer, and a little more spacious (as expected). The stereo separation is what I like most when listening to songs that pack a noticeable L/R channel dynamic. 5 Stars.

I love the Sonos system - it allows me to play anything on Pandora, Spotify, or any other internet service (including music in my personal library) over the speakers wirelessly. The cool thing is that it is not device-specific, so I can set it to play Pandora with my phone, and then change the station or volume with my iPad, without skipping a beat. These also have controls directly on the speaker that allow you to adjust volume and pause music without having to use your device. Sonos also has an automatic equalizer that uses your device's microphone to test how the speaker sounds in the room and make adjustments so it sounds its best no matter what room it is in. The Sonos 5 is the flagship of the individual speakers, and has excellent bass response and dynamic range for such a small speaker. I wish they made this in an outdoor version because they are every bit as good as the Bose outdoor speakers but without the hassle of speaker wiring..

reviews.reviewTitle: No audio from computer; much better in pairs
reviews.reviewText:
I basically happy with the Sonos, but it has some problems:

1. It won't stream audio from the computer. Why can't it play my audio from Youtube? Even a $30 bluetooth speaker can do that. Sonos is essentially a software company, so why don't they fix the problem. The Sonos would be far more useful if I could watch Youtube or a movie on my computer and get the audio on larger speakers.

2. The sound is ok but it won't compete with a real stereo. I would not want the Sonos as my only music system. It's convenient, but a good set of stereo speakers, amp, preamp, and DAC will stomp it. I you really like good sound, you'll want a better system. Sure, the Sonos has a "full and rich" Bose type of sound, but the serious detail and timbre are missing. It's pleasing for what it is, however. If you want to get a lot better sound quality for the price of a pair of Sonos 5's, check out the "Cheap and Cheerful" forum on AudioCircle.

3. It's about 10x better when you get a pair. I first just bought one Sonos 5 for various internet radio stations and casual Apple Music streaming (to check out new music). After adding a second Sonos 5, the difference is astounding. Sure, I knew I wasn't getting stereo before, but the difference is much much more significant than that. Even a mono news program like BBC World is significantly better with 2 Sonos speakers.

4. The "TruePlay" tuning feature is useless. It's obvious that it is not sophisticated. It only allows for subtle and meaningless adjustments and it sounds better turned off. I've tried it a few times, and it tends to muffle the high frequencies slightly. This might be an improvement to the measured sound, but turning on the digital filter that TruePlay uses muffles details across the spectrum which more than negates the tiny tiny adjustment of frequency response. Just turn off TruePlay and "Loudness" and you'll get the least adulterated sound.

Awesome performance. Pricy, but the ability to have a wireless music source with the ability to play from a mobile device makes up for the high price. Not having the traditional free standing wired speakers is a plus as far as i'm concerned. Also bought the Play one pair and love those as well.
You can never go wrong with Sonos. The sound quality is clear with deep bass. Very easy to setup.
Everything about this speaker is perfect from my experience. Bought one and within days, bought another. Easy install, continuous software upgrades, magical sound. I will buy more.
We tested the Play 1, 3 and 5. Only the Play 5 was good enough sound quality for our home. The set up was exceptionally simple and love that it connects over the wifi.
Only buy this speaker if you want to be disappointed by all other speakers.

The three buttons on top handle volume up, volume down, play/pause, next song, and previous song. The last two are accomplished by swiping your finger across all three buttons. Its even smart enough to know what orientation its in so that volume up is always the button thats on top, and volume down the button on the bottom. Its expensive, but I'm happy with my investment.

reviews.reviewText: Speaker failed after seven months. Called up Sonos, they determined that the wireless card had failed completely and speaker was non functional without an eathernet cable plugged in. Sonos claimed it was still under warranty and would send replacement. Have not received it.
great sound quality, it makes my parties better with whole house sound!

What is it?

Sonos is a wireless speaker system that streams music from your computer (downloaded, ripped from CD, iTunes etc) or internet streaming services such as Spotify, Tidal and streaming radio stations directly into your room. It's all controlled via an Android or iPhone/IPad app. There is also a PC/MAC program but it's easier to use the phone. There is no screen and very limited controls on the speaker itself.

With the app (or program) you can choose local or steaming music, create playlists, etc. Unlike a Bluetooth speaker, the app is just controlling what the speaker is playing. It's not the source of the music. The speaker is connected to you router via Wi-Fi (Or wired) so it get the music it's playing directly over the network.

The idea of Sonos is you have a speaker in every room. But you just need one to start. Eventually you can have many speakers and they can be playing different music or all linked together playing the same thing.

Why I bought it

I had a CD changer, surround sound receiver and some speakers which worked for many years. I found I wanted to modernize to something easier after my friend let me try his Sonos system.

Once I saw what this could do, I knew I could:

- Listen to my almost 350 CD collection
- Be able to create playlists from my existing collection
- Access my purchased music collection (Amazon music and some iTunes tracks) (Was hoping this was possible)
- Stream radio and use services like Spotify/Pandora
- Start playing and change music easily

My CD collection

One thing Sonos does not tell you how to do is get your CD collection into the Sonos system. You can rip your CDs using some program and store them on you computer. But if you have a laptop like me sometimes it's not always available. I ended up using a microJukebox which ripped the CDs automatically. It acts as a computer server and allows me to play my music at any time. I also was able to load my existing tracks from iTunes and Amazon on it. Sonos has a nice interface like iTunes but again if your laptop is not powered on, it won't work. Now all my CDs and music are in stored on the microJukebox.

How does it sound?

I was going to purchase the old version of the PLAY:5 but waited after I read that the new version was almost out. I'm glad I waited. The sound is pretty amazing. My original system has good size speakers and a small sub woofer; and the PLAY:5 fills the room with rich sound just as well is not better then the larger system.

Audio quality

I have been doing some listening tests between my ripped CDs and the same tracks on Spotify. The tracks ripped from CD are defiantly much better, but Spotify has a lot more music available.

The only thing I had to compare before was playing my Android phone through a blue-tooth speaker and playing CDs on my CD player was good. Now the PLAY:5 sounds even better than my CD player did with the same tracks (ripped from my CDs).

I heard that Tidal streams most of their content in CD quality. I may get a trial account and try that out with this system.

What's next?

I need to start learning the advanced functionality that Sonos has to offer. I also want to start exploring some of the other free streaming services. I was very surprised at how many stream services are included.

I may purchase another smaller Sonos unit for the bedroom. I see you can set alarms and it would be cool to wake up to music. I'm very happy so far!

Conclusion

The PLAY:5 is a great system.

- Easy to use
- Great app
- Supports lots of different streaming services
- Access to local music
- Sounds amazing
- Solidly built

Exceeded my expectations. Returned play 3, since that speaker was not powerful enough. One play 5 speaker has enough power and clarity to fill my entire living area now (1100 sq. ft.) with music. Really good bass. Mind you, i use it only for streaming music, not for TV or home theater.

My wife and I like to pick 1 item every year that we think was our favorite item we owned in that year. We bought the first generation of a Sonos 5 back when it first came out, it won that year. We bought this one this year for another room, I think it is in the lead to win again in 2016. Much better sound quality than their first generation speaker. Install the Sonos app on your smart phone, plug the speaker into an outlet, and less than two minutes later, it's ready to go. We have never had any connectivity or sound problems out of any Sonos product ever. I like the soft touch fast forward, rewind, pause/play, and volume controls on the top. The little audible sound for the buttons is nice also. This is a lot of money to pay for a one piece sound system, but because of the ease of the Sonos app, access to streaming apps, and volume and quality of sound, it's worth it.

I'm so happy I didn't buy the MUCH larger and expensive B & O A6 or A9. I highly recommend Sonos both for a quality powered speaker and a lightning fast and trouble-free music streaming system.

reviews.reviewTitle: The Sonos you've been waiting for
reviews.reviewText:
Plunk.

The Play:5 box arrives at your door. You slide the two plastic latches on the side to open the box. Premium, thoughtful, apple-esque packaging. But then again, would you expect anything less from the newest flagship speaker from Sonos?

Setup is simple. Plug in the power cable. Click add a new device on the mobile app. Press a button on the back of the Play:5. Chose a Music Source and boom. Music is filling your home.

Looks+Feel: Understated and Stunning. I got the White with the grey screen. Heavier than I expected. New form factor is more in line with their recent design language. Also notable is the font grill which shows a serious attention to detail. The Capacitive touch panel at the top works great for volume control and track navigation. (Though most users will be controlling the Play:5 from their mobile app, nice touch none the less.)

Trueplay Tuning: The Play5 has a neat little trick. It can use your mobile device as a way to automatically "tune" itself for the room. You enable the Trueplay setup procedure on your mobile application. The Play:5 will then begin playing a series of sounds. Follow the instructions from the mobile application and walk around the room slowly waving your mobile device. The app will tell you when it is finished and the automatic "tuning" will happen. Your mileage may vary here depending on the shape/size of your room and where you've placed the Play:5.

Sound: As one of the pioneers for streaming music, Sonos has often been (somewhat unfairly) viewed as a tech upstart. Emphasizing wireless multi-room integration/clean user experience/streaming capability over Sound quality and frequency range. And while sound quality is highly subjective, I think you'll be hard pressed to find someone not impressed with the quality from this new speaker.

The new speaker has 3 tweeters and 3 mid-woofers with a tuned class-D amplifier for each. In english, this basically means more awesome. The Play:5 has a noticeably larger and more articulate soundstage. Bass definitely improved. Sonos got rid of the Bass Port from the last generation for a fully enclosed architecture. This allowed them to get deeper and richer bass. Mids and Highs also improved and have better clarity. And don't worry...the Play:5 can get plenty loud without any distortion. You won't have any problems filling large spaces with sweet sweet music. Overall, extremely impressed.

Just get the Play:5 already. Your ears will thank you. Your neighbors may not :)

reviews.reviewText: works very well and easy to use. set up, performed by a son, seemed easy also. This was an additional speaker to the system I have and use every day.

Rarely if ever do i write reviews on things i buy but i felt compelled to write one about this speaker as i know alot of people might be skeptical about the price. I had researched this speaker a few weeks before it was due to hit the shelves and initial testers gave rave reviews. So i couldnt wait till it came out on the 20th!
So the 20th comes around and i head to Best Buy to demo the speaker. I press the play button, turn the volume up and am blown away bby the sound quality, clarity and bass! I listen to it for a few minutes on their demo song and then my decision i made. So i ask to buy and the sales rep says there is only one left! So i hurridaly tell him ill take it and i rush home elated with my purchase and eager to test it out it in te comfort of my own home!
1. Unboxing is farily easy and upon seeing the speaker i am pleased by the aesthitics of it. Simple but beautiful. BTW, this this is heavy! Solid and well built! It comes with the power cable and an ethernet cable in case your wifi is not stable.
2. Connecting to my wifi was a breeze! I downloaded the SONOS app on both my ipad and andriod phones. It found my wifi, i enter the password, it connects, downloads and update then i am off and running. Setup could not be easier! And for testing purposes i had this set up on my kitchen island. The SONOS app has many different music services you can connect to it which is awesome in itself.
3. The true test. I connect my Pandora account and selected a Smooth Jazz Christmas channel and hit Play Now. What followed next made my ears melt. The easy lows, the crisp highs! Hearing every single instrument in the ensemble! My ears rejoice and i instantly feel more holiday spirit! For the size of this speaker the sound it puts out is absolutely amazing even at high levels. I turned the volume all the way up and everything was still crisp and precise. I switched to instrumental hip hop. Once again my jaw drops. Now dont except this thing to give you the bass response of a 12in subwoofer connected to an amp, but the low bass it puts out is stunning. This was proved once again when i played some dubstep on it. The bass punched my stomach and snares made my eyes tear up. Nex up, some Al Green. It felt like the man was singing right there in the room with me. Once again, i feel every note, every tone. From pianos, to sax, to bass, to vocals, highs lows and all in between, this beauty shines!
So just to be sure i wasnt going crazy, i invited a friend over to get his opinion on it. He put on some Michael Jackson, a song from his last album. He used the Line in to connect to his phone. The look on his face when the sound came out was priceless. As was mine. As complex as MJ's songs could be you heard everything! He listened to it for about an hour and is now going to buy two to put in stereo mode lol. He would have gone to Best Buy that night but all Best Buy's were sold out!
So in my conclusion, if you are on the fence about this speaker because of the price i do understand. But believe me, after bringing it home and giving it a test run i can say this is not going back. Purchase it and give it a try. I can guarantee you will not be disappointed! Across every realm of music i tried i had nothing but a smile on my face. Oh! We even tried a movie on it as well played through my Plex app connected to Line in and the clarity was also amazing!
Amazing sound. Love the wireless setup over bluetooth. If you can afford it go buy one.

reviews.reviewTitle: Expected more out of the Play 5
reviews.reviewText: We have invested heavy in Sonos in our new home. We have the Play Bar, with Sub, 6 Play 1's and 2 Play 2's and I really wanted this Play 5 to blow me away and it didn't. I would rather have Play 3's. IMHO, I Play 5 should have a optic input, would give 5 starts if it did. I will find a place for this Play 5 but it will be the one and only one I get. The Play 3's are plenty good and the Play 1's are great to have, never have enough of them if you ask me.

I wanted to like them, having read so many glowing recommendations. However, the sound is just off. It's severely lacking in the mid-range and this is making music sound tinny, especially singing (yes, we tuned everything and also tried various positions around the room.)

Mind you, these sound way better than cheap phone speakers but the music just feels flat and is not alive. We've directly compared them to Bose Soundlink and to a Bowers and Wilkins Zeppelin and those both just sound way better.

We're returning it and probably will try a Sonos AMP with freestanding speakers as we really like the setup experience and the Sonos app.

reviews.reviewTitle: DO NOT PURCHASE - YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED
reviews.reviewText: DO NOT PURCHASE. I have a play 5 that all of a sudden stopped working a little over 2 years of owning it. Lightly used the speaker never blasted it or moved it too much and listened to music a few times a week. Went through all the troubleshooting with the support team and they could not solve my issue. Their only solution after that was to tell me to spend another $350 to buy a new speaker. After already dishing out $550 for a "premium speaker." What guarantee would I have that this new speaker wouldn't stop working after 2 years. Clearly the life expectancy of this speaker is 2 years. Pretty poor customer service to essentially just tell you tough luck purchase a new one. The kicker is that they mentioned that if i had consistent issues with the speaker then they would be able to do something for me. Really? If I had consistent issues with your product? Is that normal to have consistent issues with your product? I'm sure I would have been better off purchasing a cheaper speaker that would last longer. Never would give this company any more business and rather go with a more reliable brand like Bose. Just want everyone to be fairly warned of this product and company.

reviews.reviewTitle: Awful sound and nonexistent customer support
reviews.reviewText:
The worst thjng about this is the flat and hollow sound
The next worst thing is the user interface that is not intuitive and cannot be easily programmed
Then...when i tried desperately to get it to work or understand there was jo customer support
Rather than continue the hassle i just returned it
Big disappointment

reviews.reviewTitle: Lack of 5GHz support is a showstopper... literally.
reviews.reviewText: Sounds great but totally useless in an apartment complex with tons of 2.4GHz signals around. Constantly skips tracks/podcasts, or stops playing altogether due to interference. Have tried countless solutions with Sonos support including changing wireless channels and using Boost mode. Never going to work on 2.4GHz. Get it together and support 5GHz Sonos.
Great sound
Ready to buy another one!
Amazing sound quality... but chalanges regarding setting up

reviews.reviewTitle: Sound quality is good, u wont expect a small speaker with a ...
reviews.reviewText: Sound quality is good, u wont expect a small speaker with a deep low bass, it produces clean sound, u dont need extra sub woofer for it
Great sound from this unit.
INCREDIBLE SOUND!!!...I LOVE IT!

For lack of a better phrase, I have been a skeptic about Sonos for a long time. "What's the difference between using a Sonos and using a bluetooth-connected speaker instead? Why would I pay so much money for speakers? Is the sound REALLY as good as everyone says?"

I decided to take the plunge recently because I was remodeling the house and my old speakers were...destroyed. I had also been eyeing a Sonos for a while, so it just made sense to me to finally get one.

When I opened the box I was in for a surprise. I did not expect it to be so large—it absolutely looks a lot smaller in photos. I was taken back by it at first, but I'm warming up to its size because it just feels so solid and premium, and so I expected the sound to come out of it to be nothing less than amazing. Setup was a breeze. Probably took all of two minutes for the app to detect my wifi and automatically attach itself to it. Then I had to set up Trueplay, which took another minute. From there, I set up my music service, Apple Music, and began playing "Gravity" by Parker & Hanson. My jaw dropped after about ten seconds because the sound that came out of it is so rich, so pure, so true—I had never heard my music in such a way before. The sound, again for lack of a better word, felt "real" and I can felt the music vibrate in my body, which was unusual. It was a whole new experience of listening to music for me and I can't wait for the many, many years to come using this beautiful speaker.

reviews.reviewTitle: Important! Do not buy these speakers, I will tell you why.
reviews.reviewText: For several years I have been one of Sono's biggest supporters. I have bought over 40 speakers for all of my houses and businesses. It has always been a little risky since you can only use these speakers with their software. For some unknown reason, they changed their entire format. The new software does not allow you to add new speakers, listen to your own music, or add new music services, or just about anything. They must have had a change in management, but they ruined a perfectly good business model. The software is riddled with bugs. and comes in and out. I can tell you this with confidence since I have 10 different system setups, and literally none of them are working anymore. I am stuck with $20,000 worth of speakers that do not work anymore. On top of that I have 4 houses and 6 businesses that I will have to buy all new systems for. They used to have stellar customer service. They would answer tech support immediately. Now when I call, they tell me that the wait time is 3 hours. This should be everyone's first clue.

reviews.reviewTitle: I like these speakers but wonder how much of my data ...
reviews.reviewText: I like these speakers but wonder how much of my data plan they use. We regularly run out of data before the end of the month. The other thing I noticed is that sometimes I cannot play the radio station I want. Possibly that's the fault of my satellite internet signal.

reviews.reviewTitle: Rock solid wireless performance? After 8+ years, I really have to disagree.
reviews.reviewText: I just watched their marketing video, “Rock solid wireless performance”. OMG! I have a Sonos Connect, Sonos Bridge, Sonos Connect: Amp, Sonos Sub, and two Sonos Play 5s. I am putting them all on Craigslist and *hoping* to get maybe 10% of what I paid for them. Because the wireless is anything but “Rock solid”. I bought so much of their expensive stuff (about $2,500) because it is excellent sound and amazing convenience, when it works. And it does work, MOST of the time. And then it stops working for no obvious reason. And then you spend hours and hours and hours, trying to figure out how to get it working again. And you do, until the next time the system mysteriously stops working again. And it always seems to stop working just hours before you have a party, with lots of friends over and no ability to use your expensive wireless speakers that sound so great, well, if they were working right now... Since they are a very proprietary system, you are totally at the mercy of Sonos. If they don’t support them, you have $2,500 of useless plastic and electronic boards that do absolutely nothing. Excellent sounding speakers that don’t make any sound at all. And why did it stop working? Because you got a defective item? No. Just... because. Because it is a complex system and sometimes things get “out of adjustment”. And then it’s up to you to spend hours and hours to get it working again. And again. And again. And again. And again...
Great product
Great speaker
Great sound and convenience of set up.

reviews.reviewTitle: I really like sonos and the new play 5 speaker but I ...
reviews.reviewText: I really like sonos and the new play 5 speaker but I feel it cost too much.
nice system, but this one is too expensive
good

I’ve had one of these for 5-6 years. The sound is great, but from time to time it “crashes”. By that I mean it stops working and you have to call the company to guide you through getting it working again.
But now, after all these years, they want me to set up an account or my Sonos will no longer work. I’ve got enough accounts already. Don’t need any more passwords. Now it’s just a black box sitting on a table because it won’t do a thing.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very expensive system with limited support (1 year warranty)
reviews.reviewText:
While the Sonos system is fine when it works when it fails after the 1 year warranty it is no longer serviceable.

I was received my first Sonos 5 in December 2013. Setting it up was a little challenging although reasonable. Adding/activating sources/services was fairly easy as well. I have added units after the Sonos 5 and that was fairly easy as well. The sound is really good. Much better than most Bluetooth units.

My issue comes when the units or Controller software need to be updated. You cannot use the system (any of the units) until they are all and the controller application are updated. After some controller updates the system needs to be reconfigured. There is no opting out of updates.
Romantic time? Guests came over and want set background music? Kid wants to show you a dance they came up with in their room? Need to wait (and babysit) up to 10 minutes for each each unit to update if it is successful as well as the controller application. One fails as they often do, repeat.

Which brings me to my negative review. It was during one of these updates this three months ago that my units continuously failed to update and were unusable. Each time it failed, I would send a Diagnostic as requested in the failed updated. Never heard a response. Looked up the error code as instructed - does not exist

I opened a ticket and found out that my unit has a defect (most like occurred during the update as it worked up until I had to update the units) is no longer supported (1 year warranty). Even out of warranty support in unavailable because I don't know which of my email accounts I used to originally register the initial device.

I will use Amazon Echo's going forward. Although you cannot connect multiple Alexa devices to each other and play the same requested audio at the same time, we rarely had that need.
Phenomenal speaker; however over priced!

reviews.reviewTitle: Sloppy design for an expensive speaker.
reviews.reviewText: The sound is good. The construction has decline for a $500 speaker. For example, it does not have a good grip make sure the are place in a non slippery area because the vibration can make it slip. The old play 5 had a great runber grip that you had to lift it to move it. This one easily slides and is heavier than the older version.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great sound. Watch out if you use a DNS service
reviews.reviewText:
Easy to install. Great sound!
I live outside the US, so I watch Netflix on a Roku 3 and use Unblock-Us to watch the US catalogue. When trying to connect to the same router the Sonos Play 5 to listen to Spotify it has been impossible, because they don't support Sonos. Be aware it this if you have the same configuration. Asked the same question to the people of Unlocator (another DNS provider) and they replied that they don't support Sonos either

reviews.reviewTitle: Will NOT play all the music you own
reviews.reviewText: The sound is okay. For as large as it is, it still doesn't fill up my 1000 sq ft house as well as my old Bose wired bookshelf speakers once did, which is Very disappointing. It has a HUGE problem, tho, in that it does not play my entire music library. Apparently, all amazon speaker products will only play non-DRM music tracks, which is to say that I have to go back and delete and reload TEN+ years of Apple iTunes music purchases! WHEN THE BLOODY HELL DO I HAVE TIME TO DO THAT???? It's a damned useless rock until them. $500 plus tax of nothing. DON'T BUY THIS. (And, no, I do NOT want to have to play off some else's server ("the cloud") to enjoy my own music!!!!)

Powerful. Good sub for the size. Very clear sound. However it does not create stereo pair with a play:3 (understandably so but would be great to have).
Although the sound is noticeably better than play 3, it's not that significant in my opinion.
Better to have two play:3 paired than one play:5.

reviews.reviewTitle: Sonos is not what you think, do your research!!
reviews.reviewText: Sound quality is pretty good when you compare it to Alexia. Doesnt really compete with home stereo speakers. You cannot play movies, Youtube, Audible, TV on your PC or any other non sanctioned sources without using the Line in which sux. Overall pretty disappointing and will return it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Plugging in record player does not work
reviews.reviewText: These sound excellent! Very full rich sound. Great bass. But does not work well with an audio technical turntable I bought. When I plug in the Aux, it plays for about 10 minutes and then stops working. It then erases my settings and I have to re setup my system, including the annoying tuning.

reviews.reviewTitle: Can’t Beat a Traditional System, But it’s Close (-ish)
reviews.reviewText:
OVERVIEW:
This review is more specifically geared toward SOUND QUALITY for potential buyers who are curious to learn how the Sonos Play 5 stacks up against a more traditional home stereo system of comparable cost. While I’ve owned a few other Sonos products (Play 1 and 3)—having found the simplicity and reliability of connectivity to be stellar and integration with iPhones/iPads as seamless as if it were an Apple product itself—I’ll leave these areas to other reviewers, though I imagine the Play 5 will perform as well as the rest of the stellar product line.

There are a few videos available that compare the Sonos Play 5 speakers to more traditional speakers for those who prefer their own ears to the subjective opinion of this reviewer (those serious about evaluating the tonal difference should at least use a decent pair of headphones or speakers). However, I do try to remain as unbiased and open-minded when writing these types of reviews.

BACKGROUND:
For reference: in terms of both equipment owned and discernment of quality audio, I’m fairly close to being an audiophile. At the same time, audiophiles and their tendency to focus on how music SOUNDS vs how it makes you FEEL is a philosophy (or tendency) I don’t align with. So, if you appreciate the audio quality of a CD, but can healthily accept that a quality MP3 (320kbps) can approximate 95% of the tonal quality and nuances in 99% of listening situations, this is the review for you.

AUDIO QUALITY:
For 96% of listeners — those who aren’t concerned with (at least) adjusting their streaming quality to 320kbps and those seeking convenience, volume, and decent bass —the Sonos are going to sound fantastic! And considering the relatively affordable price tag and zero hassle with wires and ‘ugly’ black receivers, it’s hard to beat their simplicity and quality... especially since the Sonos 5 is likely to sound better than whatever audio equipment the majority of households are currently using (particularly if that consists of a portable Bluetooth speaker or those little “B” brand cubes).

I’d confidently recommend the Sonos 5 for those seeking a “big” sound, and for those who aren’t needlessly obsessed with things like frequency response, sensitivity ratings, or DAC’s.

If it wasn’t for a side-by-side comparison against both a cost-comparable traditional stereo system (and an “audiophile”-ish one), at least half of the remaining 4% would give the Sonos 5 top marks.

BUT, for more discerning listeners, a pair of Sonos 5 don’t (and cannot) compete with a dedicated receiver and bookshelf speakers of relatively equal cost. You’re always gonna lose sound quality when trying to stuff an amplifier, power supply, and additional electronics into the same box that’s meant to project sound.

After purchasing a pair of Sonos 5, I did my own home comparison against B&W 685’s (S1) and an entry-level Marantz 7.1 channel received — combined, these retail for roughly the same cost AND come with Apple Airplay built into the receiver... so same streaming functionality. I also compared these against B&W CM6 (S2’s) with an Anthem MRX 720 — which, combined, retails at roughly 4x the cost of a pair of Play 5’s. To be frank, while the Sonos DID sound absolutely rich and satisfying, capable of filling my entire 18x23’ family room with full, bass-heavy audio (capable of dance-party-level decibels), BOTH wired systems were on a whole other level. In fact, the difference between the $1K system and $4K wired systems was much smaller than the difference between the $1K system and the Sonos.

Even the cost-comparable system offered far clearer separation of instruments and vocals — especially in the midrange. The midrange on the Sonos sounded a bit flat and compressed while the treble felt slightly muted at the highest of frequencies (8-12kHz). The soundstages were also significantly more expansive. The Sonos sounded like a speaker playing the music while the B&W speakers sounded like the music recording, if that makes sense. Close your eyes sitting dead center on any well-balanced system (correct height, distance, etc) and you can’t place the speakers... you CAN place the instruments in the three dimensional soundstage quality speakers give you. The higher quality the speakers, receiver, recording format, and DAC (digital-analogue converter—a $3-15 part integrated into everything that plays digital music), the more Detailed and refined the soundstage.

The Play 5’s sounded good, great even. They did not sound accurate, detailed, or anywhere near as refined as a dedicated set of bookshelf speakers and integrated amp (or HT receiver). The Sonos did offer more noticeable mid to upper bass (particularly in the 80-100hz range), though it seemed to be the result of tweaking the internal crossovers around 90hz to give the impression of “fuller” bass; not bad, just not accurate reproduction and touch too boomy for my taste. I prefer a slightly pronounced low end, but in the 40-60Hz range, the deeper, punchier bass you feel, not hear. Both wired systems had more noticeable lower-end bass reproduction, particularly at higher volumes.

So for the remaining 2%, those interested in not only hearing and feeling the music but ‘listening’ to it — the actual recording, the placement of instruments, etc — it’s pretty clear what that extra equipment, wires, and extra $$ is getting you...

FEATURES:
Trouble is, there’s no fine-tuning any audio parameters with the Play 5’s except thru your phone’s crummy EQ (or worse, your streaming player’s lame 5-band equalizer). This is partly where having a dedicated receiver really shines. While it does cost you some space and possibly some aesthetics (wires, etc), you have a wealth of functionality and customization options, particularly if you want to incorporate TV or Film.
And if/when the tech changes, you’re out the entire system whereas dedicated speakers can last for a solid 15+ years. My Sonos Play 1 is already dated as it doesn’t have Airplay and can’t play music stored in my phone :/

RECOMMENDATIONS:
If convenience and simplicity are your thing, Sonos 5 won’t disappoint. They’re clean, they’re cool, they’re fairly attractive (though I prefer grill-free speakers), they sound great, get loud, and best of all... there’s ONE plug. Easy.

If you’re someone who nitpicks over sound quality or someone looking for a longer term solution (as well as a MUCH greater resell value), spend roughly the same $ on a solid bookshelf speakers (Klipsch, B&W, KEF, Monitor Audio, etc) and an integrated amplifier (NAD, Marantz, Peachtree, Rotel) with AirPlay or Play-Fi. And if you’re on a budget but ALSO want small and convenient, try something like a used NAD D3020 amp (the size of a modem), compact bookshelf speakers that put out bigger bass (klipsch/BW), and a used Apple Airport Express (if you want to utilize AirPlay with any non-connected amp). All in... $700 (used) and you’ve got a higher quality sound system that uses no additional space, provides slightly more functionality, and yields noticeable higher audio quality— for those who even notice this stuff—all for less than a pair of Sonos 5’s.

If I could do it all over again, I’d still invest in separates. If I could do it all over again and I DIDN’T also watch a lot of movies and DIDN’T already hear the higher-end system, I’d get the wire/connection-free PLAY 5’a!

Hope this helps!
You'll have to get another job at McDonald's to pay for it. It's awesome though.

Playbar
Sub
2 x Play 5s
2 x Play 3s
3x Play 1s
And Bridge.

I just finished reading the 1 star reviews for this speaker and was inspired to write this one... Look... This system depends on a strong WiFi signal to work properly. If you are stealing your neighbor's signal or don't have the patience to ensure that the system is set to a separate channel to prevent interference this just isn't the right speaker or system for you. Also, this is not a Bluetooth speaker. While Sonos has recently added the option to play music straight from the Spotify app on your phone or tablet this does not happen via Bluetooth and any other content you play on this speaker that is not a line in source will have to be played through the Sonos controller app (yes, this includes you iTunes fans.) The app is admittedly not the most attractive piece of software but is under constant development. Again, if you don't have the patience to learn how to reboot the system to refresh things now and then after an app update, this is not the right speaker for you. I have had my system for about 2 years and the only issues that I have had to troubleshoot were accounted for with corresponding wifi or router issues that were not any fault of the sonos system. The sound quality is amazing, and customizable. The system makes it very easy to add new components at any time ensuring that this system will grow and expand as needed with little effort.
