I don't regret a single penny that I've spent on this system and when the room I'm working on is finished I will happily be adding to it. The bottom line, this system best serves the tech enthusiast and if you have the patience care for it, it will be a stellar addition to your home.

reviews.reviewDate: The manufacturer commented on the review below
reviews.reviewText: phone support hours don't favor west coast people. Couldn't setup device on Ipad, had to use computer. very frustrating running around in circles using the Sonos iOS App to setup the system.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great sound but that is it.
reviews.reviewText:
The sound is very good, but due to Sonos' restrictive, clunky interface and audio drops I returned this product. Using Spotify you have to use the Sonos' version within the Sonos app which translates into frustration when selecting music. The audio drops occurred at random using my Apple router (AirPort Extreme current gen). I either had to spend more $ to get a wifi bridge or hardwire a speaker to the router. My location was not convenient to run an ethernet cable and I wasn't going to spend more $ for a system that should work over my wifi network as advertised. I also didn't like that there was a delay to the audio when using the aux input. Sonos should provide a software switch on how to use the aux input to eliminate the delay when you are not going to broadcast the aux input to other speakers.

Overall I found the product to not function as advertised due to audio drops where my $35 alternative works flawlessly... even in multiroom environments. For much less $ my alternative has better sound, more convenience as I can use the actual streaming apps, no signal delays from my TV audio, and most important no audio drops!

reviews.reviewTitle: Sounds good but needs more base
reviews.reviewText: Sounds good but needs more base, needs a 8" sub built into it. The 3.5mm plug did not work on my speaker. I call Sonos 5 times and waited 30 minutes to 1hour each time but never got a chance to talk to someone, go tired of waiting. Sent it back.

There once was a time when you could invest in high-quality audio equipment and be assured of reliable performance for years, if not decades. Sonos does not follow that model. If you own Sonos equipment, you have to worry not only about the performance of the equipment -- which is unpredictable -- but you must also take into account that the people at Sonos might change their mind about how they prefer their equipment to work.

I have spent thousands of dollars on my Sonos system, and many more thousands on a music library that I own. However, Sonos notified me that with the next update these two investments of mine will no longer be compatible. In other words, I will not be able to play back any music stored locally on my devices.

Of course, I will be able to play my own music if I spend more money on additional Sonos products (a lot more) or start paying for a premium streaming service every month and download my entire library to it. But to be forced into this decision based on the whims of the people at Sonos does not make for satisfied customers when they have already spent as much money as I have.

It took nearly two years of dealing with technical issues getting all of my Sonos speakers to consistently cooperate. I have finally been able to enjoy my own music library hassle-free for the last several months. Looks like that will be all I get to enjoy.

I have nothing but regret for buying these speakers. My experience with Sonos has been only repeated disappointment.

Had it for a week, Sounds great, but it the app stops recognizing the path to my music library on a very frequent basis. Some times in mid song and at other times when I start a new session. When this happens the music stops! Re-initializing seems to be a temporary solution (At 5 minutes a pop), but then it stops playing at any given time.
Too bad, it sounds great when it is playing.

reviews.reviewTitle: So angry and dissappointed - I was your #1 Fan
reviews.reviewText:
Check out other reviews. Running one or two speakers seems to work fine. Adding multi room sound is another thing altogether and, sadly, Sonos comes up very short in that department.

I invested thousands of dollars in sonos products - I have 16 pieces in a house I literally designed with sonos product placement in mind. This is because at the time the Sonos software worked well with the hardware. So very frustrated as I now have a system that may or may not work on a given day. It's related to the software designed to manage the system. I've tried Sonos support many times, upgraded my router, added a dedicated Sonos Boost device and paid for more bandwidth from my ISP. Yet the system gets worse with every software update from Sonos. If I could elimate the sonos app/interface I would in a heartbeat but you cannot 100% divorce the system from the app/controller.

I have roughly $5000 invested in a system that has not worked properly for almost a year. I'm not doing anything crazy like playing different music on 16 different devices. I am simply trying to run the same music throughout my 2500 sq foot home with gig speed internet. Heck I'd take the same music on 8 sonos devices in my home but even that is a iffy proposition.

Sonos has worked with me to troubleshoot and tweak the system but it never resolves. They cannot solve the problem nor will they offer me a refund for the large amount of money invested into a multi room system that does not function. VERY FRUSTRATED AND I AM NOW SONOS #1 CRITIC

The sound is great and the system worked fine for a year and then it was constant trouble. Now the $500 Play 5 is dead and Sonos is happy to "exchange" it for an additional $150 which comes with a banging 90 day warranty. Let me ask you, when was the last time you spent $500 on a sound system and it died after 2 years? Total rip off, these speakers sound great but do NOT last. And I happy to sell you mine for a deep discount and you can repair and use.

I invested in this because of the reviews of this product. It sounded perfect for me and my family. I was so wrong!
Every time it is unplugged it is very difficult to reconnect to the app. After finally getting it connected, now it intermittently goes in and out. If you enjoy dealing with their customer service every time you want to use the device...by all means, buy this expensive paperweight. My advice, save your time and money and choose another product!

OK,

Sound wise $500 spent anywhere else won't approach the sound quality of these. Blows away Bose in side by side. Wifi mo' betta than bluetooth. App works great and incredibly easy to plug and play via computer or iphone! Investigating other options you pay over $1300 for a integrated amp that does the same and is NOT as simple!

I had some issues getting this speaker up and running and gave it only 3 stars as a results. I followed up by griping on the Sonos web site.

Well it ends up the issue is with my wifi which is not surprising having cox as my ISP (avoid cox if at all possible!).

Sonos caught wind of my complaints and called me and spent over an hour trouble shooting and optimizing my wifi remotely! Super intelligent and patient with my bad attitude!

I have NEVER had customer service even close to the level of professionalism and thoroughness and belief in their product! Above and beyond what could be expected on any level! Seriously 2 one hour phone calls to troubleshoot and most of it they could do without me and I kept working as they tweaked and optimized and analyzed! Again ANY issues are a result of my wifi network and once plugged into modem via ethernet cable has been rock solid!

Get this is you have wifi and want a way to wirelessly stream music with great sound at a super bargain price when all is considered!

reviews.reviewTitle: Everything worked fine and the connection is convenient and easy to use
reviews.reviewText: I have a Sonos Play 5 (Gen 1). Everything worked fine and the connection is convenient and easy to use. However, my speaker began to have clicking sounds out of blue. It is under 4 years old and I would say in very good condition (I use it as my computer speaker and don't move it much). The clicking sound begins a while after power is connected and its frequency speeds up over time; the volume of the clicking sound is not affected by the volume control (ie I put the whole thing on mute and the clicking sound continues). Really frustrating... called customer support and they offered to give me a new Gen 2 Play 5 for $250. Is it a great deal? I don't know.. this speaker was $450 to begin with and its shelf life certainly came in below my expectation. I searched around online and apparently this clicking sound problem is not isolated.

reviews.reviewTitle: All 3 of my Play 5s Gen 2 Died
reviews.reviewText: These are awesome speakers when they work. I bought my speakers in 2017. In Oct 2018 one lost WiFi, outside of the 12 month warranty, Sonos replaced it for free. In January 2019, another of the original 3 (wifi) crapped out. After calling tech support it was also replaced. At the time I asked to send in my 3d original and was denied. Now - March 2019 comes along and the 3rd POS Play 5 dies, probable power supply this time. Sonos wants me to spend $350 for a refurb! Why would I pay $350 for an expensive speaker that won't last 3 years. When you have 3 out of 3 die - the odds are stacked against you. Great Speaker if you only need then for two years :)

I really like the speaker, it has been working well for about a year since I ordered it directly from Sonos (Sales Tax was lower ordering it through their website for some reason).

However, I give it three stars because the company on the whole seems very set on conducting its business in a way that is not customer-focused. The Sonos App is pretty lousy. It seems like it is always either crashing, not installing a music service correctly (I've never been able to add Soundcloud), or in some way just being very hard to organize my music. You cannot access Spotify playlists belonging to Spotify users, for instance.

In addition, Sonos very intentionally does not allow you to make ANY changes to the speaker without Wifi, and the wifi set up process is often painful. If you want to set the Sonos to line-in, you need to do so on Wifi - otherwise the app will not even OPEN.

Overall, pretty nice speaker, but terrible company. Maybe its just my overreaction but it feels like a company that is truly greedy, and is not ashamed in not hiding it. Sonos wants to provide a good speaker, but they also want to significantly constrain the user experience in ways that benefit themselves.

reviews.reviewTitle: New Flagship for the Sonos Family and a Huge Sonic Improvement
reviews.reviewText:
I have a number of the first generation Play 5 and Play 1 speakers at my house. Until today, I thought the Play 1 was the most musical of the Sonos speakers---it has a nice flat response to a streaming music file, and it doesn't color the mid-range with a somewhat dark or muddied sound as the gen 1 PLay 5 speaker seems to do for my ears. However, I heard a demo of the new generation Play 5 this past week at a local audio shop, and I immediately heard a much more transparent sound image for the music that was being demo'd (re-mastered Beatle tracks, Dave Brubeck jazz quartet, Adele 25 tracks). I went ahead and upgraded my living room today, replacing a pair of gen 1 Play 5's with a pair of gen 2 PLay 5's. I am VERY HAPPY with the improved sound transparency, much improved sound stage imaging, and the sonic range of the new, paired speakers. IMO, this speaker is a big improvement over the previous Play 5. I suspect that I will be able to continue to tweak the exact placement of my new Play 5's in my living room to further refine the sound stage imaging.

An added bonus: Sonos speakers tend to hold their value quite well on the used market, if you take good care of the speaker. I was able to sell my four year old Play 5's at a good price (about 25% less than I paid for them), so it was not that hard to justify the upgrade costs for the new PLay 5 speakers.

I have been listening to music on a Beats pill for several years, and was given this as a gift. I hadn't realized that I had become used to not hearing most of the subtleties of the music. I listen to everything from rap to rock to classical. This speaker accommodates them all. There were notes and details on songs that I had been listening to for years that I had entirely missed. Kendrick Lamar's DNA sounded totally different than in my car. I could hear the keys struck on Glennn Gould's rendition of Bach's Goldberg Variaitions. The Beatles Sun King sounded like ti did in my dorm room when I had a truly "bad ass" stereo systm in college.

Also, I placed the speaker in a room with 15 foot ceilings, and the Truesound feature adapted the sound to the room to make it less "echoey."

I think Blue Tooth speakers have caused us to get used to poor acoustics, This speaker was like learning to hear again.
Wish it had bluetooth - app is a pain

reviews.reviewTitle: The Best Speaker I Have Ever Owned
reviews.reviewText:
The Sonos Play:5 is the crown jewel of the Sonos Hi-Fi collection. With 6 drivers in total (3 tweeters and 3 mid-woofers) and a Linux computer running the show, this speaker packs a PUNCH. My family and I listened to some Christmas songs on it last night and were blown away by new sounds we have never heard from songs we have been listening to for years.

The thing itself is stunning; a white matte box contains the setup, and a grey grille with precise venting emboldens the front. This speaker is definitely something to put on show, but can blend in if needed. I wouldn't ever put this thing in a bookshelf or hide it somehow, it is meant to be seen.

If you're wondering wether or not to buy it, you're probably scared about the price. I will be the first to say it is completely worth it, but everyone's situation is different. If you CAN afford it, you should splurge. It is an endless delight, built to last, and continues to fill my home with beautiful music and delight.

reviews.reviewTitle: The best speaker you can get for this price
reviews.reviewText:
The fidelity blows away anything I’ve ever heard before. I sold all my Bose speakers after getting this one and it rocks!!

What nobody will tell you is that if you think one is amazing, it is game changing when you have two of these - even if they are on opposite walls and not stereo paired. With the right sub and two of these, it sounds like you are in the center of a live performance.

The experience is transcendental, and I don’t give good reviews most of the time.

I think we are going to call this “the legendary play 5 gen 2” over time. The sound is highly dependent on the room. It does not show how good it is on the Best Buy floor. I took it home for my bathroom as it can handle humidity - only Speaker of its size which can do it.

Got hooked by the sound! Heard stuff I have never heard before.

Got one more for my dining room, got the third one refurb from Sonos. My God! Two play 5’s sound so good, especially with the sub, at this price, this quality of sound, I have never heard even from the $5000 lifestyle system at the Bose store.

Forget every other speaker, get one of these, add a sub, add another one. You will forget the world for the next week or so!

They are that good. 50x better than Bose. This is a no brainer.

If you love music, try this one out. You will not regret it.

I was wondering why it maybe working fine for me while others have WiFi issues. I never trusted WiFi being a software engineer because it always has problems with congestion. So I put in cat 5 cables to most rooms and some have cat 6 as well. Have gigabit internet and 1gbps network connections as compared to 100mbps in many places. Network congestion could be an issue. WiFi for me is a last mile thing where most of the large devices are Ethernet connected including two of my play 5’s.

CD Quality audio like with Airplay 2 (not even hi-res) can consume a lot of bandwidth. Same for high-res streaming. It might be just that. You need to figure out where you are getting congested - could be WiFi, could be your internet.

WiFi routers go bad after a while and WiFi cards as well are not that reliable. Over prolonged usage with large bandwidth usage, especially few years old equipment the issue could be at the router, speaker or the streaming device like the phone.

Living in an apartment with neighbors across shared walls probably makes things worse. Sorry folks! That might be the issue here.

I’ll update the review if I see any issues with my setup.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very nice sounding speaker if you have the room and cash, but does not approach high-end speakers
reviews.reviewText:
We decided to go full Nelson with Sonos and own play:5, play:1, the soundbar and sub in various rooms in the house. These have replaced a number of conventional speakers and subs. The sound quality of the play:5 is much better than the play:1 in maximum volume, frequency range (high and low), and overall clarity. I'd highly recommend getting a pair because of the better stereo separation. The play:5 will not distort much at high volumes for most music, except bass heavy hip hop. There is some painful distortion in the upper mid-range / lower high range which creeps in near maximum volume.

The play:5 matches the quality of conventional speakers in the $600-$800/pair range. When you consider that the amplifiers are included and the extreme convenience of the streaming software it is a pretty good value. If you are an audiophile, you are better off getting the Sonos connect:amp and adding a sub.

One great convenience of the Sonos system is that you can add units over time and still get full functionality because of the long production runs of each unit. We've added speakers over a few years, singly or in pairs to avoid large cash outlays and as we reconfigure rooms.

Pros:
Excellent sound and convenience
3.5mm mini-plug audio input (for bluetooth adapter, PC input, etc.)
Plays fairly loud without distortion
Good bass for regular music listening.
Wireless (2.4 Ghz) or wired Ethernet input
Vertical or Horizontal Orientation
Add units over time. Even a single play:5 is very functional. A pair is a lot better.
Any input can play on any speaker, or group of speakers.

Cons:
Won't play loud enough for a DJ-style party
Bookshelf speaker sized, 14 lbs.
Requires AC, somewhat limiting placement.
Optional Sub does not rock the house
Distortion creeps in at high volumes

IMO the sub is unnecessary for music. The play:1 is good for smaller rooms or if you don't play music very loudly.

reviews.reviewTitle: Buggy software, terrible support, prepare to be disappointed.
reviews.reviewText: I’ve had a Sonos 5 for a couple of years now. At first, it was great, never a problem. Then Sonos started monkeying with the software, and it all went downhill fast. Don’t get me wrong, their software needed updating badly — it was not very good. But now, when I listen to Sirius XM channels, the speaker starts skipping randomly through the cache, jumping back and forth through the program. Then Sonos added a feature where you can play songs from your phone. Great! Except a song will be playing when it suddenly stops as if it has ended — only the song has not ended, it’s just skipped to the next track. I looked it up, and the Sirius problem is definitely widely reported, yet Sonos played the old tech support game of pretending like I was the only person who had ever had this problem. They asked me to go through an incredibly complicated process to send them logs, which I was not able to figure out. Then, they told me that a new release was coming soon, and hinted that it would fix this problem. That was a year ago, and it’s still having the same problem. I’m about done. I think I’ll get an Amazon device, even though the sound will suffer and the government will probably be listening to me through it.

I had the older model Play:5 and it stopped working, and I am glad it did when it did, so that I bought this new model instead of purchasing another gen 1 Play:5. The sound quality on this thing is amazing. I also own two play 1's, playbar, and sub that I compare it to. I am excited to for when the a new playbar comes out because I am not impressed with the sound quality from the playbar, as this new play 5 can produce better sound. It produce s more than enough bass to fill my 600 sq ft bedrom, big improvement from the older play5 on this aspect. The bass is much more pronounced at lower volumes too, whereas the older play5 sounded flat at lower volumes. Lastly, the look is much improved over the old play5 and it allows for it to be positioned in different configurations and to be mounted. I Had to drive an hour to get it and got the last one at any best but in Minnesota till next week. It is worth the $100 increase over the old play5 and it is worth every penny of its rather outrageous price tag. Already dreaming about being able to stereo pairing this up with another play5; might have to treat myself if I can get a 4.0 this semester. One last note to those just getting interested in Sonos speakers I would get two play5s over the sub as the play 5s can produce plenty of bass.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not as trouble-free as I hoped (but getting better, I think)
reviews.reviewText:
I have a pair of Sonos 5s. When it works, it's brilliant. Unfortunately, there are still some software issues.

For the first months I owned these, I had problems with the controller (mostly my iPhone) losing the connection with the speakers. Sometimes, I could not connect. At other times, I would have music playing, but I could not connect to stop the music, so I had to unplug the speakers to get them to stop playing.

The solution to every problem seemed to be to unplug the speakers, power down the Internet router, power everything back up in reverse order, and hope for the best. That usually worked, but sometimes more than one try was required to get everything working. When I just wanted to hear some music, this wasn't how I wanted to spend my time.

Sonos technical support seemed to think it was a problem with my router.

Then after a software update from Sonos, I had several months of trouble-free operation. I was delighted. I could pause the music, and if I was away for a week, when I reconnected, it would pick up mid-song exactly where I left off. It seemed they had solved their software problems.

I recently accepted the most recent software update from Sonos. Yes, I ignored the adage, "If it ain't broke don't fix it." Unfortunately, things are back to the earlier state or even worse. If I want to listen to music, I expect that the Sonos system won't be found. I will spend 30 minutes or so restarting everything

A day does not go by now without problems. I come home and want to listen to music while I cook dinner, and I am confronted with not being able to connect to the speakers. It's bad enough that I don't expect it to work now. Some days, I just give up and listen to music on Amazon Echo. Sound quality is not nearly as good as the Sonos, but at least it works reliably.

Makes me sad. It's a product with great potential, but you may not get simple, fuss-free operation.

I'm updating and revising this review upward. After my initial review, I decided to give a Sonos Boost a try, figuring that getting some of the Sonos traffic off my "main" wireless network might help. Sonos technical support did not seem optimistic that this would solve my problem, but for $99, I figured it was worth a shot. I hooked up the Boost and switched my speakers to use it (easy!). My "main" WiFi is configured for channel 11, so I set the Boost to channel 1.

It's been over a month since I did that, and I have experienced no subsequent problems with the Play 5's.

I'm not completely sure my problems are gone, since I had over six months of trouble-free operation last year, but I'm keeping my fingers crossed.

reviews.reviewTitle: Beware of faulty Wifi and need to exchange through Sonos, Excellent Speaker otherwise and worth the upgrade from Gen 1
reviews.reviewText: As a Sonos owner for a few years now (two Play 3, one Play 5, one Play 5 gen:2, and the soundbar for a short while), I have been impressed and have used my Sonos sound system enough times to know that they are well built. Reading the many reviews on the new Gen 2, I decided to take the financial plunge and purchased mine in December of 2016. Overall, it is everything I read it was compared to the Gen 1. The Gen 1 is still a great speaker, but in terms of filling my living room with music which is where my Gen 1 was placed before, the Gen 2 sounds louder, music sounds better, and the base makes me doubt I will ever need a standalone Sonos Bass. In fact, since I live in a condo I've turned down the loudness setting and some of the bass as well. Even taking away the bass, I enjoy the richness in the music more than I do with my Gen 1. So for 3 months, everything was great. I use my system at least 5 times a week, each time for 1-3 hours. Especially now with the music controller integration onto my apple watch now that I don't need to carry my phone to change tracks or control volume. I've never had an issue with my other 3 year old speakers, then all of a sudden my new 2 month old Play:5 fell off of my Sonos system. Odd, but I managed to add the speaker again. Then early in early March, the speaker fell of the system again and I was unable to reconnect wirelessly no matter what I tried. It did still work however when connected to an ethernet cable, but that's not how I meant to have my Sonos system connected in the first place. After some time and research, it turns out that there are a number of Play:5 Gen 2's with faulty wireless chips/cards which makes them fall off of wireless systems periodically, or permanently. I called Sonos, and without saying anything, the Sonos tech politely walked me through different troubleshooting steps, until finally 30 min later he stated the same thing, that there have been a number of wireless malfunctions with some of the newer Play 5's. Since the speakers have to register with Sonos when you use them for the first time, the rep knew that mine was less than a year old, and set up an exchange which was painless. I used the same box I received my new Sonos to ship the faulty one back, and so far no issues with my new Speaker. So if you do buy this speaker, understand that it is an excellent sounding speaker, but be aware and ready to call customer service if you experience any sort of Wifi drop. I did not deduct any stars from the review because Sonos customer service was friendly, polite, and made the exchange painless, and they did confirm that the replacement speaker comes with a new 1 year warranty from the shipment date.

I picked up my first wireless speaker, a play:1, during a black friday sale and in less than a year decided to upgrade to a play:5 during a Sonos anniversary sale. The play:1 rebate was immediate but the play:5 was a rebate after purchase. Sonos provided the rebate only as a wire transfer (not ACH) which caused a $15 fee from my bank. Sonos eventually got that straight by refunding me even more money.

I use the Sonos in the kitchen. I placed the play:1 on top of my refrigerator as it sounded boomy on the countertop (and I wanted it out of the way). It sounded better at ear height. I wanted to upgrade to get a fuller sound, with more bass, and more stereo separation. The play:1 has only one, universal driver while the play:5 has 6 independent drivers. The play:5 is contoured and probably meant to rest below hear height, like on a countertop. Since the drivers face upward, I had to adjust the cabinet so while on top of the refrigerator the drivers faced forward (or even slightly down). It took rubber feet almost 0.5” tall to reach proper adjustment.

I like the sound of the play:5. It certainly is a fuller sound than the play:1 that fills the kitchen regardless of your location. I find it stops playing infrequently when the microwave is in use. The play:1 never did this. I’ve tried different wi-fi frequencies but the issue persists. One other irritating issue is that you can start and stop music from your own collection (on my PC’s hard drive) by simply touching the button on top. But if you are listening to radio from TuneIn, if you turn it off for any length of time it won’t resume with a press of the ON button. You have to return to the app to restart.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not worth the money if you want to listen to your own music
reviews.reviewText: very very disappointed I wanted to play music from my I tunes from my lib only thing it won't do you have to order a music service got to be about 25 alot I never heard of but I tunes which is one of the top I wanted to listen to my music the only way is line in with a i pod will then you have only volume is the i pod and you have to have a cord to line in for i pod this was very poorly designed

reviews.reviewTitle: Serious connection problems with wifi. Keeps dropping and does not work well with theater.
reviews.reviewText: Sonos also does not play well with blu ray or 4k players. Very limited in features. They have gone down hill since 2 years ago. I am selling the whole system, spent over $3,000 dollars and now I have to get rid of it. Garbage software with wifi card issues that constantly drop every few weeks. Customer service is completely lacking. Zero service. There app constantly want to know my location and private information. There end goal is to spy on us and then sell our information from what it seems like with there updated privacy agreement to even use there app to use Sonos.

reviews.reviewTitle: Sonos Product Support is Horrible - I Will Never Again Buy Another Sonos Product!
reviews.reviewText:
Purchased this and it went completely dead shortly after the warranty expired. Sonos customer support basically said ‘I’m sorry, there is nothing we can do for you and we don’t offer any repair options’. After doing some research into the issue I learned that there are systemic issues with their power and WIFI boards and Sonos won’t do anything about it. After strking out with customer service, I reached out to Nick Millington, who is their Chief Product Officer and he didn’t bother to return my call.

Conversely, Bose customer service has always been outstanding and they are making inroads in this market. I’ll most likely buy their products going forward.

You can test their support before you buy any of their products and call CS and ask about their chronic problems with their power and WIFI boards. If they tell you they are unaware of them, they are lying. Then you can ask them what happens if the boards fail just after the warranty expires. If they’re honest, they’ll tell you that they’ll do nothing.

A very high percentage of Sonos’ customers end up buying more of their products after buying their 1st one. I was about to spend $3k in additional Sonos speakers, but based on their horrible support of their very expensive speakers, I will never buy another one of their products.

Hi, my name is Carrie, and I am a SONOS addict. I have been clean zero days. Let me tell you about Play 5. If you buy this speaker, you will love it. You will be so, so happy with the quality of sound, and you will feel it was worth the money. If you are going to buy just one SONOS, get the Play 5 for sure. HOWEVER, I must warn you that if you buy a second SONOS speaker, you will become an addict. When you plug a second SONOS in for the first time, you realize you must have more and more. These speakers communicate with each other, so for example, if you have two Play 5s in one room, they will not be playing the exact same sounds. They work together to bring a richness to music that you did not ever know was possible. The sound quality of movies is that of a theater. If you like shooter games, you will hear the enemy coming up behind you, from the direction they are coming from. These speakers are SIIIIIICK. As a bonus, when your friends come over, they can instantly change the music to their own playlist on their own phone, or everyone in the room can stack the songs they want to play into the queue like a jukebox.

I now own two Play 5s, two Play 1s, two sub-woofers, and the sound bar. I recommend not having neighbors who live close by if you become addicted. You may need to move so you can fully appreciate your sound system and shake your home to its very foundation. The sub-woofers create *wind*. I'm not joking. I still want more. Just two maybe. Two more Play 5s should do it. ;)

I should start out by saying that I really like Sonos products, and have them throughout the house. For the main listening area, I bought two Play 5s about a year and a half ago and set them set up in stereo. Ok, so we've got a pair of $1,000 speakers. As far as sound goes, they are decent, but not great for that amount of money. There are wired speakers in that price range that will do a lot better. That said, the wireless environment is pretty much the only way for me to go at this point, and I enjoy these speakers quite a bit, but I have had to adjust my expectations. I think all the great reviews about the sound quality are only partially justified, the rest are in my view at least, wishful thinking. I wish they produced a bigger sound (not louder, just better).

The right speaker just died suddenly one day, and nothing I did could bring it back to life. Bad wifi card, and Sonos agreed to immediately replace it even though the warranty had expired. No questions asked, just return the old one. The entire process took about 5 days. You see a lot of complaints about Sonos customer service, but not here. Now I'm kinda paranoid about the left speaker though.

I have a lot of money invested in Sonos, and overall I am happy. The software is weak absolutely, but I have never had any problems with my other speakers, sound bar, sub, or connect.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does a good job with few drops in music - too expensive. I only got because I had a lot of Amazon reward points.
reviews.reviewText: Does a good job in my open area Living-room/dining room and kitchen. (front third of my home basically). I was using only a Play One. Couldn't decide if I should add another One and stereo pair it or just get this....happy with getting this and adding the One to a small room. Let's hope I don't have the wifi break issues others have reported as the unit ages. I have 3 zones in my house and I have never had a problem getting them connected with the app. I do have drops where the music just stops at times but adding an extender/repeater cut them down a lot. Sonos does seem to have wifi signal strength issues as my Alexa devices never needed an extender. This needs to be addressed as it seems Sonos wants everyone to buy their boost product and waste more money. Much cheaper getting a simple extender.

reviews.reviewTitle: Warning - it's only as good as the software, which doesn't work most of the time.
reviews.reviewText: The styling of the speaker and the sound quality are outstanding. Unfortunately, the software it uses is critical to its functioning. And that part doesn't work about 3/4 of the time. I wouldn't buy it again. It's only reliable when I play music from my phone using the 1/8" cord. They really should add bluetooth for the times the wifi doesn't work, which is most of the time.

Fro the moment I opened my pair of Sonos 5s it was clear that I am dealing here with a quality product that was made with attention to detail and simplicity. The setup was very easy and I put them vertically about 15 Feet aqwy from each other. I was concerned because it's in my living room with a large open kitchen and a some 30 feet long walls. So basically because it's vertical the Sonos adjusts itself to vertical mode and I have an amazing clear sound with both high, mid and lows at a perfect range. Now, don't get upset if it doesn't have the high and lows at the beginning. It's because the default settings suppress the lows and highs. I find out that when you go to the App and go to Settings and to the "Room" and to "Speaker" and to "EQ" (Equalizer) , you then can control the highs and the lows. I had to go through a few songs in different styles until I settled on a high that was just right (higher than the default) and on the bass that was just right (also higher than eventually got it to where I just loved it and all the tones were natural and not metallic or too vibrating. I just love the sound. Couldn't have been better. The only way they got such great sound is the internal amplifiers. I have to mention that the vertical setting gives an amazing sweet spot with perfect natural stereo and if it's horizontal the spot spreads wider and fills the house better if you are in a large house. In my case I just want it to be perfect on my couch and I will get smaller units for the kitchen and other rooms. I can now see why people are buying more units. It's just so beautiful and an improvement in quality of life. Thanks to Sonos who decided to make the best quality and the most intuitive system on the market. I had a few concerns about he L shape of my living room and about the fact that I don't connect any of them directly to the router but this system has no problem to be 20 plus feet away from the router. Juts an awesome purchase. You had to see the look on my wife's face when I first let her sit on the couch where the sweet spot is. It really makes you forget about the price.

I’m beginning to regret ever getting into bed with Sonos products. I barely use my system as it is and it barely ever work properly. I’ve had to replace a few Play 1’s that barely lasted a year or so. And now I fear my Play 5 has a failed wireless card since it just stopped working and won’t connect wirelessly but will connect if plugged in directly to the router. For the amount of money for these speakers and they barely last, they’re no longer worth the hassle. And customer service is pretty terrible. Specially the hours. They’re only available to talk to Monday - Friday from 10am - 9pm EST, if you’re in another time zone, it’s more than likely you’re working during the times they are available and not at home with your system. How the hell are you supposed to be able to trouble shoot your system with a live customer service rep. Take a day off from work to do it I suppose. As I said. Not worth the price since they don’t seem to last long and the hassles of trying to get customer service.

The highest of high fidelity. Gorgeous, awe-inspiring sound. Clear sweet treble and full creamy bass, even at low volume. Probably sounds better than live music unless you can get your ear built in to the guitar's sound hole. Very easy to set up. I am not technically proficient and I did it on my own. The only bad moment was when the app didn't recognize the speaker because, yes it was me, I didn't have the power cord jammed in to the back of the speaker all the way. So I had to figure that out, phttph, good thing I'm a genius.

Get yourself a subscription to Spotify or Pandora or any of a dozen of music services, and then the Sonos will play from that just fine. Again, I am not good at this sort of thing and I did not have any problem.

Be wise and do not try to network other brands along with your Sonos things or else your wifi will get confused and get dizzy and pass out. Stick with the one brand.

I bought at a big box store so I could get the customer service, but I won't need it. And I don't want to leave the house with the sound being here now.

reviews.reviewTitle: Speaker stops working if it is temporarily disconnected from power
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this $500 speaker 2 months ago. I would have given it a 5 rating for the 2 months that it worked. However, I disconnected the power to the speaker. After I plugged the speaker back in, the speaker would not play. I have wasted hours searching on the internet on on how to fix this known problem. None of the "fixes" worked. Advice... Do NOT buy Sonos if you ever intend to move a speaker! If you already have a Sonos system do NOT ever unplug the speakers or they might stop working.

Update...
Talked to support. This was a software issue that was fixed in a brief phone call by tech support.

reviews.reviewTitle: The sound quality is beautiful, just beautiful
reviews.reviewText:
THE SOUND QUALITY OF THIS SPEAKER IS SO GODD*** BEAUTIFUL. The sound stays crisp and clear, even when the volume is allllll the way up. Also important, and unlike the PLAY 1 or PLAY 3, it has a built-in sub, which truly elevates music quality to an entirely different level.

More pros:
--Easy to use
--Can be positioned vertically or horizontally
--Gorgeous design

Cons:
--The biggest downfall of this and all other Sonos speakers is that music must be wirelessly streamed through music-only third party apps, such as Spotify, Pandora, Google Play Music, or the music library on your mobile device. Youtube is incompatible for wireless use with Sonos speakers, and Sonos has no intention on making their speakers Youtube-compatible. The PLAY 5 does have a Line-In option though that allows you to connect your phone/tablet/mp3/pc/etc to the speaker via auxiliary cord and play whatever you want that way. It's annoying that it cannot be done wirelessly, but at least it has this option.

--Not very portable. Power must be supplied via electrical outlet, and it's a bit heavy.

--Power supply cord does not latch on to the speaker tightly and thus can easily be disconnected if you touch the cord or move the speaker.

--Connecting to a wireless network can be frustrating. The first-time set up should go smoothly; Sonos has an app that walks you through the entire process. But when I need to connect to a new Network (ie, change Internet providers, or take the system over to a friend's house), I cannot get a connection to establish unless I factory-reset the Sonos speaker. I searched the Sonos website up and down and tried everything they recommended, but nothing worked. The only thing that did it for me was a factory reset. I'm not a Networking guru, so maybe a simpler way exists, but I could not find one that actually worked. Anyway, here's directions from the Sonos website on how to factory reset a PLAY 5, should you need them:

"What is the difference between factory resetting or rebooting a Sonos player?

Factory resetting and simply rebooting your Sonos player or product are very different things. Factory resetting your Sonos player will completely wipe any stored information from the player, where as rebooting the Sonos player just powers it off and on while preserving the data.

Factory resetting is typically done when you are transferring ownership of the player or want to register the player to a different email address. Rebooting the player is done if you've replaced your router or move a player from one location in your home to another.

How to reboot your Sonos player

To reboot a Sonos player:

Simply remove the power cord from the wall outlet or from the back or bottom of the Sonos player.
Wait about 10 seconds for the unit to completely power off and then plug the player back in.
Allow 1 minute for the player to boot back up.
If the player was previously setup, it should automatically rejoin when the boot sequence is complete.

How to factory reset your Sonos player

Factory resetting is most commonly used when it is necessary to register the Sonos system to a different email address or to completely wipe all saved data from a player, such as music services, Sonos playlists, and music library shares. This information cannot be restored.

Unplug the power cord from the electrical wall outlet.
Press and hold the Connect button while simultaneously plugging the power cord back into the electrical wall outlet.
Continue holding the Connect button until the light begins flashing amber and white.
Once reset, the light will flash green, indicating the product has been reset and can be added back to your Sonos household."

reviews.reviewTitle: Persistent Wifi interference and connection issues - don't buy!
reviews.reviewText: I started with Sonos in 2013, now have 11 speakers, but totally exasperated by horrible connection issues. Tech support will help you find alternative wifi channels, but unless you live in a rural area or neighborhood with very wide home spacing, you will be dealing with neighbor wifi conflicts and persistent disconnection issues. I try to keep my Sono speakers on the same channel, but within a day, all the speakers will be once again unseparated. I strongly recommend choosing a different system.

reviews.reviewTitle: Truly inspiring sound from a single speaker.
reviews.reviewText:
For most, spending hundreds of dollars on a music speaker may seem a bit excessive, but every single time I listen to this speaker it reminds me that it was totally worth it. The clarity and richness of the sound is truly amazing. I will say that you will have to be a bit of an audiophile to appreciate it, so if you’re the type of person who thinks $20 headphones are sufficient, you will not appreciate this speaker. However, if you’re the type of person who has spent $200 on headphones just for sound quality, this speaker is what you have been missing. All types of music sound fantastic from calming piano, to upbeat country, to seriously loud club style music.
Take the extra minute to preform the Trueplay tuning (iPhone only, so android users miss out here) and you will instantly love this speaker.
My only warning to everyone is if you start by purchasing one Sonos product, you’ll instantly be hooked and will end up spending $1,500-$2,000 on your whole home audio set up. So if you can afford to spend serious money on speakers, this is probably the one to start with. This unit has plenty of bass alone, but if you pair it with the Sonos SUB, you will have a hard time finding anything that sounds better. From the most piercing highs, to shattering lows, Sonos is the way to go, as long as you can afford it. Be ready to catch the Sonos bug!

reviews.reviewTitle: Buy one and feel the joy!!!!
reviews.reviewText: Simply amazing. I have a $15K + A/V system with high-end speakers and amps and when at the gym use Bowers & Wilkins P5 headphones which are fantastic. So I guess I'm saying I know great audio reproduction. I immediately signed up for Tidal to listen to FLAC audio (less compression) and the sound is knock-your-socks-off great. What sold me was when I heard them at local audio show and the manufacture's reps were playing them. I only bought one but they had 2 for stereo and their wireless woofer so I didn't know if just one speaker would sound so great but I took the plunge. So far, I've listened for about 10 hours of classical, rock, pop, alternative and Jazz and ALL sound superb. The sound quality across the entire spectrum is accurate. The bass is perfect for my ears, not boomy or underpowered. It is natural and like what you would hear live. The definition of the instruments is VERY good and even with one speaker the sound stage is amazing. Vocals are crisp and spacious. Piano is notoriously difficult to faithfully reproduce and the Play 5 is dead on accurate. I have not experienced so much joy with an audio product other than my B&W headphones, in a very long time.

reviews.reviewTitle: best speakers I've owned in 40 years
reviews.reviewText:
Bought two 5s, so a matched stereo pair for the living room. Incredible audio, best speakers I've owned in 40 years. Reminds me of the digital vs. analog argument of the 80s. Yes, for more money, there are better "traditional" speakers, BUT the convenience of streaming and managing music from a single app, to each room in the house, is more important especially when the audio is this good. I think a single Sonos 5 would work well in a mid-sized room, but it won't have the channel separation of two separate 5s even though the 5 is a stereo speaker.

I'm new to Sonos, and wireless household streaming, so the great audio quality takes a second place to the convenience of the controller app (on my smartphone, and MacBook Pro). The free controller app works well. I am able to stream, and control, music from my iTunes library, Amazon Music Unlimited (or most other services), and Tunein Radio, from one single app. The app also allows me to make app-based playlists, with tracks from my library, as well as Amazon or any other subscription service. Kind of a "best-of" playlist with tracks from various sources. I also stream classical concerts from around the world with the built-in Tunein Radio service. It offers every station world-wide (and it let's you add a different higher-bitrate streaming URL for a station if it is available). Very happy I took the leap to wi-fi streaming with Sonos.....only wish the audio could also be played back via headphones on the phone and Mac.

reviews.reviewTitle: Update broke system; Customer service is nice, but doesn't help at all.
reviews.reviewText:
Was awesome. Now it just doesn't work. As I've seen other 1* reviewers mention, this happened after an update, and customer service gives me the runaround. They may genuinely not know what is going on. Paid >$1500, worth like $100, if that.

I had slight problems with the system shortly after purchasing, so I bought a $200 Nighthawk router, and things improved. Several months later, it's 10x worse.

I should mention that when it did work... it sounded excellent, and was very convenient. I think there should be a hardware button to switch to line-in mode, in the event you lose the internet, but still want to use them (there is a software way to make this the default behavior, but that is sketchy).

reviews.reviewTitle: Wouldn't pay more than $300 due to functionality issues
reviews.reviewText:
I bought 2 of these, I'll probably return one. I thought I could hook it up to my computer and use it as a regular computer system (not so).

Also for a wireless speaker... it's not wireless, it needs to be plugged in at all times, I get it, it's a powerhouse of sound, but I feel a little mislead.

Non of this is really sonos's fault, I didn't do enough research.

The real thorn I have with this product is the limited functionality due to the software/ app. There is no other way to say it, the app sucks. REALLY SUCKS. For example, in my Pandora stations are set to organize chronologically not alphabetically. In Pandora through the Sonos app, it goes back to alphabetically, which is annoying

The app is ugly, laggy, and hard to use and doesn't really interface that well. The app and the computer software really limit the usability of this awesome speaker. It would be much better if you could just tether to the network/devices and use whatever music app you want.

It's kinda like reverting back to 2004 using the line-in constantly (which underminds the not-so-wireless feature again) just with better sound quality.

Eh, all in all I love the sound, but I would NEVER recommend this product to anyone, nor will I ever buy another Sonos product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great sound but frustrating Spotify playback
reviews.reviewText: First I have to say this speaker has great sound, on par if not better than the equivalent Bose speakers and others on the market. But I am giving it 3 stars because I use this speaker primarily to stream my Spotify music. When I first bought it it worked as it was supposed to, I controlled my music either from the Sonos app on my phone and computer and the Spotyfy app from my phone and computer also without issue. But lately I've become very frustrated with the playback from Spotify. It will randomly stop playing and will not allow the control from my phone or even the PC. A large portion of the songs from my playlists are grayed out on the Sonos app and are not available for playback. I am starting to regret purchasing this speaker. I planned on adding more Sonos speakers throughout my house, but now I am weary and will probably switch to another system if this issue is not fixed.

I have owned a Play 5 for about a year and enjoyed the crispness of the bass and clarity of the treble with clear vocals. Although a single Play 5 is likely sufficient for most people I missed the stereo separation of some of my favorite tracks. This prompted purchase of an additional Play 5 to my Sonos collection paired together in L and R stereo separation. Needless to say I listen to it more than before. I am also happy with Sonos' commitment to constant update including incorporation of the AirPlay 2. So as long as I am using an Apple mobile device I can stream what ever app is streaming audio (including YouTube). I hope Google and Android come up with a similar functionality so that I can enjoy my Play 5s with my Android phones independent of the Sonos app. Overall love it!

reviews.reviewTitle: Prepare to do software engineering every time you want to play music
reviews.reviewText:
Just simply doesn't work very well - nonstop updates, incompatibilities, inability to read songs in the iTunes library, dropped wireless needing reset, losing settings...

and the company has a bad attitude towards its customers: I'd been using Sonos speakers off of a desktop Mac for years. With no notice an automatic download made it impossible to use the desktop controller - customer service helpfully informed me that "most customers like to control from a mobile device." This leaves me with hundreds of dollars of useless speakers.

If you buy anything from Sonos, you'll finally get it installed, and you'll be happy - and then you'll have to wrestle with it for half an hour most times you want to play music. Just get Apple systems instead.

reviews.reviewTitle: Sounds Great / Can't Play Your Own Music
reviews.reviewText: This was one of the most disappointing purchases in recent memory. The sound and overall design on the Play 5 really is great, except for one glaring issue: You cannot play music that you own. Period. I don't care that Sonos says that it is possible, it is not. I spent hours going through the Sonos support pages trying to add my own music library, but the system is simply not intended to be used that way. Your only option with this is to pay a monthly fee for a streaming service—or the free Pandora service with loud commercials. If that is all you want, then this will be great. If you have, say a collection of music that is not on Apple Music, Amazon, or Spotify, you are out of luck. You cannot play it on the Sonos. Really sucks, but that's the deal.

reviews.reviewTitle: Sounds Great - and works well with Alexa and Amazon Music
reviews.reviewText:
Sound quality of the 'five" is almost as good as high end $1500 plus hifi system. (In a very large room). Took me only 4 minutes to set up. I have a strong wifi signal (Mesh) and that seems to be important. Over the month I've owned it I have never lost a signal.

Works seamlessly with Alexa, although when instructing her, you'll need to keep the echo speaker and the Sonos speaker straight, otherwise there will be some confusion where you want your music played. If you are not careful you could end up with streams "open" (even if not playing) on both and the dot and the Sonos. And since each are considered separate devices that count towards your max number of your Amazon music accounts, Alexa will tell you to turn one off. A bit klutzy.

The Sonos works very well with my ipads (no Alexa) and is pretty well integrated with Amazon music via the "connect to device" option (the three dots at the top right of your screen). The Sonos software is very functional. Its easy to listen directly to thousands of streaming radio stations and and all the major music services, though the Sonos software is not quite as slick as the speaker. Hope they will upgrade in the future.

I'm very happy I bought the Sonos-5. I've never listened to more music.

Our Sonos system consists of 4 Play 1, 1 Play 5 and a Bridge that ties in my ancient but truly awesome audio stack and Infinity speakers. We've had the original pieces of the system since 2013, and have occasionally added Play 1s.
I highly prefer a pair of Play 1 speakers over the Play 5 Gen 1 we have. They seem much more natural and full. The Play 5 tends to boom and resonate such that I think I'd need a quality narrowband EQ to get the desired performance. In addition, the physical separation available with two Play 1s gives stereo separation that the Play 5 cannot have.
All that said, we've been happy enough with the Play 5 until last week. When we unplugged the Play 5 to move it to a different room, it could not be located by the Sonos controller, and the LED flashed white about every 5 seconds indefinitely. Yep, another Play 5 failure. Tried all the suggestions on the support community pages and then waited my half hour for the Sonos help desk, running diagnostics while I waited. Of course, the help desk tech eventually diagnosed a failed unit and offered the 30% off. I do not feel the Play 5 is worth $349, let alone $499. I will not be buying another Play 5. Further, with my almost 40 year old Denon audio stack still running perfectly, and the Sonos system starting to fail in less than 6 years (good compared to some of your very early failures), I am questioning my overall investment in Sonos.

I love the original Amazon Echo, but am a minor audiophile and never like the sound from its speaker.

That's why I was so excited when the dot came out! It allowed the capability of an Echo, but had an aux out to attach to a better speaker.

Sadly, a lot of speakers nowadays (like the Harmon Kardon Aura Studio) automatically put themselves to sleep after a time, but don't wake themselves up.

Enter the Play:5, which not only sounds great, with good clarity and strong bass, but also has an arguably ideal capability to not only auto-wake from line-in, but also have the smarts to switch from the Sonos app wireless play to the line-in (and back) as needed! This makes the Play:5 fit the best of both worlds, playing audio services the Echo doesn't (like songs stored on your iPhone), but also any service the Echo DOES support!

It is also a versitile part of the Sonos ecosystem, which features not only room equalization/calibration with Trueplay, but also the ability to expand into multi-speaker, or even multi-room setups!

On the downside, the speaker takes a second for auto-wake to kick in, so the first second or two of response can go missing from the Echo Dot response if you haven't used it in awhile. Additionally, there are other high-end wireless speakers that sound better (e.g. the B&W Zeppelin Wireless), but the Play:5 hit a sweet spot for me in sound quality, price and especially versatility!

I like it greatly and you will too!

I think this may be the best investment I've made to date! No, it's not "cheap," but after listening to some of the most expensive all-in-one speakers from other premium audio companies, I'm SO glad I chose this one.

Audio performance - 11/10, yes, I said it, 11 out of 10! Can't get over how low it goes and how clean and natural it sounds even at higher frequencies. Then to top it off with Trueplay, it's next level.

Looks/functionality - 9/10, the interactivity is amazing with the capacitive touch sensors. The only thing that I feel needs improvement is maybe a way to trigger a favorite station. I bet Sonos is already working on it but it would be nice.

Value - 10/10, again, I can say this thing honestly sounds better than the new Zeppelin Wireless from B&W, and that's saying a lot. Don't get me wrong, there are a couple songs that sounded better on the B&W, but the bass and overall clarity pushed this over the edge. And the cherry on top was that Trueplay made it sound that much better! Not to mention the Sonos app, no one comes close in this category.

Bottom line: Buy this, you will NOT be disappointed! Sonos literally gets better with every update that I get. I truly feel for a company with such a passion for music, that this is the start of a very bright future of products.

reviews.reviewTitle: Nothing works like sonos. Their speakers sound every bit as good ...
reviews.reviewText:
Audiophiles have stuck with Sonos from the very beginning. Nothing works like sonos. Their speakers sound every bit as good as any high brand out there. Bose doesn’t cut it guys! Play 5 sounds like Bang & Olufsen.

If you are on the fence - don’t be. This thing just works. The app is constantly updated. Not even Bose updates their app to be cutting edge. Sonos has updates all the time. It’s compatible with any music service. It makes sense.

This is by far the best you can get and and you can keep expanding on it as needed. My old equipment from 7 years ago never gets old ! It always has the latest software. Sonos is a long haul product. If you go blue tooth the Bluetooth version will get old and you’ll end up with old junk. Grab a Sonos and you won’t be sorry. I have a few of these. I have one on my hifi system with KEF XQ speakers. I grabbed the play 5 for the back yard. It doesn’t disappoint.

Some great features, some disappointments. There are lots of great things about the Sonos speaker and some disappointing things as well. Lets start off with the bad! Things you can do with a bluetooth speaker like stream youTube over the speakers is not possible. Sonos is updating but some services take a while to get there. But you can hack the system. I had Soundcloud running before it was officially supported. Another major meh is using Spotify. Needless to say I have a different taste in music than other members of the family. How do you switch accounts? I haven't figured that out yet. So it is not seamless but awkward.
The good. Sound quality is great, classical, pumping bass, low volume, high volume. Top class. One extra advantage over bluetooth is that the music does keep playing when someone calls, which I do like.
If Sonos can work a way out to get things like YouTube supported it will be the 'to go to' speaker.

After 2 years my play 5 died. I spend 2 hours on my moving day with tech support instead of working. When I finally had to go they said they had me set up with a rma and I could return the defective product. I called back after moving into my new house and they said the same thing this need to be returned. They had already had my serial number from the two hour call with tech support, but when they asked for it for the return they informed me it was out of warrenty and there was nothing they could do. A product this expensive should not fail so easy and not have a decent warrenty. I will be looking to unload the rest of my Sonos products as I can't trust them to work when I want them.

reviews.reviewTitle: What you buy is not what you get
reviews.reviewText:
My Play:5 is now a brick with no remedy from Sonos support.

It worked immediately after I bought it, but a subsequent "update" removed support for configuring the system from Windows and Mac OS X. I repeat, you *cannot configure the Sonos from these platforms*. Since these are the platforms I have access to, I now own a $500 paperweight. Support has been useless after five rounds of back and forth. Avoid this product - they may choose to invalidate *your* platform next, and you will have no recourse.

reviews.reviewTitle: Just Buy It...It's a Fantastic Speaker
reviews.reviewText:
UPDATE: 9.10.18 This just gets better. I notice it has adjusted to my room and just gets better. The depth of sound is really amazing with this speaker. I brought a Sonos 3 for my room and it was WAY less performance so I returned it and put a 5 up there too. It really keeps the clarity on high volume and throws the sound around the room, amazing it comes from a small speaker. I am 100% glad I picked this....

I have been looking at speakers for a while--couple of months. I upgraded TV's recently, and I had a Bose Soundbar that was "okay" and I was unsatisfied to the level the new TV was at. I have a Bose Soundwave in my room for the TV and it doesn't have the bass depth I like either. So since I have the new TV's, great excuse to buy more stuff and move stuff around....

First, Bose is okay but I know Bose is a reputation brand and pretty safe but there are better things out there. Before I buy more Bose stuff I wanted to see what's out there.

Since I am a big Apple user, I thought what does the HomePod have to offer...I actually ended up buying one. I read a lot of the HomePod vs. Sonos Play 5 reviews and they are both good, so I figured I would try it. First,it is not nearly as smart as Alexa. The sound is okay for it's size, but I am not impressed with it. I can't adjust the sound, I like a lot of bass, a lot of treble--and sound depth...plus I like loud. HomePod is less than what I wanted on all levels.

The HomePod is good at lower volumes and better than the Bose SoundWave for sure. But I have Alexa and it is way better from a features standpoint, so back to the store the HomePod is going.

I thought the best reviews are for this Sonos device so I will buy the Sonos Play 5--my thoughts:

* Took about 5 minutes to set up. Really nice packaging, the experience of opening it was great.
* Loaded the App, I was listening to the TV in another 5 minutes with my Apple Music all set up
* The bass is WAAAAY awesome, it goes louder than I will use in here without feeling bad for my neighbors. The whole house feels the bass.
* I can adjust the sound, not super sophisticated but I can customize it. HomePod, you get what you get--I didn't like that.
* This is more than I expected sound-wise, I kind of want to buy another one for upstairs instead of moving the SoundBar up there.
* For me, the smart speaker aspect I don't really care about. I just want to play my music and the TV. I know some of the reviews said compared to the HomePod it had a lot to be desired, but I don't need a Digital Assistant, just a killer speaker.....this is a killer speaker.

Speaker sounds great!
Good volume !
Good design !
VERY POOR PHONE APP !!!
It's horrible that you can't use the actual music apps in your phone and it all must go through the Sonos App... Bad bad bad !!!!

Each time I would like to listen, I am delayed by a software update. I can select to upload later, but then the app closes. I am held hostage to a 15 minute software update when I wish to use the Play:5. Last update, as an added feature, Sonos lost all my favorite stations. The Play:5 sounds fine, would have gotten higher marks if it had tone controls to compensate for room placement... mysteriously missing despite initial cost and clunky, constant software updates. Very disappointed with this purchase.

The only reason I purchased Sonos was for the compatibility with my iPhone. The sales person pointed out Sonos vs other available systems and demonstrated how easy Sonos paired with my iPhone. No streaming apps or other options necessary. So I went full in. My house is totally Sonos linked to my music library and playlists on my iPhone. And now Sonos has killed the only reason it was purchased. I understand technology upgrades, as Sonos seems to force weekly, but now my entire purchase is useless. I'm not on a streaming service, (extra cost) and I don't use a PC for iTunes. Bottom line, I spent a lot of money on Sonos vs Bose, and Sonos abandoned their advertised product. Looking forward to the class action. I'll be first in line!

reviews.reviewTitle: The sound coming from this thing...wow!
reviews.reviewText:
This is my first experience with Sonos and I'm hooked! I know there are better sounding speakers for the money but this is not to say that this sounds horrible. I use this outside on my patio and the sound...wow! It's amazing the amount of sound this tiny box puts out. When paired together with other Sonos speakers, they fill the room with more spatious sound.

The listening zones is where I feel there is good value. I have speakers in several rooms around the house and it's nice to be able to sync them together or listen to different playlists in each room.

Let me be clear, this isn't a Bluetooth speaker system. You cannot stream audio from your phone/tablet to the speakers. If you rely on music from streaming sources, this is for you.

Because this isn't a Bluetooth speaker, you can listen to music without a device once you've queued up a playlist. Just press the play button and you're set!

reviews.reviewTitle: Unlike Any Other Including Bose ..... Love the Play 5
reviews.reviewText:
I've had my Play 5 for about 3 weeks. Placed it under my bed. I use the Sonos Controller mobile phone app as my alarm clock and sleep mode as well. Through the Sonos Controller driver app, I can switch, add, and play both TV and Pandora. This speaker is heavy, heavy duty, clear, loud, and simply awesome (your neighbors may hate you if you turn it up).

Whether you pay brand new price or open box price, you will not be disappointed if you want an awesome audio system. Is it better than Bose, or other name brand audio systems? For me, YES, plus the price is right and is available only at certain retailers like Amazon and Best Buy. IS it for everyone? Depends on where you set it up. This along with the PlayBar or PlayBase makes for a killer surround system after you get your 65" or 75" Curved TV (HA!)

reviews.reviewTitle: A Worthy Upgrade to the Original Play:5 If You Care About Sound Quality
reviews.reviewText:
The NEW SONOS Play:5 is superior to the originals, of which I still own 3 of, in ever way. I will start of by saying that I am a sound ENTHUSIAST but not a audiophile by any means. I was bit by the SONOS bug back in 2012 when I picked up 3 of the original 5s to setup wireless music in 3 rooms in my house. I was OK with the sound quality but not super impressed. I play 320k mp3s from my server which sound almost as great as FLAC files. I added the SONOS Sub this summer and the sound improved markedly with deep but tight bass. Yet the mids and highs were a bit "laid back" even after playing with the EQ settings in the SONOS app. The 5s just sounded very good with the sub, but not great. Don't get me wrong. They weren't muddy sounding by any means but the sound lacked a bit of "presence".

I picked up 2 of the new PLAY:5s from my local big box store and the new units were totally a new experience before I even took off the 3 layers of shrink-wrap and plastic bags protecting it! Props to SONOS for the amazing and high quality packaging! You can tell SONOS took a page out of Apple's book when it came to the unboxing experience. But as they say, the proof is in the pudding. The setup was simply enough with just a push of a button on the back of the unit and using either the iOS/Android app or the desktop app to tell your system to look for the new speakers. Both new speakers were found in a minute and the app even asked if I wanted to pair them, which I happily did for my living room along with the Sub for a more immersive stereo experience.

SONOS really hit the ball out of the pack with the new 5. Sonically, the mids and highs stood out as the most improved. Bass was better as well but the open ports in the back are gone now it seems so there's less boominess. I listen to a fair amount of jazz and acoustic guitar and these new speakers were far better in it's ability to clearly and boldly reproduce them as they were recorded in the studio. This might have to do with the additional drivers and the speakers being angled upwards and to the tweeters to the sides as well as forwards. I can clearly hear a wider "soundstage" as the music played whereas my old 5s had a more narrow presentation. The highs were clear and sparkly without being too harsh or bright where you get annoyed. The mids, important for vocals, were fuller. Bass was tighter without the Sub but deeper. But I think the system still sounds best with the sub. I don't know if it's as simple as more and better drivers or if there is a bit of audio processing happening inside the unit but it works and that's all that matters.

I like the new design. I originally thought the black front grills on the white unit, which I purchased, looked out of place. The original white 5 had a white grill. But I have grown to love the new design. It looks like a high quality piece that screams high fidelity. The older unit looked a bit dated now against the new ones. The only thing I missed is the "handle" on the back which allowed me to take it to a new location at will with just one hand.

All in all, the updated PLAY:5 is superior to the originals and I have no regrets with my purchase. I've since moved my older speakers to other rooms and still enjoy them. But the new 5s are front and center in my living room paired with the Sub.

PROS:

+Superior sounding vs old 5 with clearer/cleaner mids and highs; deeper and tighter bass
+Ability to skip tracks with just a swipe of the touch sensitive controls
+Can be positioned vertically or horizontally with touch controls adjusting to the position desired
+Clean and pleasing styling
+Great packaging and protection for unit when bought new

CONS:

-$100 more expensive
-No long has the carry handle in the back of unit
-Deeper design may make it too big for smaller/shallower tables

I guess you could describe me as an audiophile. My current system cost me about 25 KBUCKS and includes Audio Research pre-amp and amp, Mirage speakers (8 speakers in each tower), an 18 inch subwoofer, etc., etc. Two things made me ready for a change: 1) I am ready to simplify and unclutter and 2) My ears ain't what they used to be. Through lots of research and recommendations by the audio store that sold me my current setup some years ago, I landed on Sonos. I am awaiting a 5.1 home theatre setup, but could not resist buying a Sonos 5 while waiting.

It came a couple of hours ago, and I am enjoying the hell out of it. Quick, intuitive setup, great sound and wireless! I love it. Understand that my listening area is a challenge. A voluminous room with 30 foot wooden ceilings. This beauty fills up the room with wonderful sound. As I type this, I am sitting in my home office which is a considerable distance from the speaker and it is clear and concise even through the walls and distance (of course I will now have to get a Play or Play one for in here!). I was amazed at the bass response. I had to immediately play Olympic fanfare which is a knockout piece on my reference setup. Wonderful! With singing, the voices are clear and the highs are crisp and clean. Unfortunately, I can see another one of these in my immediate future to setup a stereo system. I can't wait to see how it sounds when the subwoofer arrives with the 5.1 system.

Sonos, you guys rock!!

reviews.reviewTitle: Sound is amazing! However, it doesn't directly integrate w/ Amazon Echo :(
reviews.reviewText: Sound is amazing! However, it doesn't directly integrate w/ Amazon Echo :( You might want to save your $500 until these integrations are made available. For all I know, Amazon is going to release a speaker that is just as nice as SONOS that works w/ Amazon Echo. If that happens, SONOS will need to release their own voice control system (which means I'll need to by a new speaker assuming it matches Amazon's Echo's AI capabilities) or SONOS won't stand a chance competing in the market.

reviews.reviewTitle: You'll love music again, or even more than before!
reviews.reviewText:
One of the best wireless Hi-Fi speakers available! As a stand-alone speaker, it can already compete with higher end wired/wireless speakers that cost much more.

The sounds is fantastic! After listening to your favorite track on this speaker, you may not want to go back to your old speakers. The sounds is very clean/clear, with beefy bass, and you can hear every little detail that you never heard before! If you want to hear the best quality possible, rip your favorite CD using Apple lossless in iTunes. There will be a significant difference between these and the ones on the iTunes store. (Not all songs, only some)

Once you go past the half way mark on the volume control, this thing gets loud, and at max volume, it can rattle the walls of an entire house. If you are listening directly in the room the bass sounds great, however, if you go the next room or directly above the listening room, you can feel the bass even more, the bass will sounds twice as punchy. Other people are probably thinking that you're crazy! This makes it sound like a bigger system than it really is. That being said, walking into Best Buy, even with it placed in the far back, this speaker was so loud, it was so easy to find. The sound it produced made it sound like a home theater system. And the songs they had on demo, really helped.

The design of the speaker is great! You can place it three ways, just make sure you don't accidentally place it upside down. Otherwise, you may end up with a scratched speaker. That leads me to the finish of the black play 5. The paint on the very top layer seems to be a matte/satin finish. Then underneath that layer, the paint seems to be a shinny finish. Then what looks to be the bottom layer is white paint, the same paint on the Sonos logo on the back of the speaker. The same matte paint and or texture applies for the grill as well.
This leads me to conclude that the more you clean/handle the speakers, that matte/satin finish will fade or become shinny over time. Not sure if it's a good or bad thing. You can compare it to a computer keyboard, where the keys that gets used the most will have a shine to them. The black finish is really nice, it adds a high-end/expensive look to the speaker. The only bad thing is that the black finish leaves a lot of finger prints, especially if your hands aren't clean.

The magic really happens when you create a stereo pair. Stereo separation is fantastic. There, before you lays the stage, and you're in the front row. At 8-11 feet apart, these speakers will play tricks on you. The speakers may be at your left and right,however, you're also hearing instruments and vocals coming directly center of you, but when you open your eyes, there's no one's there, no speaker either! Wow!! Soundstage! And some times it feels as if the bass and music are coming out of the air and then the speakers disappear.
The one song that does this exceptionally well is: The Man In The Long Black Coat by Bob Dylan. You can hear awesome stereo separation,bass,vocal, individual instruments, and best of all, a sound that will draw you in and encompass the entire environment all around you. Wow..didn't know a song can do that to you...speechless.

Also with a stereo pair, everything can get twice as loud which leads to me to believe that people may start to hate you. And for this reason, the addition of a sub may not be necessary. You're just waiting for a knock at your door, telling you to lower down your music! But if you have the need for more bass, go for it! What I heard is that the sub will add more punch to the bass, playing down to 25 hz and also further expand the listening environment or sound stage. Also, the bass itself will no longer be directional instead encompassed all around you. Just keep in mind that at high volumes, your ears will take a beating and listening at max volume will give you the after-effect of a concert. Your ears may be ringing!
