The best thing that the Play 5 did for me was made me fall in love music again, and not with just my old music but with entirely new songs in completely new genres, songs I'd never thought I'd find myself listening to and enjoying over and over again. The Play 5 made me appreciate and love music, the way it was meant to be heard.

Only thing I wish Sonos would support is hi-res (come on already) other than that, this speaker is perfect! One of a kind.

Update 03/28/2016

After three months, these speakers sound better and better. I find that playing them in different rooms made a significant difference. I usually play in the basement so that I can crank up the volume to about 75%, however, at max volume, it gets uncomfortable. I believe that my basement isn't big enough for max volume. You'll need a really big room for max volume (with highest bit rate sample) to sound comfortable. That being said, in different rooms, the same volume will not sound the same. So in the basement, 75% sounds very loud, but in the living room, this will sound extremely loud. The sound will go right through the windows and to your neighbors.

The weather got nice enough for me to use one speaker outside on the patio. I was expecting the sound to dissipate since there's really no walls outside. However, I was completely wrong. One speaker alone filled my entire patio and onwards, all the way to the edge of my yard ( yard is about 15 yrd X 10 yrd). I was not able to set the volume pass 75% for fear that my neighbors would come out and complain. The bass sounds amazing outside, you would think that it would not be able to produce that amount of bass outside. I was able to feel bass on the patio, on the soles of my feet and hiting me directly. The new play 5 sounds great if not better outside just as it does inside. Makes commercial/business outdoors speakers sound terrible in comparison.

First off, I didn't buy my Sonos speakers on Amazon. Even though I buy everything else here. I bought one Play 5 on pcrichard. Another Play 5, and two Play 1's on Apple, as they were offering three months of Apple Music free with each purchase. Thus three separate purchases, and nine months of free music, ( which I was already subscribed to. ) Now, I've long had my eye on Sonos, and these speakers didn't disappoint. Finally pulled the trigger on this expensive system. I hear individuals say they're overrated, ( the same they say about Apple, Bose, etc.. but these are truly well supported companies, that make incredible constructed products. As are these. ) but I'm truly impressed with the separation in the music I'm playing through it. I like that it's WiFi, and can live without it being Bluetooth enabled as well, due to the sound downgrade. I do feel Sonos should loosen the reins a little, and allow more control to the user, rather than everything going through their proprietary software, which is a bit clunky. But I understand this is what most companies want these days, walled gardens. Because I'm sure they're looking for ways to somehow monetize their software. I know there are cons to these speakers, but couldn't ding them for it, as I've done my research, and knew well before hand, what I wasn't getting. I'm not an audiophile, but know what sounds good to me. And this, sounds great! Trueplay tuning is definitely not a gimmick, as I definitely hear a difference in post tuned, as opposed to pre-tuned. I have them in a bookshelf, and they sounded good and loud when I first turned them on, but totally evened out after Trueplay. I know, no Bluetooth, ( don't need it ) had a ton of these speakers, didn't like the sound coming out of any of them, thus Sonos. Hi-Res audio, have it in my car, and am definitely not missing it in my Sonos. AirPlay would be nice, but again, not missing it. You can find flaws in everything, but today's companies are trying to tie us to their complete eco-systems. With all the competition, right or wrong, it's what we have to deal with as consumers. This system does what I need it for, whole house, clear and precise, distortion free, well separated, loud music. They just sound great. I use them everyday. My Apple and Spotify accounts are very happy!

I have two Play5's and a Play1. The Play5 sound in my view is not worth the extra money. Also, I have had trouble with one of my Play5's dropping connection for a few seconds then reconnecting, multiple times per day. As for the other Play5, it just went dead less than 4 years after purchase. Tech support admits it is defective, but wants to charge me $259 for a refurbished replacement. All of these only have a 1 year warranty. Don't risk it, just get a Play1, that's what I am doing to replace my "dead-as-a-door-stop" Play5.

reviews.reviewTitle: ... the whole kit in the trash after becoming completely disgusted by constant laborious updates that made the app ridiculously ...
reviews.reviewText: I just threw the whole kit in the trash after becoming completely disgusted by constant laborious updates that made the app ridiculously difficult to use. Good riddance.

reviews.reviewTitle: Play 5 Gen 1 Bought on Amazon 4 Years Ago - DEAD
reviews.reviewText:
I was an early adopter of Sonos and especially liked the ability to stream Amazon Music to my Sonos. Initially, it was pretty glitchy but as time passed the controllers and firmware became less problematic. Problems like periodically failing to find Sonos network, dropped network connections (it was wired to router) and controller not finding the speaker.
Now I find the Play 5 has stopped working, plug in the head phones to the Play 5 and they work, lights are on just no sound. I've done all the routine trouble shooting as recommended in the community forum. I've ruled out IP problems, etc. I have spent hours on-line researching and it seems this is a common problem with the Play 5 Gen 1. Something in the latest firmware updates or...?
Since it is out of warranty I am out in the cold. At a price point of $500 USD I expected it to last longer than 4 years but alas it's not the reality.
So now I am at a crossroads, buy another Play 5 and see if it will last longer than 4 years or move on to another product. Good news is there is a lot more competition for Sonos than 4 years ago.
Don't think I'll be buying another Sonos any time soon.

reviews.reviewTitle: What amazing sound! Cant believe the way they fill the ...
reviews.reviewText: We have a loft style modern home with exposed walls and ceilings and a huge main living area. No way to wire a built-in sound system. Sonos was suggested by friend. At first I was skeptical and bought only two Sonos Play:5s to try them out. I bought 2 because of the ability to link them together into one stereo unit. Flabbergasted! What amazing sound! Cant believe the way they fill the huge space with such clear, rich sound. I am so impressed I just went back to Amazon and ordered one for every room in the house! Love the controller app and the ease of set up and use. My life is now complete!

The Sonos sounds quality is pretty good, but the customer support varies from poor to fair. Given the cost of the product, that doesn't cut it. The wi-fi system is fragile, and will go off-line frequently. Customer service gives partial answers, says it will get back (but doesn't) and when it does answer, is often condescending and rude. Currently my system only works for the radio- no recorded music will play. When I asked how to resolve this, I got a "you are not doing it right answer" and then some directions that didn't work.

Unless you like spending a lot of time with customer no-service, I advise staying away.

reviews.reviewTitle: Terribly inferior product at a very high price.
reviews.reviewText: Really disappointed in this product. For starters it keeps dropping the WiFi signal. This seems to be a common theme among Play 5 users. Second, I am an avid Spotify user. This device only allows access to a scaled down version of Spotify which severely limits the performance. The sound quality is decent. But honestly, I don’t think I can tell the difference between this and lesser priced but more versatile products. I would not recommend this inferior product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very very good. Bought them second hand
reviews.reviewText:
Don’t know why people are complaining.
This are amazing speakers.
I have 4 play1 and 1 play5.
Love them all.
Very very good sound, easy to conect, just love them
The pay5 is in my living room, 2play1 at sleeping room paired as street ., other at kitchen.
At small room best is 2play 1.
At big room best is 2play5 but if you can’t then 1play5 is better then 2play 1 when the room is big.

reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent sound quality and real support
reviews.reviewText:
I bought the previous generation of the Sonos Play:5 two years ago, and I absolutely love it. I am particular about sound quality, and I like my Play:5 very much. This speaker is controlled by an app you can put on any device. I have it on my laptop, my tablet, and my phone. The app is very easy to use. Possibly the best thing about Sonos is their support. They have live telephone support. I've had to call them twice. Both times, I was quickly connected, and they helped me solve my issues very easily. How many tech companies have that type of support?

I like this speaker so much I bought two Sonos Play:1s. I put one in the bedroom and the other in the kitchen.

reviews.reviewTitle: Much improved sound compared to first gen PLAY:5
reviews.reviewText:
I have an original (gen 1) PLAY:5, a pair of PLAY:1's, a soundbar/subwoofer combination, and now a new gen 2 PLAY:5. The drawback to Sonos components has always been that their sound is mediocre. That's more than made up for by the incredible convenience and flexibility of using the system (assuming you are oriented towards digital music, especially from online sources such as Spotify), but it's always been more than a little annoying.

Happily, the new PLAY:5 sounds much better than the original version. While the original version's sound was just adequate, with an overall muddiness, the new version sounds much tighter, punchier, and clearer. With Sonos, you're paying for the convenience, but now at least you get decent sound too!

I bought from Best Buy because I was unsure if I was going to keep it and didn't want to deal with shipping. There is no way I will return this speaker. I currently own the Play 1 and Play 3 and was looking for something with a line in to connect to my echo dot.
Pros:
-Sound quality is off the charts awesome even compared to the other two sonos speakers I own which both sound great.
-The interface is easy and the app sets up these speakers in minutes with no experience.
-The touch controls on this are intuitive and responsive no matter how the speaker is set up (horizontal or vertical)
-Links to Echo dot with the line in and automatically wakes when sound is detected.
-Fills the room with sound without being too loud (unless you want it to be)
-Wi-fi system is 100% reliable thus far, I've never had a lag or speaker out of sync with the Sonos system to date! (9 months of use)
Cons:
-Line in has a delay when auto-detecting sound and cuts off a second or two of Echo-Dot's response which can be annoying when you are asking a simple question and the response is short
-Price tag is hefty, I am not saying this is not worth the money by any means but to set up your house with Sonos in every room it will get real expensive real fast.

Great speakers BUT if you want to do ANYTHING other than just use the Sonos provided music stations be prepared to do a lot of technical troubleshooting and research. For instance using Audible (no longer supported), playing podcasts (lots of issues since iOS 11.3), Spotify (frequent issues introduced by Spotify, Sonos, or device updates). Etc. they’re great speakers don’t get me wrong when they work. But if you’re not comfortable doing lots of technical troubleshooting (like my wife - and even after awhile me, who is usually pretty patient) you’re going to get frustrated. The Sonos team is hugely helpful, very cheerful and often sincerely apologetic that you can’t get “x” to work now that used to work or that you need to “reset, recycle, get some other device, router, Sonos product” in order to do something seemingly straightforward (e.g. play content from your phone or computer on your expensive speakers) then think twice about going down the Sonos route.

If you want to spend 75% of your time frustrated, trying to get your speaker to work properly (instead of listening to music), than this is the product for you! It constantly cuts songs off in the middle and skips songs. Additionally it suffers major compatibility issues with different music software. The only way to enjoy this speaker is to physically plug it into the 1/8th inch jack (good luck iPhone users).

Note: I would have given this 1 star but the sound is good (but not better than you would expect for $500). I bought mine from Bestbuy (not Amazon) but felt I should alert the world to the limitations of this speaker. Don't buy this product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Far & Away the best Sonos speaker for a price
reviews.reviewText:
The price kept this speaker off my wishlist. I have a couple first generations and play ones. That changed when I happened upon an "open box" deal at Target for about half price. I pounced right away and can tell you this new speaker is amazing no matter what you play. It's so good it makes the first gens sound like treble and bass are out of whack. Using the "Tuning" feature helped tremendously with this.

If money is no object or sound quality is most important, this 2nd gen Play 5 is for you.

I purchased two of the Sonos Play 5 speakers the day they were released and figured I would circle back around and right a review on them. These are by far, hands down, the best portal speaker I have ever heard - Heck, the best speaker I've heard! I have owned quite a few portable speakers in the past with the last one being Kicker which I thought sounded pretty good. The base is amazing and the vocals makes it feel you are right in the middle of the concert. I'm serious, they sound that amazing.

As am sure everyone is aware the Sonos Speakers sit on your Wifi Network. I also have a pair of Sonos Play 1s and all 4 speakers work automagically and in sync on my home network. I have had an issue with the Sonos stop playing music but that is due to my Internet Service Provider.

We listen to our Sonos Play 5s and 1s every day and night and the 5's sound absolutely amazing at very soft or CRANK IT UP volume. I have listened to the 'equivalent' Bose Wifi Speakers and they don't even come close to the sleek design and sound of the Play 5 Speakers so don't even waste your money.

I wish they were Wifi enabled but they were designed to be on WifI. Besides one can purchase a bluetooth adapter to the audio in and easily accomplish this.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not sure it's worth the money
reviews.reviewText:
The souns is excellent. Good highs and lows but the middle is somewhat flat.

But 2 issues. I've had trouble keeping the WiFi working. Sonos support is terrible and keep in mind they are only there mon-fri so good luck if you run into problems on the weekend. I've taken to doing factory resets periodically but this is getting old.

Second issue is you can only connect to paid services. I have premium Spotify but occasionally I like to use other services but I don't have a premium account with those so not an option.

Given the annoyance factor I wonder if Bose, DT or others are a better way to go.

I first heard this speaker in a restaurant in Honolulu. I loved the sound and couldn't believe it was coming out of one speaker! The place was easily 2000 square feet and only one Play5 was being used to fill the entire room. After this, I was set on getting a Play5. I did extensive research and went to all the department stores to compare this speaker to its competitors. Nothing could match the Play5's audio. I then went into researching Sonos itself, and boy what a pleasant surprise​. I saw how much engineering went into their products, and how well they are made. The last Play5 was out for 6 years! 6 Years! So I bought it. Set up took about 10 mins, and this thing sounds incredible. I have a 2000 square foot living room and it fills it so incredibly well. Also looks fantastic. I highly recommend this speaker.

reviews.reviewTitle: Beautiful sound, no Google Home integration, high price
reviews.reviewText:
This speaker is my first Sonos, and I also ordered two Play:1s and I was going to order one more Play:5, but I ended up returning the two Play:1s and canceled my second Play:5. The reason? The Play:1s didn't sound that good at all, and there is no Google Home integration. While the Sonos Play:5 sounds really great, and it can play music from my Google Music All-Access subscription, I can not control the Sonos verbally from my Google Home devices. And now that Google has recently announced the Google Home Max, an upcoming Sonos-like multi-room premium speaker that will have all of the Google Assistant features built-in, I decided to go that route instead of purchasing more Sonos speakers.

I am very happy with the Play:5's sound and features, but I will be holding off on purchasing any more Sonos speakers until I can hear the Google Home Max in person. Unless, of course, Sonos finally makes their speakers compatible with Google Home so I can control them with my voice. My guess is that the Google Home Max speaker will happen first.

reviews.reviewTitle: Poor reliability; unreliable wireless connection; nonexistent support
reviews.reviewText: The sound quality is good - when they work. But they almost never work. Airplay or direct music play via the Sonos app rarely works, both for streaming music or music from my own library. Sometimes music plays for a few seconds then drops out. More frequently, it says it’s playing and no music comes out. These speakers are based on outdated wireless technology. Go elsewhere. Horrendous value. Poor reliability. Sonos support is worthless. They should be held accountable for manufacturing defects.
Absolutely stunning audio quality. I spent several hours researching higher end speakers. The clarity and robust bass is what sealed the deal. Denon HEOS 5 and Bose Touch 30 were runners up.

I have purchased several sonos speakers for my house. I was a fan of the system, but I recently had a play5 fail after about 3 years, and the offer from sonos was to have me pay $347 to replace it. I didn’t do anything to the speaker, it had sat in the same spot since setup and it wasn’t mistreated in any way. I feel like this is a bad deal. To purchase comparatively expensive speaker hardware and then be faced with this type of non-support is disappointing to say the least. I don’t think that is an acceptable service life for a product you purchase at a premium. I would say think seriously before committing to sonos as your audio system, especially now that they offer Alexa integration. I should add that I gave Sonos an opportunity to make be a better offer than this and they declined saying the ‘new speaker is better, so it’s a good deal’ Not to me it isn’t.

reviews.reviewTitle: Now forces you to sign into their website.
reviews.reviewText:
I've had this for years. Now the latest update requires you to sign into their website just to add a speaker. Not having to do that was a key criteria for me previously.

It's a shame, b/c just like GoPro, they introduced this unwanted feature when I was about to buy another.

reviews.reviewTitle: if you like to work, this is a great speaker
reviews.reviewText: Initially, I loved Sonos. The sound quality is great. However, living with it has increasingly become a hassle. It constantly disconnects from Spotify, when you try to reconnect, it won't let you, it decides not to play certain songs, it skips forward if the song or podcast is too long. To circumvent these glitches, you are told to either reset your router or change router settings. These solutions are very temporary patches.

reviews.reviewTitle: Love it! Nothing better than immersing yourself in pure quality sound and music that you love!
reviews.reviewText:
If I had the money this speaker would be in every room I ever travel too. This speaker so versatile and easy to use. Connect it and you immediately feel immersed in crystal clear pure sound! Be careful because it is loud and can bother others in rooms nearby.

Pros-
The looks of this speaker matches its price
Easy to connect to devices and haven't had any issues switching between phones
Sounds AMAZING, matches the quality of the "well respected" brands like BOSE
Connection to wifi was super simple. Just download the APP and you are basically set.

Cons-
The price is the only difficult part to swallow!

I'm not convinced this is any better than a pair of Play 1's... Audio quality is better on the Play 1's IMO. Never think you will be able to pull off lossless wireless playback; it no-worky. Went several rounds with Sonos over that misrepresentation of their product.

Sounds good when it works, but had to hardwire the speaker to the internet because the Sonos wifi was not reliable (laptops/phones work fine on my home wifi). Still periodically does not work. I have been a long time Bose fan and tried Sonos with the hope of setting up a whole house music system as advertised by Sonos. My second Sonos purchase was the soundbar and was a complete fail - dropped sound intermittently for a second or so during movies. This was incrediby annoying, so I returned the soundbar and replaced it with a Bose 123 system at half the cost of the Sonos soundbar. Stay with bluetooth and Bose.

reviews.reviewTitle: OK speaker, but missing critical design features.
reviews.reviewText:
I was really excited about this speaker, but there are several design features that were a real disappointment, so I had to return this.

1) No Bluetooth Capability-This doesn't seem like an issue at first glance, but since you don't have BT with the Sonos 5, you are completely reliant on Wifi or connecting your phone to the speaker with an aux cable. Come on, what is this 2004?

2) You are forced to use Sono's App. to play music-This really annoyed me, might not be an issue to others.

3) To connect to another Wifi network, you must connect the Sonos to the modem via ethernet cable-Yes, you read that right. The Sonos 5 cannot connect to another Wifi network wirelessly. You have to plug it in with the ethernet to connect to a new wifi network. What a terrible design.

reviews.reviewTitle: AirPlay does work if you also have a PlayBar and Apple TV
reviews.reviewText:
Update 12/29/15: A lot of folks have stated that one of their big disappointments was not being able to use AirPlay from their Apple devices. One thing I realized is that if you have a PlayBar hooked up to your TV, then you actually can us AirPlay through your Apple TV. This also resolves any latency issue, since the video and audio are coming from your Apple TV and to your TV/PlayBar, and therefore is the same as when you are streaming HBOGo or Netflix, etc. In other words, if there is any latency when you normally are watching something and using the PlayBar, then you can adjust that in your TV sound settings, and that will also prevent problems throughout your whole home setup. And by the way, if you have stereo paired your Play 5's along with your PlayBar, then you are in for a treat.

I purchased two of these and am very much initially pleased with them as of 12/8/15. Their connection is solid (no issues whatsoever in far apart rooms), sound quality is excellent (especially when integrated with a SUB), and the app works very well (including the playlist functionality which may be accessed or edited by your entire dinner party, family, etc.). It's a great system and worth it. Will provide updates as I continue to use them.

reviews.reviewTitle: great sound, good connection, nice app, beautiful look
reviews.reviewText: Great speakers. The sound is excellent. Looks beautiful. Connects perfectly and easily. Everything is really easy to setup. The app's interface is really nice. I think it may even be better than iTunes. I was really skeptical because audio companies usually don't make the greatest software. It puts out a good amount of bass but I could use a bit more. Maybe I will get the subwoofers too. I had the Peachtree Deepblue2 before this and while the bass was heavier the bluetooth connection wasn't good. The Riva Turbo X is ugly and doesn't produce a sound in the same league as this. Bose SoundTouch 20 also isn't nearly as good as this. When people say Sonos is designed for musical lovers it is really true.

reviews.reviewTitle: unless youre using it in a big room it might be better to buy two play 3's to give it more ...
reviews.reviewText:
Sound is unreal. Bass and lows are sooooo big. I dont know how else to describe it.

I only have one regret, i use it in my bedroom/office, and i seriously will never use it on more than half volume, its so loud. In retrospect, unless youre using it in a big room it might be better to buy two play 3's to give it more of a sterio sound if youre not going to use its full capacity. I mean one on its own already sounds amazing, but if i could have one on both sides of the room it might be a better experience all around. But NO COMPLAINTS. if you have the money to throw around its definitely worth it, no question.

reviews.reviewTitle: Second Gen Play 5 is more amazing, and I already loved 1st gen.
reviews.reviewText:
Second generation Play five is a HUGE improvement over the first generation, and I love the first gen. Huge advantage on second gen is is ability to set the unit on it's side instead of flat. It is a MAJOR improvement. Sound is amazing and feels much stronger than the other Play 5 first gen units I have. I absolutely LOVE this Play 5 Second Gen, I have Sonos units all over my house, they all sync. All fantastic sound.
Cudos to the box designer too, it is absolutely a work of art, and I'm talking the shipping box. Very apple-esque plus some. The only problem I have now is I want to trade in my four first generation Play 5's and get all new Second Gen units.

The all-new Sonos PLAY:5 is the company’s first new speaker (limited editions aside) in two years and it's fabulous. The PLAY:5’s driver count has been upped from five in the old model to six in the refreshed design with six dedicated Class D amplifiers in support. Three tweeters and three mid-woofers are carefully positioned left, right and centre to deliver a surprisingly wide soundstage.

Two built-in microphones have been included in the speaker, which Sonos says will allow the speakers to automatically tune themselves to their surroundings, using the company’s new Trueplay auto-tuning feature. Right now, Trueplay has to use the microphone built into an iPad or iPhone to function, but the company are clearly working on making their smart speakers even smarter. At launch, the integrated microphones are disabled and reserved for future use, but their inclusion reinforces Sonos’ value as a perpetually-improving platform.

There’s no integrated Bluetooth support – but obviously you could connect a suitable third-party adaptor to the PLAY:5’s line-in jack if you were so inclined. The PLAY:5 can be oriented in three ways – like its little brother, the PLAY:3, the PLAY:5 can be positioned in a horizontal or vertical orientation and is smart enough to know which way it’s standing. The new capacitive touch controls work intuitively in each configuration – when positioned horizontally, simply tap the control either side for volume up/down, or use swipe gestures to navigate between tracks. Audio tones help you confirm the commands have been received.

I’ve owned the last generation PLAY:5 for a couple of years now and loved it dearly, but the improvements Sonos have made with this new speaker are pronounced. That said, the difference between the generations varies somewhat depending on the type of music being played. I found heavier, noisier tracks to be more immediate and more enjoyable on this new model, but there’s less of a leap compared to the previous generation (maybe due to the production, who knows?). But the new PLAY:5 really comes into its own with quieter, more reflective tracks where it’s truly a class apart.

Put simply, the new Sonos PLAY:5 sounds deeper, fuller and more resonant than the previous model with a wider soundstage. Side by side, playing the same tracks with the same EQ settings, the new PLAY:5 offers surprisingly more definition. Put simply, the new Sonos PLAY:5 sounds deeper, fuller and more resonant than the previous model with a wider soundstage. Side by side, playing the same tracks with the same EQ settings, the new PLAY:5 offers surprisingly more definition.

reviews.reviewDate: The manufacturer commented on the review below
reviews.reviewText: The setup and music transfer from my Mac Air didn't work. My integration to Amazon Prime Music also didn't work well. I haven't had the time to spend on it to correct whatever is hanging up the porting over of the music.

reviews.reviewTitle: If youre on the fence because of cost like I was
reviews.reviewText: This things absolutely RIPS. Highs, kickdrums and bass are so impressive. We use it for a 3000sqft kickboxing gym that has a 24ft ceiling and it fills it PLENTY. Our landlord came down and asked where the subwoofer and other speakers were placed because he couldnt see them. When he learned that the Play 5 was the only speaker he was shocked. Serious serious power. Looked at the others, Bose, LG, Monster etc. and its not even a race. We have owned it for nearly a year now and it has been flawless. Im still fascinated with this thing.....it just pumps. We use Spotify and have never had an issue...not one. You can crank it to max and it WILL NOT distort. Sonos got it right. If youre on the fence because of cost like I was, this thing will not let you down. Its a beast.

reviews.reviewTitle: Amazing hardware, impressive customer service, looking foward to the future of Sonos.
reviews.reviewText:
I, like other reviewers, took the plunge and am thrilled. Moving into a house with no significant stereo equipment, this single unit transformed the place and in on stroke met all of our audio needs. Not that I will hesitate to get a second Play 5 soon.
There are complaints about the application and integration with Apple Music. The partnership of Sonos and Apple is young. I expect that between the two companies, they will continue to improve the interface. Most of the complaints I see in the amazon reviews stem from connectivity issues that seem to stem from poor wifi networks, not from this product.

I am also deeply impressed by something I am seeing in these reviews. Sonos customer service representatives are responding to every negative review, especially those regarding connectivity. That is very encouraging. I think Sonos is going to lead the market with their products and we can have faith in their longevity and dedication to making a great thing ever better.

Looking forward to Siri voice commands, integrated with Apple Music. I know other systems have some of this in place and working, but with this elegant hardware and partnership with Apple, I think it's going to become a way of life at home. If you have not yet invested in a wireless audio ecosystem, go listen to the Sonos Play 5 (generation 2). They knocked it out of the park.

reviews.reviewTitle: Complete surround sound system! Movie theater quality.
reviews.reviewText: I have the complete Sonos system to include the sound bar, sub, and now the Sonos 5 speakers. I replaced the 3 with the 5 due to my hearing issues. What a difference! I called tech support to help adjust the system properly, and they couldn't have been any happier to help. This is an awesome system! I'm typically a Bose guy, however, after my experience with Sonos I'll never be a Bose customer again.

Simply stunning.

Put a Stereo Pair in our large living room, tuned them and blasted tunes and just smiled.

On par with the best Infinity and Bose speakers that I've owned over the years.

reviews.reviewTitle: High Quality Build & Great Sound. Easy, Quick Setup & Connect.
reviews.reviewText: Elegant packaging. Super simple to startup, setup and connect to wi-fi & music sources. Solidly built attractive appearance. Auditioned Play-3 and Play-5 at home. Play-5 is significantly more expensive and WORTH IT !! Plenty of bass punch. Decided we didn't need sub woofer after listening in our room (two speakers in 1200 Sq ft open plan family section of house). Will utilize primarily for background music (high quality sound without high volume) which will allow conversation when entertaining. Controller app is easy to use. Control speakers individually or group them within app to control all speakers at once from a device or multiple devices. Had one question regarding app, customer service was responsive & competent.

Buyer beware. The speaker is great. Excellent sound. Unfortunately, I get about 1.5 minutes out every song before the thing skips to the next song. It worked very well for several years until the last couple software updates. Downloaded the new software and now I only make it through a song if it's very short (no, no other changes to electronics were made in the house). These are songs that are on my phone sitting 15 feet from the wireless router, so there's no shortage of signal strength. Very frustrating. Sonos website is no help here, as there is no way to reload the old software.

I'll start by saying I actually liked the quality of the speakers, while they worked. However, a couple of months ago, my Sonos 5 speaker stopped working and maintained a continuously blinking white light. Trying to actually find someone to talk to is nearly impossible as their support model is to contact someone in the user community. I finally got ahold of someone whose solution was to plug a cable in and hold down the power button for 30 seconds. Obviously, this didn't work, so he offered to send me a new speaker for $350. At this point, I ended the conversation.
I did some research and found out this was likely due to a firmware update Sonos pushed out. I then sent an email to them, to which they responded they were sorry, but sometimes they have defective speakers. My Sonos 3 also stopped working with the same symptoms. So, now I have two very expensive "disposable" speakers. Please - Do NOT waste your money on Sonos. Bose offers a very similar product and is a much higher quality speaker with much better customer support.

If you are considering Sonos, go for it! I have added Sonos to each room in my home. I have several Play 1's which are great for portability and the small footprint. Also, I have the PLAY 5 and Sonos Connect. I was pleased with the original Play 5 and decided to add the new Play 5. Although I generally use the remote application the updated Play 5 has improved touch controls. It has a robust sound and premium feel. Overall the Sonos ecosystem is amazing. They are constantly adding the latest streaming support and it can easy find and index your music from any computer or networked device in your home. The app is intuitive and does not have a large learning curve. It is great for music at meal time or when you are hosting a get-together. When you add additional Sonos devices (after you buy your first you will inevitably want more) consider adding the Sonos Boost. It connects to your router via ethernet and creates a mesh network for the Sonos devices. No configuration and network setup, just plug it in and follow the steps in app. It can help isolate the Sonos from your other network devices which is helpful if you have a busy network with many connected devices. Sonos has excellent support as well. The Play 5 is the centerpiece in my growing Sonos family.SONOS PLAY:5 - Ultimate Smart Speaker for Streaming Music (Black)

reviews.reviewTitle: The speaker is amazing! Although I thought it was wireless
reviews.reviewText: The speaker is amazing! Although I thought it was wireless, maybe I was alittle naive. It's wireless Bluetooth but required to be plugged in. I was bummed but didn't want to return it

Only okay at first. Loses IP address if you don't play it for a while and it is a pain to re-setup. Biggest issue I have is that after about 5-years, it's obsolete. I could probably call Sonos and have them walk me through a work around (again), but for this type of money, is that really a good value proposition?

This is the most expensive speaker I have ever owned, but it's worth it. After I got my Play 3, I knew more Sonos are coming. It easily fills my entire living room at just a moderate volume. The design is modern and the app is super easy to use. Now I find myself reading and listening to internet radio much more than watching TV, since it's so enjoyable.. One of this speaker alone is not a home theater substitute, though. This is more for music lovers.

These speakers are a headache to own. I think Sonos pushes out software updates about once a week, which takes about a minute to install each time (no auto install, you have to stop listening to music and click through agreement screens to update). I'd be fine just skipping them with the old software, but the system automatically limits functionality if you don't do the software update. So basically you either update constantly when Sonos decides you need to, or you can't fully use the equipment you paid for. Sometimes things should be "dumb" for a reason, this smart equipment is a pain!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Tech and Great Customer Support
reviews.reviewText: I have been a Sonos customer since they first launched and they have continued to just get better and better. I finally had a component die on me and their customer service worked with me to help exactly diagnose the issue and even helped me get a good deal on refurbished unit when mine couldn't be fixed. A company that stands behind a 10 year old component is one I will be a customer for life. I now have Sonos in every room patio and Garage. Yes they are a premium price but this is one of those rare times you truly get what you pay for.

Great sound with the Play 5, but my Stereo Pair constantly gives trouble, with the right speaker often kicking out, especially if any changes are made to the wireless service. Can't believe why pairing two speakers should be so difficult. When working, the music is great.

Updated: Changed the channel on my router, which seems to have fixed the problam.

Very impressed. Have held off for a few years and am pleased that I took the plunge with the new Play:5. Fantastic sound, even without considering the size; when you consider the size, it easily puts this product into the five star category. The setup was seamless. The interface is highly functional. I've run into a few quirks, but considering the array of media platforms they have been able to incorporate is exceptional. Clearly the system is at its best when coupled with other SONOS speakers. I can confidently say that within a year I'll have another Play:5 to pair with my current single Play:5 to create a stereo pair.

Im no audiophile, but these speakers blew me away. At $500, for a single wireless speaker, I was initially a bit skeptical. Once you exprience these speakers, it becomes clear that they are an excellent value. You can tell a huge amount of engineering and thought has been put into this speaker. This speaker is extemely easy to setup and use. You could happily give these speakers to a clueless family member and they could figure it out. I listen to many types of music and podcasts and they all sound excellent. I am particularly impressed by the way the sound travels through a large space. Ive never had speakers that provided such good clarity. The build quality and design are also beyond reproach. I feel very comfortable recommending the Sono's Play:5 to just about anybody.

reviews.reviewTitle: I'd never really heard my favorite songs until I played them on this
reviews.reviewText:
I am thrilled with the Play 5. I plan to use it not only to stream music, but also to serve as a soundbar substitute for my TV. The sound that come out of this thing is fully, crisp and clean. It envelops the entire room. I'd never really heard my favorite songs until I played them on this!

Easy to set up, took only a few minutes, although FYI if you are planning to stream Spotify to your Sonos know that you can't unless you have a premium Spotify account. They don't tell you this, so I figured it's worth mentioning.

reviews.reviewTitle: Music is recreated beautifully, crisp highs and chest shaking lows
reviews.reviewText: I received a new SONOS Play 5 for the holidays and I have to say that this thing rocks. Music is recreated beautifully, crisp highs and chest shaking lows. It's amazing the sound that this thing can produce. The speaker is solid, heavy, and aesthetically pleasing. The speaker was boxed beautifully and you can tell that SONOS put a lot of thought into every aspect of this new speaker. I am very pleased with the purchase as evidenced by my 5 star review. The only hesitation I have, and it's not a big one for me at least, is that I'm not certain that the difference in sound between the Play1 (of which I own 2) and this Play5, is worth $300.00. But again, that doesn't really take away from my enjoyment of the Play5 at all. Basically, if it says SONOS on the front, then in my opinion it's going to sound good whether you're at the entry level Play1 or up at the flagship Play5. It's all good.

reviews.reviewTitle: Sounds good but not significantly better than Play 3
reviews.reviewText: Sounds good. High quality. I have to say, though, I have a pair of play 3s and they sound really good. For the money difference, the Play 3s to do a excellent job and are a better buy.

reviews.reviewTitle: SIMPLY ONE OF THE BEST SPEAKER THERE IS ON THE MARKET for under $1k PERIOD.
reviews.reviewText: I have used a lot of different brand of speaker you name it , I have tried them , from Devialet to much more 100k speakers you name it I have heard them all, but! when it comes to C/P of your money , this SONO PLAYS 5 II can't not be beat within the $2500 range, its simply one of the best choice out there IMHO

Very good sound, perfect syncing of music, and looks great too! First time I heard a Sonos system I was blown away by the sound quality and ease of use, had to buy it for myself. If there is a product that compares in sound and quality I am not aware.

Pros:
Great sound, very powerful, fills room with highs and lows
Easy to set up
Great iPhone app, easy to learn
Works great to play the turntable through the entire house
Does not cut out or skip (did once but resolved by restarting my router)
Every room can be controlled and use separately or together
Used as my alarm clock in the bedroom, very customizable and has never failed me
All you guests will be impressed

Cons-none other than wanting to buy speakers for every room of the house

reviews.reviewTitle: Very good sound, excellent definition even at the highest of ...
reviews.reviewText:
Very good sound, excellent definition even at the highest of volume. This Speaker sounds totally clear, i have it in my room and the sound it's better than everything i had before. Really like it, I enjoy watching whatever i put in my computer with a bluetooth receiver and it sounds very good but if you want more volume with this option you should get an amplifier program for the computer!

Recommended, i will be buying another one when i can to have the pair. I will be connecting a Korg to it and see how good the piano can sound and i will be telling you people!

This is amazing the bass is so good and deep I can't explain how good this speaker is it's a bit pricey but then again whene are you ever gonna buy a good brand and quality for less than 100$ lol you get what you pay so I got just that its a must have!!!band the built in equalizer on the app is grate and you can rase that bass way up... Having the volume only at half way sounds insane already!!!

Two reasons why I am giving this 4 stars:
1. The app will randomly reset and the music will stop playing just when I'm getting into a song and
2. I am disappointed that the line-in feature still only works if you have a wi-fi connection.This "wifi only" feature makes it difficult to travel with.
Otherwise, the sound from this speaker is AMAZING. I am a huge audiophile and was looking for a speaker that had an excellently-balanced sound without paying bigger name brand price. The ability to expand the total speaker network to be as widespread as you want with adding more speakers is a major selling point. You can control any speaker in the house from the app. I also like the ability to have multiple music apps built right in to one single app controller. It IS possible to have more than one person's Spotify or Pandora logged in, it just takes some wiggling to figure out how to do it. I have now had this speaker for almost a year and I am still in love with it. Wifi streaming enables a more direct sound transfer and produces clearer sound when compared to bluetooth streaming.

***Disclaimer: I bought mine from a retail store and not from Amazon. I went searching at a store first so that I could compare sound in person before purchasing and I am a bit wary of spending a good bit for something that I can't test first or that can get damaged while shipping. With that being said, I did just order two Play:1 speakers from Amazon and am anxiously awaiting the moment I get to set them up with the Play:5 for surround sound.

reviews.reviewTitle: New Play 5 Not Worth the Extra Cost
reviews.reviewText:
I have 57 Sonos speakers, bridges, amps, playbars, and subs ... every room in my house and patio has Sonos sound.

So, in my opinion, the updated version of the Play 5 is NOT worth the 25% price increase. My original Play 5's sound better, and we're less expensive. Tried the new Play 5 as a stand along speaker and as a stereo pair, just not worth the extra cost. Get two Play 1's plus a Sonos Sub, and the sound is 10X better for a similar price. Disappointment that Amazon/Sonos would not provide free return shipping - cost $25 to return.

reviews.reviewTitle: SONOS: MAKE THIS SPEAKER BLUETOOTH READY!!!
reviews.reviewText:
THIS SPEAKER NEEDS BLUETOOTH!!!
I get Sonos pushes their own connecting system but still...for $500 I went with Klipsch instead ONLY because the Play 5 lacks bluetooth connectivity whereas Klipsch’s “The Three” streams AND can connect via bluetooth where wifi is not available!

reviews.reviewTitle: The sound quality is great, the software on the other hand is buggy ...
reviews.reviewText: The sound quality is great, the software on the other hand is buggy as all hell -and these speakers WILL NOT run without their software cooperating, nor will they run without a great internet connection. "But wait," you're thinking... "my music is all on a local hardrive, isn't a wifi network enough? why is Sonos constantly using the internet?" Be prepared for a lot of "error 1002," "cannot find your library," "cannot find your speakers" and also for the occasional condescending customer service rep. The solution is always the same "turn everything off and on again." Great, except for the part that requires you to do this weekly and at the most inconvenient times -like when you want to just listen to music.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great speakers, horrific app — and you HAVE to use the app
reviews.reviewText:
Make no mistake, the sound from Sonos systems is excellent. Setup is also a breeze. If either wasn't the case, this would have been a zero-star situation. HOWEVER, the Sonos controller app is complete and utter trash. The UX is straight out of the 90s. It makes me long for WinAmp. Remember that? I've encountered literally more bugs than I can count and after more hours than I can count trying to sort them out, I'm giving up and learning to live with a system that randomly doesn't recognize songs in my music library, routinely "forgets" one of my speakers, erases my song queue when I change my speaker grouping, and whose volume controls basically are meaningless dots on a slider. You will too if you blow hundreds or thousands of dollars on these.

That said, I don't know who offers a better alternative, so there ya go. I wish I'd known this before I bought a bunch of them. I might have applied a little more ingenuity to make my current hi-fi system play in other rooms or at least managed my own expectations a little better.

reviews.reviewTitle: These speakers do not function properly!!!
reviews.reviewText: Ok so the sound is great but it constantly gets disconnected even when I use the line in option for the tv.I have a WiFi range extender for the room I use it in so it doesn’t make any sense that it does this.It is extremely frustrating to say the least.When I’m watching tv I almost rather listen to the crumby factory sound of the tv than have to keep re-opening the app and fiddling around til it re-connects.I am an idiot for buying 2.I thought it was a sure thing because of all the hype and I have heard them before and loved the sound.I would stay clear of this product.

I got a pair of these in black yesterday, having held off for a couple of years, watching the audio market change. First impressions are pretty good, this coming from an admittedly fussy, critical listener. The initial set up got me a little off course, as I tried to pair the two speakers and found the instructions on the iPad app ambiguous. After a little troubleshooting for 10 minutes, it all came together and they produced a wide stereo image!

Having only briefly experienced Sonos at my sister's house, where she has one old Play 5 and a SUB, I really had no idea about adapting to the Sonos ecosystem. It takes a little adjustment, although I have got Pandora and Apple Music going quite well. My wife, who was keen to get a new sound system for music, was baffled at the non conventional set up and the limitations that come with it. I am trying to explain to her what is possible and not. For instance Karaoke will not work with Sonos! I have hooked up the TV to the line input and the sound from the Apple TV is pretty impressive, with a very minimal lip sync delay with the setting set on uncompressed. My son said it sounded like a real movie theater and thought it was much better that our main TV Sound set up, which actually is pretty decent, but seems to lack the crispness and detailed sound, from the pair of Play 5's. Makes me think about getting a Playbar for surround sound. I also have an Airport Express attached to the other line input on the other speaker, which allows me to access anything that can be played on an iPad and iPhone, so Youtube etc. are all available.

The bass from such a smaller speaker is impressive, although my wife asked for more bass, so I slid the bass control up to around 75% to fill it out more, which for me makes it a little thick and muddy. I also have the loudness on which at low volumes helps too. I will be getting the SUB, at a later date, as I am sure it will open up the sound and add even more weight and slam and I can lower the bass setting on the Play 5's. It was the SUB that initially caught my attention in terms of sound quality. I have plenty of experience with lesser subwoofers, that thump and are nearly impossible to make disappear acoustically. The SUB seems to be a very capable subwoofer and is rare, in that it can be placed in a room with great flexibility and blends seamlessly with speakers. It also has a very tuneful musical bass, based on my limited experience with it.

The Trueplay was interesting to set up, although having waved the phone around the room a few times, it said it needed minimal adjustments. Initially, I tried my old iPad 2 and that kept saying there was too much background noise, even though the room was dead quiet. I even turned the fridge off. Maybe it is not compatible. Anyway the iPhone 5 worked fine.

I do find that battery life suffers through the day on my phone and dedicating an iPad as a controller might be the answer. Overall I am impressed at the thoughtful design that has gone into this speaker and ecosystem. With this speaker, I hear a big leap in sound quality, which bodes well for future offerings from Sonos. I am very glad I held off until these were released.

Power board blown after two years. This thing cost so much money, I can’t tell you how much I am disappointed in this company. What a huge waste of money. I will never do business with this company again.

reviews.reviewTitle: SONOS needs an update virtually EVERYTIME I want to use it.
reviews.reviewText: Listening to music is not supposed to be this frustrating. Random shut downs drop music all over the house. Service interruptions that require immediate, urgent updates prevent the products from doing what they're supposed to. Somehow, SONOS has charged me top dollar for a 'user experience' that doesn't seem to be very dependable.

reviews.reviewTitle: but I do appreciate listening to my music over good speakers. I got a Play
reviews.reviewText: I am not an audiophile, but I do appreciate listening to my music over good speakers. I got a Play:5 as a gift some weeks ago, and all I have to say is Wow! This smallish speaker delivers a punch in my three-storeyed house. In the morning, I use the music to wake up my kids on the second floor. The volume does not detract from the quality at all. I am seriously thinking of pairing it with another Play:5 when I win the lottery.

What a great speaker, set up was done on my iphone6 in less than five minutes . Make sure all of your songs on I tunes library are downloaded to the phone or it will not show up on the app. The equilzer settings are ok, bass and treble. Sound at full volume is awesome, great highs and bass is good too, will definitely add another one soon. Another great feature is the tuning to the room or area outdoors to adapt to the surrounding walls and such. Love it!!

reviews.reviewTitle: Sonos is the best invention after iPod/iTunes
reviews.reviewText:
First I started with Play1 and then I can't stop. Sonos App is honestly better than Apple Music App, it's created for music fan for listening to music. Period. It comes with various music services including Spotify, iHeartRadio, MLB, Apple Music, etc.

The new Play5 is the best of all! Beside the cool design (I have the white one), the sound quality is the best compared to all other sonos. Setting up experience is much improved, very easy and exciting! The first time you hear the music stream from your device through the Sonos system is like magic!

reviews.reviewTitle: BEST ALL AROUND STREAMING SPEAKER. PERIOD.
reviews.reviewText:
I agonized over buying the NEW Play 5's (HI-FI, CD quality) OR the BLUESOUND Pulse 2's (HI RES quality). The Play 5 has more dynamic range (even though the Pulse 2 is said to have more fidelity), and it was much cheaper, so I bought a stereo pair.
After many hours of scrutiny, I've decided I love these speakers! The stereo separation is grand, the low end is all the bass most people would ever want, and, when you stream TIDAL or CD quality files, the HI-FI playback is clear and simple as the truth. Norah Jones was on stage in my living room, which is a big room to fill.
The Play 5 is good enough for an entry-level audiophile--if not many audiophiles--for sure. Plus, I went to a nearby Magnolia that demos the Play 5 and Pulse 2. The Pulse 2 came off a bit messy to me; the Play 5 does a better job of showcasing the highs, mids and lows. The Pulse Mini actually had more transparent sound than the Pulse 2, but it is too small.
The Play 5 has the best combination of scale, clarity, affordability, ease of use, streaming service options, power, design, and support of any all-in-one, streaming speaker. I have had a SONOS ecosystem with CONNECTs, PLAY 1's and PLAY 3's for some time, and I'm glad I stuck with them. SONOS is here to stay for quite some time, they will continue to update and support these Play 5's, which makes them future-proof even without the HI RES support. Besides, HI RES vs. HI-FI is not as important as quality amps and speakers versus lesser quality. And the SONOS is good quality--just as good a physical speaker as any other streaming speaker on the market, it plays CD quality superbly, and I look forward to all the great updates to come...

reviews.reviewTitle: incredible sound and performance, but still managed to get mislead and dissatisfied by Sonos.
reviews.reviewText:
This is probably the only Non 5 star review and I'm probably the only dissatisfied customer of Sonos.
We bought a Play 5 in January and use it almost everyday and truely enjoy and love it. I registered with sonos and got their november newsletter about their enhanced new Play 5. so we decided to (finally) add another component, which we discussed for months. Make no mistake... the sound and performance is a solid 5 stars. Seldom do I purchase consumer electronics at full retail price. Sonos is THAT GOOD. The original Sonos is easy to unplug, lift and carry into another room, when necessary, which we do on the weekends, without any difficulty. The new version seems slightly heavier, has a better power cable, but does not have the "handle" on the back, so you need to use two hands to move it. The older version is considerably "more portable" because of this.
the new speaker sounds a bit better than the original. The sound is a bit more crisp and full with slightly better low range.
the volume/on/off button allows to advance to next track and the speaker can be oriented vertically, which is VERY nice for one of our locations. However, about 75% of the time, we're in the same space, and wanted to pair the new P5 to create a stereo pair. This is not possible, which I find disappointing if you want to add speakers over time. Not everyone will splash out 1000 or more dollars for 2 or more "Components". Since it's labelled a "component", we planned to add up to 4 units within a year or two. Nope. Aside from their outstanding performance and great reviews in every form of media, they STILL managed to allow customers to be mislead by building in non compatibility and "hiding it" in their or troubleshooting info that one would normally examine AFTER the purchase. it's amazing that the New Play 5 cannot be paired as a stereo with the previous generation that I purchased in the same calendar year!
I will NOT be ordering a Playbar, pair of Play 1's, and a sub for the home theater.

reviews.reviewTitle: The new app is horrible. Can no longer sort Pandora stations alphabetically
reviews.reviewText:
The new app is horrible. Can no longer sort Pandora stations alphabetically. Can not navigate app. What was a stable and simple system is now just junk. Can no longer control two speakers via the tv remote (using Playbase).

I have multiple Sonos products throughout the house and after spending all this money on the hardware, the software has effectively "bricked" the system. Tried to add a Sonos Sub last week, but now that an account setup is required to track my data, I told dealer to take product back.

just bought them used thank god they work, sound is pretty good for the size and ok for the price I have 2 play 5s I will connect a playbar sub and 2 more 5s for movies (I like bass and good sound) I originally had my eye on b&w towers but I guess this will do I am happy with them

Love the Sonos! Fantastic sound even at max volume. Setting up the app is a process but it walks you through it and was straightforward.

I originally bought the Bose soundmaster 30 but there was static and distortion at higher volume and I packed it up within an hour and bought the Sonos. Best decision I could have made.

reviews.reviewTitle: Just getting the unit to play consistently...It'll play one or two songs and quit.
reviews.reviewText: Frustrating unit. When first installed it seemed to play well. But now it plays one song or so and quits. I've tried installing a wi-fi booster, but it still poops after a song or two. Way too much money for such endless problems. Don't buy it!!

reviews.reviewTitle: Astounding and eye opening experience, worth every penny...
reviews.reviewText:
This is mind blowing experience in the art of sound. After this purchase I get rid of all my "high end" music gear, selling it or giving away to friends and family.
My B&W speakers did not sound much better and I am still wondering how it is possible.
Suddenly I realized that my "old" system which cost me thousands is not really exceptional in the sound quality. It was hard to maintain it and it was always a struggle to try to hide all the cables behind it. Keep it clean and well organized.
The remote was like a computer keyboard with more than twenty buttons and small text prints hard to see and remember its location. Now I have simple app on my tablet and phone and a program on my computers if I want bigger interface.
I think that it means a lot that Sonos brought on legendary producer Giles Martin (son of Beatles producer Sir George Martin) to help tune both the Play:5 and Trueplay so the end result was as close to the speakers you'd find in a studio as possible.
This little device does it is all and some more with a jaw dropping awe.
I used to have more than fifteen wires going in and out of my a/v receiver and now most of that mess is limited to just power line and aux line in. I am planning to add one more speaker to get more stereo separation and resolution but even with this one speaker this is like a magic. Absolutely worth every penny and it is a must buy for any music lover. It streams anything without any problems or pauses. I only wish it could have a headphones output line included like in the old version model and the TruePlay feature is not only provided on Iphones. I do not have one and I think I should have an option to tune it without a "need" to buy or borrow a device I do not have. It should be solved by simply providing a customer with a separate mic as attachment with a long cable you connect to a connector on the back of the speaker for tuning purposes. Something I have had on my old system with the Multi-Channel Acoustic Calibration option.
I have got my enjoyment of music back! Something a system costing many times more was unable to do!
UPDATE:
The addition of the second speaker was a breeze. Very quick and trouble free process with only of exception of indicating to the system which speaker is the left one. As expected the sound field is now much wider and the stereo image is improved as well. Overall I am very satisfied with this second speaker and how this now pair of speakers performs. It is connected to my Samsung Smart TV via the TV's aux line to the right speaker line-in connector. The second speaker do not need to be connected to any source except wireless network and the power supply via the power cord. The TV acts as the switch and it is connected to my PC system via the HDMI cable. The TV serves as HD monitor and I watch movies or play music from a hard drives connected to my home network .The slight delay of the audio at about 70 ms is observed on some of the movies (out of synchronization of audio and video signals) due to conversion process.I think is better to set the audio compression in the advanced settings from the "auto" to the "uncompressed". Then you can try to add a Digital Coax and Optical Toslink to Analog Audio Converter and see how it works for you.

reviews.reviewTitle: customer service is not worth a crap your better off spending your $$ on a high ...
reviews.reviewText: I’m very dissatisfied with Sonos play five. If one spends $700 + for speaker it should be flawless!! customer service is not worth a crap your better off spending your $$ on a high quality Bluetooth!!

reviews.reviewTitle: they’re good speakers when they works
reviews.reviewText: I have two Sonos 5 and two Sones 1 thrrought my house. Overall, they’re good speakers when they works, but sometimes the app can’t find the speakers so you can’t play the music. And it’s VERY hard to figure out how to find them again. I also found the customer service to be very slow and inadequate. I don’t recommend them.

reviews.reviewTitle: Be aware that the wired analog connection needs wifi to work
reviews.reviewText: Absolutely great sounding speaker. And beautifully designed. But be aware that the line in function requires wifi to work. I had purchased this to use in an area of the house that did not get a strong wifi signal, to use as a standalone most of the time but also occasionally as part of our multi-room Sonos system. Was not aware that the analog connection didn't work by itself. Ended up returning the speaker (but with tears in my eyes).

reviews.reviewTitle: No wonder Sonos stock is doing poorly
reviews.reviewText: Doesn’t work unless connected via Ethernet cable to router.

I don't review much, but these are simply amazing. I've heard the top Bose systems, klipsch stadium speakers, Polk audio makes a great speakers, but sonos is premium. Made my buddy sell his 8k system to go into Sonos. Curious what is next with this company; but I'd like to see some outdoor/weatherproof speakers.

reviews.reviewTitle: "Sonos cannot be found on your WiFi"
reviews.reviewText:
After hours of hassle and direct connecting it with an ethernet cable it's back. A week later and it's lost again. Huge time sink, pain in the ass and it all happens without the ability to listen to music.

Expensive product for such buggy software.

I had this Play5 in my cart for a while but hesitant in pulling the trigger since it’s a $499.00 speaker. Walking around Bestbuy, I end up getting one there (I was not planning but bought it anyway). So I “beat the crap out of this speaker” by listening to it every day, all day, with all sort of locations and settings. I have to say: It is a nice speaker with a solid built. Nice and simple design. I bought the white one and it looks amazing. Although the sound quality is good, I didn’t think it was worth the $499.00 price tag. Perhaps my expectations were a little too high, but this is the first time I spent this kind of money on a speaker. My mobile app experience wasn’t the a smoother one either. You have control everything via the app, which can be a little tricky: For example: Since it doesn’t come with a Remote control (which I don’t know why), you have to go in the app in order to turn down the sound. You can’t just pull your phone up and turn the volume up/down. You have to go in the app to do that, which is not very intuitive. The sound is good, not as great as I expected. Again, it is a solid speaker, and perhaps, it will sound amazingly well if you happen to have two speakers, but that is going way too crazy. If price tag was around $349.00 or even $399.00, then it would make more sense. I found it way too expensive for what it offers as a whole.

I have sonos speakers and playbar and playbase in my home. Loved them all until my 14 month old playbase disappeared from the controller making it a useless 700$ brick. Wireless card failed. 1 year warranty = not cool. I now assume from a little research eventually all my even older speakers cards will fail leaving me with 3k worth of black bricks!!

reviews.reviewTitle: Ok if you have money to burn but disappointing.
reviews.reviewText: Disappointing. The sound is fine but not what I’d expect for a single $500 speaker. Sonos in general is a headache. Often it just fails to connect. Or changes songs in the middle of the song. Or pauses for no reason. The mobile app seems to get worse with every release. I would have returned it but waited to long to install it.

reviews.reviewTitle: The sound quality on this is utterly fantastic. Never before have me ears heard such clear ...
reviews.reviewText: Wow. Paired this with an echo after getting frustrated with having to manually power on an old nose sound dock. The sound quality on this is utterly fantastic. Never before have me ears heard such clear and high quality audio. pricey for sure, but well worth it if you even remotely value audio quality.

This unit sounds great indoors but better than most. Streaming music in one room sounds great in another. But when I take it out on the patio it blows me away. Never get the lows or highs out of a speaker outdoors? Problem solved. NOT WEATHER PROOF but this kicks the butt of my Bose patio speakers.

reviews.reviewTitle: ... i need to go to bedt buys and act like i bought it from their
reviews.reviewDate: The manufacturer commented on the review below
reviews.reviewText: Very complex to hook up i need to go to bedt buys and act like i bought it from their. The customer service at Sonas did not know not know how to handle the set up.

reviews.reviewTitle: Sonos. The Sound of Setup Frustration.
reviews.reviewText:
Edit: I was so ready to return this, but it nagged at me. After doing considerably more support than I wanted I found out the problem. My ASUS router has a feature called "Airtime Fairness" that is enabled by default. This feature apparently prevents the SONOS from connecting to devices properly. After turning off this setting on my router the device began behaving properly. I still feel that as a customer I should not have had to go through so much effort to resolve this problem.

The device sounds great and has a lot of cool features, but for $500 I still would have rather it worked right out of the box.

Original Review

I purchased this without checking if it was 2.4 GHZ or 5 GHZ. I figured a $500 device would use that wacky new 5 GHZ frequency. This was not the case. I could survive that disappointment. I could not, however, survive the disappointment of a device that was unable to connect at all to my wireless network. "Unknown Error" it mocked me, time and time again.

I fussed and fiddled and finally, when I thought i had succeeded by plugging in the Network jack, setting it up on my iPad and listening to the device for 10 or 15 minutes my wife came along and was going to add her phone.

"Not Found" it mocked.

Restart. "Not Found" It continued to mock.

I don't need a $500 dollar support albatross in my life. I want to come home and listen to some music, not fight with an expensive device.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does not support bluetooth, air play or any sort of direct device wireless audio input. Must use Sonos app.
reviews.reviewText: Sound quality is good but there is no support to play music wirelessly from a device to the Play 5. You can use the 3.5 mm audio cable to physically add in an external device but you can not use bluetooth or air play to steam music. Funny thing is Bose systems have been able to do this for some time now.

reviews.reviewTitle: Pleasantly surprised by the spectacular sound quality of this one ...
reviews.reviewText: Pleasantly surprised by the spectacular sound quality of this one speaker in my living room. Simple to set up using the Sonos app and an iPhone or Android phone. You can pair it with multiple smartphones (husband and wife, for example) and multiple music services.

reviews.reviewTitle: This is NOT a Bluetooth speaker and difficult to operate.
reviews.reviewText: I hate it. The App sucks. Just make a damn BT speaker. I wish I enjoyed using it because the sound is good, but having to use the App just to turn it on or turn it up/down is a PITA. I end up using an inferior speaker because it just a lot easier. I would not recommend it. No EQ either, just Bass/Treble..

reviews.reviewTitle: Broke after 3 years and won't repair
reviews.reviewText: I purchased a Play 5 about 3.5 years ago and it recently stopped working. (Suddenly played nothing but an extremely loud buzzing sound when connected) I updated, called support, and after walking through everything, I was told they have a newer Play 5 and would not repair mine. The only option he gave me was purchasing a newer Play 5 for $349! Thanks a lot. Now I will never purchase a Sonos product again. I paid a hefty price tag for that speaker and just a few years later it's trash.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good sound but the functionality they advertise that it works ...
reviews.reviewText: Good sound but the functionality they advertise that it works with Spotify Connect just isn't true. You can see the device from Spotify but it usually won't connect. Sometimes it does but you can't count on it. I went with a Sonos over the Bose system for just this feature since I really like the Spotify interface. Now $500 bucks wasted (way way way over priced for the sound quality) and I'm forced to use the very lame Sonos app. I definitely wouldn't recommend this and will take be sending this back. I really hate false advertising and think companies should be held accountable for their product claims.

I am currently on hold with Sonos product support.

It's surprising to me that so many people give this product 5 stars. My own experience has been far from 5 stars, even if I wasn't particularly annoyed right now at my Sonos player (note, i am on the phone with "customer service") I can't imagine giving this more than 4 stars. If you like to stream your music from Apps like Spotify, Deezer, Audible or others than I can't imagine giving this product more than 3 stars. The quality of the sound is good, but it has been the most frustrating and high-maintenance technology purchase I have ever made, especially for a speaker.

My story:
Very excited at the prospect of cable-less music and impressed by the Sonos design online, I purchased a Sonos play 5 online. The initial set up was not too complicated, it was annoying to have to set up 2 devices; the speaker and the BRIDGE. (I understand that SONOS has now gotten rid of the need for the BRIDGE?)

The music quality and the loudness were both very good as well. Soon, however, my feelings began to change as I grew accustomed to some of the annoyances of having a WiFi speaker.

1.Streamed music is frustrating to setup
options for playing your music from Deezer or Spotify or Audible are very sub-par... the connection to your speaker is much more tedious and frustrating than the simple marketing messages suggest it will be.

2. Streamed music is slow
Every time i wanted to change songs or look for a new song it took much longer than i wanted. The Sonos ability for connecting to streamed music has been too slow and it is super frustrating to wait for so many things to load when you just want to find or switch to a new song.

3. No moving it around
You cannot expect to set this up in a new location if you need to move it -- whether to a friend's house for a party or to another room in your own house. Every time you unplug and move the Sonos something goes wrong and I felt like an idiot trying to make my "fancy wireless speaker" perform the most ordinary task... play music.

4. Internet goes out, so does your music
Let's be realistic, your internet probably isn't as reliable as you want it to be... i know that mine has trouble once in a while... so forget about playing any music when your internet is down.

5. No easy Auxiliary Connection
Using the Sonos Controller App is clunky and slow, unfortunately there is no way to avoid it. Almost all of my problems would have been fixed if I could have plugged my iphone into the speaker and just hit play... but Sonos doesn't work like that. PROBABLY THE MOST ANNOYING THING OF ALL.

I think that's enough, I don't want to be any more of a grouch about this. Just know that your experience will not feel like 5 / 5 stars. The main reason I am writing this review is because I suspect there is some funny business going on in this review board with all of these 5 star reviews. I have been on hold with the Sonos helpline for more than 30 minutes since beginning this quest to review my Play 5... that alone should be warning enough.

Amazing product, worth every penny!!! I used it in the back yard and found that it actually sounds better as you stand about 5 to 10 feet away. I went all the way to the end of property line just to check how loud I could blast it before my neighbors would get annoyed, it was about 30 feet away and 5 feet of elevation, I got it to about 80% and it was proper!!!! WOW, love it!!!

Pump it up. Put it loud...really loud as Sonos website suggest...it will not distort, will not make a sound that is not from the song itself. Put it loud! It will hit you in the chest, with extreme accuracy. The difference with the former 5 is huge. The bass is really present but middles and tweets complement perfectly. My walls literally trembled. So beautifully designed. Really happy, looking forward to buy the couple.

reviews.reviewTitle: Simply the BEST and EASIEST way to do wireless audio
reviews.reviewText: Huge fan of Sonos, and the Play:5 is the best of the bunch, by far. ... If you're serious about good, EASY wireless music, this is what you want.

reviews.reviewTitle: Chose Sonos over Bose After Lots of Experimenting
reviews.reviewText:
I moved from two inexpensive receivers (one with a 5-disc changer!) to the Sonos system, but not before a lot of research comparing Sonos and Bose SoundTouch. Here's what I learned: The Bose system attracted me given the Bose name, and I liked that all three sizes of the Soundtouch have line in/bluetooth (I want to play AirPlay via an Apple Express), etc. And I very much liked the 6 preset buttons on each speaker: having to look for one's phone to start or change the music is a challenge when the phone is on another floor or charging, etc.

But the Sonos system is well respected and has much to offer, so I bought both: one Sonos Play 5 and a SoundTouch 10 and a SoundtTouch 20 (expecting to take the Sono's back). Then I compared experientially. After a few days, the decision was clear: go with Sonos.

First: the application for Sonos is way better: it's much easier to group rooms and switch between them, to choose music, and to organize one's music options. The Bose app is much less well-developed: it is clunky and limited and frustrating. The Sonos app allows one to set alarms to one speaker, or more, with choice of music stations. Such advantages offered by Sonos software outweighed the preset options supplied by Bose. (One can adjust volume and start/stop music on all the Sono's speakers, just no switching between stations).

Second, I wanted to be able to play via Apple Airplay, and Bose only does this one speaker at a time. To do so for a group of speakers in Bose, things are more complicated and less reliable. Airplay is actually well supported on Sonos if you have the Play5, for it has a line in (as do the Connects). Once you attach an Airport Express to the line-in for Sonos, you can play all the speakers in your system via Airplay (you can even name the Airport Express "Sonos" or like), grouped or individually. Good directions for such are given on the Sonos site.

Further: there seemed to be drops in connection with Bose that I don't experience with the Sonos. I also realized that with wireless connection I'd seldom use the line in or bluetooth on the Bose speakers. And, being Apple oriented, I sense that AppleMusic (now in beta on Sonos) will be more likely to work well Sonos (Bose seems to be in conflict with Apple, and has dropped Airplay).

So, I returned the Bose speakers, and bought two Play 1's to add to the Play 5. The build of the Play 1's seem to be of much higher quality than the Bose Soundtouch 10.
