The sound is great! And I use the system all the time (a large advantage compared to more complex receivers).

I'll list the only positive first. It sounds great. Now for the (lengthy) downside. NO BLUETOOTH CONNECTIVITY! It is necessary to use the Sonos app to play anything (not necessary if it had bluetooth). It is VERY picky about wifi connection and router. I'm operating 4 plus other devices on my network with no issue, but Sonos doesn't like it. After playing a few songs, it started to randomly skip to the next song; sometimes a minute into the song/sometimes a few seconds. Sonos says feel free to contact them with any questions. What they don't tell you is that there is usually and hour plus waiting time to speak with anyone. I contacted them via email and received 3 or 4 replies from different techs. None of which were able to resolve the problem. Judging from their online forum, this is a common problem that they apparently don't have a fix for. Returned it yesterday. Think I'll give google Max a try. A hundred bucks less and has bluetooth.

This is the best speaker I have heard in all my life, it's just amazing. I proved in a store and It was amazing, the best sound I have heard. I wanted to buy but lamentably it is so expensive. I you are looking for a good spekear with quality, this would be the best choice you will do. I recommend 100%, if you don't believe, go to a store and prove it. You will not regret.

reviews.reviewTitle: Anything that depends on wifi connectivity is risky
reviews.reviewText:
If you LOVE troubleshooting why Sonos cannot find the music on your pc EVERY time you press play, by all means buy this thing.

I think they've found a great niche audience -- people who hate music and don't want to risk ever hearing it but want to get rid of $500. So yeah.
Buy this.
If that's you.

reviews.reviewTitle: Pay lots of money for headaches.
reviews.reviewText: Great sound. Terrible APP. Why can't I just play my own music straight from iTunes where it is all organized and easy to browse. Nope. Have to index it all and export the index to the Sonos App. God forbid you are over the catalog size limit. Sonos app is terrible. Searching for a song but then have to go back a screen to adjust the play volume? Now you have lost your place in the search. Found the soung you were looking for? Great now I'll queue up a bunch of related songs you don't really want to hear, and you can try to delete them and find more music at the same time. Oops sorry! WiFi interference mystery from the router 2 feet away! System not found!
DO NOT BUY! No longer supports ITunes!

reviews.reviewTitle: Your Sonos will eventually stop working, you can't play free podcasts, and you are subject to their App
reviews.reviewText:
Sonos as a company is complete garbage. Their goal as a company is to force their customers into the exact products and services they want to sell and use, period. Here is what you need to know about the play 5:

*You cannot stream via blu tooth and are forced to use their software/app. This means many of your streaming apps will not work, and you have to take extra steps to access the music you can play. You will also have to update the software constantly and the device will eventually stop working (see below). For the same price you can purchase a far superior set of speakers, receiver, and blu tooth streaming device that will give you many more options than using Sonos. This is what I ended up doing and now I can play any app I want, off the same great system that I use for my vinyl and cd's.

*Historically their software never allowed access to playing any podcasts (remember...you cannot simply use your current podcast app as you have to use whatever they choose to let you use. They get paid from the companies that are represented in their software, so it's likely your favorite app is not available). They now offer one music service within their app that can play podcasts, but it is a subscription based service that you must pay for separately

*Speaking of software updates, be prepared to update software ALL THE TIME. Constantly. It is so frustrating to the point where we eventually stopped using Sonos because it was so much faster to hook up to my additional blu-tooth / shelf speaker system

*This company has designed all of their language and marketing, to tell you why you need multiple devices to get the most out of their offerings. They are concerned will selling products and making licensing agreements with the apps that they choose to give access to. Sound and music is an afterthought.

*Eventually the Play-5 stopped working all together on my MAC, and is now a paperweight. They updated it to the point where it is no longer compatible with my device. This will eventually happen to you too unless you continue to purchase new devices to support the speaker.

Be forewarned and know what you are getting into. The only positive I can say, is that if you are fine accessing music you've downloaded to your device via their software, and you accept the fact the device has a 2-5 year lifespan, the sound is a solid 6 out of 10 and will suffice your needs.

reviews.reviewTitle: I paired this with the PLAYBAR for the surround sound ...
reviews.reviewText: I paired two of these with the PLAYBAR for the surround sound... oh my goodness.... I ain't leaving this room any time soon LOL

Just got my PLAY:5 so these are just my initial thoughts.

SETUP: easy. Download the app, find the device, press a button on the device. Done.

APP: not bad. I downloaded the Sonos controller on my android tablet and also my iOS phone. Both are good and you basically log into your account so it is the same no matter what device. Even when you setup your music source, it is all shared, ie. Pandora, Amazon Music, etc. I have a very old android tablet and that is my dedicated Sonos display. I still need to find out how to get it to play music off my home server.

SOUND QUALITY: excellent. Really for what it is, an modern day boom box, it is awesome. Have not tried the sound tuning yet. Not since the days of the Squeezebox have I seen so well-connected a product that also sounds great.
The sound is as good as it gets. Love the smarts of the Sonos system as a whole.

You know you've just purchased a kick-butt speaker when it even makes low bitrate Pandora sound excellent!!
Setup was a bit cumbersome due to me having to change some network settings, but it was a one time thing.
Worth every penny. That is all.

Amazing! Love my Sonos System, which includes two Play 5 speakers, a sound bar, two Play 2, and a sub woofer. The quality of the sound of the amazing Play 5 is the same whether it is turned down low or functioning at a higher volume!

Great speaker! the sound quality that this size speaker puts out is great, much better than a BOSE. Doesn't take up too much space and looks sleek. Definitely worth the price if you like to listen to music regularly.
Why couldn't you make this speaker bluetooth?!? If it was bluetooth or at least have that option I would give it 5 stars

Compared to my trusted speakers from the 90ies driven by the Nakamichi (from the 90ies too), this is Boom-Box quality. I bought 2 of those, and the legs, so for $1300 I got $200 worth of stereo quality.
Love this product. I bought it from a competitor since I had a gift card. The customer service has been very helpful.
The sound is amazing. Literally the only thing it lacks is Bluetooth connectivity but who uses that lossy connection these days anyway?

reviews.reviewTitle: Best money I’ve ever spent on a speaker
reviews.reviewText: Best money I ever spent on a speaker. Sounds amazing! If you are considering 2 play 3’s vs 1 play 5 go with the play 5. It sounds better than 14 play 3’s

The sound on this speaker is fine, BUT it drops songs every time it's used... which means the music will suddenly stop playing, frequently, and then you have to turn it back on from the command device you're using (in this case, my iPad which is in another room). For a company whose one trick pony is wireless music delivery, this “bug" is unacceptable and if I hadn't spent a thousand dollars on this speaker plus two of the smaller ones, I'd return them. If you're considering buying these, I'd say absolutely not. The annoyance of having your music cut out constantly totally outweighs the quality of the sound delivery.
this boy is LOUD. Cranked it up when nobody was home and you could hear it all the way outside. Love it.

reviews.reviewTitle: They used the update to make the system worse instead of making it better
reviews.reviewText: Sonos is operated by various controllers including apps that you can download on an iPod. They recently released a software update and deactivated the controller that I was using. They used the update to make the system worse instead of making it better. Their customer service personnel were unhelpful, but their community forum offered advice to use a 3rd party app that solved my problem.

reviews.reviewTitle: Gen 1 to Gen 2 upgrade, worth it!
reviews.reviewText:
I had two first gen play 5's and a fairly complete Sonos system in my house. When the new play 5 came out I figured I'd pass on it.

Well, I read some reviews and finally listened to the gen 2 at Best Buy. I think the gen 1 sounds great. This is better. Yes the $100 difference is worth it to me. I sold one of my gen 1's for a fairly good price ($360, figure I had it since 2011 so losing $40 on it, not bad). I bought the gen 2 and put it in it's place. What a difference!

If you're in the same situation, go for it - you'll be glad you did! Just waiting to sell my other gen 1 now ;)
Apple Music (currently in Beta) works great!!! Bass response is really incredible. Crystal clear. I only bought one of these, but it sounds so great, I'm ready to buy a second one to pair it with.

reviews.reviewTitle: Do not the same mistake that we did.
reviews.reviewText:
The most expensive speakers that we ever spent money and the worst one.

At first, its sound was so good and we thought I did the right decision buying it.

However, just two years after that, it started " un-connecting" itself for the software and the system.

So It forced me to "reconnect" it back into the software and the system.

One or twice was fine with me but if you have to "reconnect" your speakers with your computer and system, it became unusable. After all, I own other wireless devices around my house and It never asks me to keep "reconnecting" them to the system everytime that I want to use it.

My last straw was yesterday when we spent 2 hours successfully " reconnecting" it back with it system but after one hour, we stepped away and tried to play it again. It asked us to reconnect it again and this time, it never found itself back to its system!

Do not the same mistake that we did. Buy other wireless speakers. We also own Sony wireless speakers which's older than this one and it never asked us to reconnect it to its system at all.
My Whole house is wired. I have hosted 3 parties without a need for a DJ. " Best System" by far.... great job!!!!!!!

Purchased a 1,3 and 5 and amp. Total waste. 5 has decent sound, but is the only one with any sort of auxiliary in. They don't sync together like they are supposed to. Turn on at random, and cost 1500 for my set up. Trying to sell them on Craig's list now. Save your money as there are a ton of other superior options out there. Sonos controls the price of these
speakers. Very overpriced for what they are.

Update- just sold them all and purchased another system. Best decision ever. Can believe people pay for these.
Super simple to set up and sync to my other sonos speakers, unbelievable sound projection, clarity, and quality along with an impressive sound range.

reviews.reviewTitle: The blue tooth connectivity isn't great for the house I was in
reviews.reviewText: The blue tooth connectivity isn't great for the house I was in. Sound is amazing but tech is okay.

reviews.reviewTitle: Already this is one of the greatest devices I have ever owned.
reviews.reviewText: I have had this for about a week now and my sentiment remains the same. Most incredible group of high end products out there. They just work and they do it WELL. I own at least one of each of all of the other Sonos components, I have never been let down by a Sonos product yet. Sure it's expensive but with Sonos you really do get what you pay for. I don't say that about many high end products. This one looks great and is all about the prestige and design as well as being functional as can be. I can't ask for anything more to be honest.

reviews.reviewTitle: nice product but software gets old fast
reviews.reviewText:
The sound is quite nice, really high end, quality speaker. Everything sounds great on it.

My problem, however, is that while the hardware is great, the software is not. It feels outdated, somewhat clunky, and if you want to listen to, say, music on youtube, you can't do that without an audio in. it has some obvious qualities, but i feel sonos needs to put a lot more work into the software side, because it just isn't cutting it.

With a legacy, wired theater system, I thought there would be an easy connection between Sonos streaming and my older devices based on their advertisements and press releases. You know what they say about ASSuME!!
When I contacted Sonos customer support, they were fairly dismissive saying that what I now really needed was another $350 Connect device to integrate the systems. This is in the same era when $35 buys a Chomecast video link from your computer to your TV. This is no longer rocket science, but it seems that it is not in the best interests of Sonos to integrate with legacy, wired systems.
I am very disappointed and may return the Sonos Play:5 for falling far short of it's hype.
Be sure that this unit meets your needs before you buy - if it's out of their customer support window, you're toast.
Does anyone know of a software hack that would allow an iPod, Windows Laptop, or other device to broadcast the same audio signal from its audio (headphone) jack at the same time as the Sonos App was sending? That would be worth a lot - but presumably less than the $350 Connect device. Marketing opportunity here.
Bass distortion. Returned for two play 1s

I have a Play 5 + 2 Play 3s + bridge. They worked fine for awhile. Then I started to have problems. Currently, they work lovely for about 40-60 min, then stop working. I have worked on the system for many hours trying to troubleshoot. Numerous calls to customer support. Even when I submit diagnositics, CS has no idea what the problem is (except they keep blaming my router, which is fine for every other application I use it for). Unfortunately, I now have about $1300 of worthless equipment and my wife is back to carrying her boombox around the house.

reviews.reviewTitle: they are great. But they are great for the SAME reason ...
reviews.reviewText:
Straight to the point.

If you have 3+ of these, they are great. But they are great for the SAME reason that I gave them a 2/5... The app... Sonos makes it so that you can have an entire house, in sync with great music... All thanks to its WIFI connection and its very in depth app... But that's about it.. Why 2 stars? Simple.

For the REST of us, that just want a plug and play option, this isn't for you. Period.. Plug and play for sonos means

1-open iPhone app (if u don't have wifi plug into aux cord, more bout that later)
2-Go to my music
3-click on a song
4-click play now... Or, 5 different options
5-enjoy song.

5 STEPS JUST TO LISTEN to a song. You can just plug and play. You need to specify when you want the song, what que, do u want to replace the que. ECT..

AUX cord?

1-plug in device
2-open sonos app
3-click input
4-click aux
5-leace app running in the back or else it shuts off.

SO you CANT close the application, you HAVE to keep it open..

WHY DIDN'T THEY JUST INCLUDE A SIMPLE $5 BLUETOOTH ANTENNA!?. The most basic function of ANY speaker.

Now to the App.

1- NEEDS TO BE RUNNING, period. Sonos won't work unless the application is up and running in the back.
2- YOU CANT set your music to be an alarm. Music from your phone that is. WHY THE HELL can't you use your own music!? You have to import it, and that alone is so complicated I stopped. So you have music on your phone, the speaker PLAYS music from your phone, but you CANT set a song to be the wakeup music..
3- The application runs no matter what. Yo are blasting music and get a phone call, you need to answer, then go into the app, wait for it load, then pause or lower the volume.
4- Unless you are in the app, you can't control the music
5- you set rules on the songs via iTunes such as, start and stop markers.. Sonos decided to not count those in. So a 5 minute song that you have it to end at 3 minutes? Enjoy listening to the entire song. Sonos doesn't recognize the stop marker.

Lastly,

they tried so hard in making such a great in depth application that they failed. So many freaking options just to play songs. add to que, replace que, play next, shuffle que.. Millions of options and not just play and go..

FINAL NOTE:

WHY THE HELL DOES A $500 SPEAKER NOT HAVE THE MOST BASIC FUNCTIONS SUCH AS BLUETOOTH.

1-turn on Bluetooth on your phone
2-connect to Sonos
3-play music from your phone

PERIOD! Set an alarm on your phone, it plays on the sonos. Take a call for s*** sake form your Sonos..
Don't forget, the app NEEDS to be running for ANYTHING to work. EVEN an iPad connected to it via AUX cord. And don't get me started on having more than 1 device controlling the speaker.

DONE purchase this. Period.

Bought two Play 5's directly from Sonos and have been testing them out for over a week now.

First the good —to my knowledge —there isn't better multi-room home audio setup out there, not at this price point. But if you're reading this you probably already knew that. Setup is fast and easy, you can join / separate "rooms" on the fly and guests can add songs seamlessly (once they know how to use the controller app).

But here's what you need to know about the revamped Play 5 — the audio quality just isn't that great, not for $500 / speaker. The new Play 5 sounds airy, flat and lacks definition throughout. I'm disappointed because it's been 6 years since the Play 5 (named the ZonePlayer S5 in 2009) first launched and while the 2015 update improves audio quality it doesn't compare to wireless offerings from B&W. Are my standards high? Absolutely. But so are Sonos's.

I really wanted to like the Play 5’s, for most listeners it will be a great addition to a Sonos household (most people who buy Sonos already own at least 1 speaker). Today many people are perfectly happy with compressed audio and disposable ear buds – the Play 5 reinforces this trend. It comes down to a tradeoff do you need multi-room home audio? If so, you’ll probably be better off with Sonos if you don’t mind sacrificing audio quality. If audio quality is higher up on your list look elsewhere – B&W is a great place to start, or ditch wireless all together.

reviews.reviewTitle: Deepblue 2 is a better sounding and more flexible speaker.
reviews.reviewText:
I compared the Play 5 with the Deepblue2 bluetooth speaker which is widely considered the best bluetooth speaker. I would recommend the Deepblue2 instead.
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00THKVQDO?keywords=deepblue2&qid=1452534673&ref_=sr_1_1&sr=8-1
and see the Wirecutter review
http://thewirecutter.com/reviews/best-home-bluetooth-speaker/
The Deepblue2 sounds better with better bass and far more controls over your music playback. It also has more connectors with both an RCA and optical port. The optical port is handy for attaching an Apple TV or Airport Extreme so you can also use Airplay with this speaker. However the bluetooth connection sounds really good too and I have never been a big fan of bluetooth instead of Airplay. The Deepblue2 is also $100 cheaper.
The Sonos app is clunky and does not fully support all features of all streaming services. I pay for Spotify, Pandora, and Apple Music by the way.
Also the other parts of the Sonos lineup are silly overpriced with limited functionality especially the ridiculous Playbar which only has one optical port and an inability to do 5.1, DTS, or anything recent. Sonos is milking their existing lineup for all its worth.

reviews.reviewTitle: No carrier than no Sonos Play 5.
reviews.reviewText:
Had to return mine as I do not have a carrier but a excellent wifi set up. Went to ebay to my fellow techie and he told me I must have a carrier v for this speaker to work. I feel it's priced a bit high, could be lower as it has its limitations.
Also trying to register this device was difficult at best and trying to hook it up to another system was nearly impossible, even though I was told I could do it. I brought in professionals and they could not do it either, all I said was no , No Sonas. So it's a great concept but it's still not completely where it should be. Perhaps next year I'll try it again and maybe things will be different.
Everything sounds different on this speaker....

reviews.reviewTitle: With Great Sound Came Great Frustration
reviews.reviewText: I bought a gen1 SONOS play 5 and love the sound. But -after changing my WI-FI router and trying to reconnect the SONOS, I do not recommend this product. It appears the manufacturer neglected the earlier model and the instructions to link the system to your WI-FI are for the gen2 or newer models. I also have a BOSE and pairing it to my new router was a snap. Based on my experience, I will not buy SONOS again!

I had a good couple of weeks with my Sonos, although I have to say, I wasn't sure if the sound from my three Sonos Play:5 speakers was quite what it should be. Not quite as good as I expected. However, after either an iOS update or my update to the Beta Apple Music on my Sonos, the system stopped being operational. I can usually fix my tech problems after research on the internet, but three hours of running around the house and trying to reset the system, even going to the trouble of going back to factory settings, it still wasn't working properly. One speaker would work, and then as soon as another speaker would start working the first speaker dropped out. Very frustrating. I have to say from what I have ascertained in my research, software updates are the Achilles heel of Sonos and can cause all sorts of problems. Luckily, I was still within the return period at Best Buy, and they now have my Sonos system. I might try again someday, but more likely I will look into other options. Not interested in having $1500 bookends which don't play music. I don't need this aggravation with every update. Too bad.
It's rather disappointing. I have multiple Play 1's and the performance is not much better despite the $300 price difference. It's also huge and hard to find a place it doesn't take up visual space.

reviews.reviewTitle: Can't music thru wifi w/o subscription
reviews.reviewText: I find it frustrating that I can't just send music on my iPhone through my wifi to the speakers. To use wifi, the music has to come through one of the subscribed services?! I wish I had studied how Sonos' subscription requirement work before I bought it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not a reliable system to get music or radio when you need it
reviews.reviewText: This is a review for the entire sonos system. I have several components having purchased them over the years - a play one, play 3, play 5, and a TV Bar. I also have the subwoofer. Until this last 6 months, the system has generally been great. Easy to use and reliable connection. But in the last year the reliability has steadily declined. I have to reset the system at least 3 times a week, which is very time consuming and usually doesn't work. A call to the support call center can mean a 30 - 60 minute wait. They prefer to talk to the community to diagnose your network issues. Now that there are so many great bluetooth speakers with great sound quality, I would recommend checking those out first. This system is a complete hassle now. And, the new improvements to the interface actually made it less easy and more difficult to get to different features.

reviews.reviewTitle: Poor value and frustrating to use.
reviews.reviewText: The sound is good, but this product is so much more expensive than competing products and does so much less, it just isn't worth it. The few times I've used it I've had to reset my entire network. Unreliable, inflexible, and over-priced.
I don't write many reviews, but I had to just say the sound is amazing! Needs more apps for the Sonos Controller.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not a good sound system if you think you should use it ...
reviews.reviewText: Not a good sound system if you think you should use it for a varied of sources. It takes over your iTunes music list, you can't play anything that it doesn't control. No YouTube, no music from other sources, no family video, no calls or messages. Nothing but what Sonos puts into its hijacking player. Don't buy. I can't return the Sonos because in addition it has a short time frame for returns.

reviews.reviewTitle: Physical hardware is good. Software is horrible
reviews.reviewText: Physical hardware is good. Software is horrible. This applies to all Sonos products. They do not seem to ever want to address the issues. You will be trapped in their eco system. I own 7 different Sonos speakers. And I regret them all now.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great speaker but horrible Sonos App
reviews.reviewText: Great speaker but horrible Sonos App. Difficult to set up. Updates all the time and erases all your settings. Find something else before you have to deal with this frustrating product

I have been an enthusiastic Sonos user for years.

I was excited to try the Play:5 given the backstory. I ended up returning it.

The company clearly invested a lot of thought and resources into developing the Play:5. In listening over the course of a week, I found that the bass range was uncannily punchy, the soundstage was vivid and pleasant; yet the high range sounded exaggerated, hyperreal--as if revealing the cold intelligence underlying the Play:5.

In an earlier era of hi-fi, the ideal was to reproduce audio faithfully with minimal processing. The Play:5 is a clear break from that tradition, and it's an impressive effort. Nevertheless -- and let me make an important qualification: I am commenting not on the Play:5, but on *my experience of music played through the Play:5* -- I came to feel it was a fine engineering achievement that does not necessarily bring me any closer to the music. Indeed, because the high-end response is so creepily real, it reveals the amount of sound processing happening, and I found myself wanting the Play:5 to simply chill out and let the music be great. I found myself wanting to suggest that Sonos embed musicians with the engineering teams.

reviews.reviewTitle: Sound is great, Spotify integration is not
reviews.reviewText:
I own two of the previous model of this speaker, and I love the sound, particularly given the amount of real estate the speakers occupy. The new Play:5s, which I listened to in a showroom yesterday, sound even better. I doubt that anyone will be disappointed in the sound of these speakers.

The rest of this review will only apply to people who create your own Spotify playlists, who have more than a few of these playlists, and for whom these playlists are a central element of your streaming music experience. I'm learning that this probably represents a small percentage of Sonos listeners. If however you are part of this minority, then this information will be important to you. If you don't use Spotify in this way, the following review will be completely irrelevant to you. So please don't waste your time reading it, or your "unhelpful" vote: I'm saying in advance that I know that this review will be unhelpful to you. Thanks for your consideration.

I listen to classical music on Spotify, and so I have hundreds of classical playlists (each representing a classical "album") and a dozen or so playlists of other kinds of music. These playlists are arranged in folders, making it easy to find my playlists. I can also search my playlists within the Spotify desktop and iPhone apps.

In the Sonos app, my Spotify playlists are presented to me in an unusable, seemingly random order. I have no option to reorder my playlists (alphabetically, by composer, by type, whatever). I furthermore have no option to search my playlists (the search function searches all of Spotify, not just my playlists). The result is that I can't find my playlists unless I scan the list and am very lucky to happen to see it while doing so.

I've stopped using Spotify on my Sonos equipment altogether, it's just not usable given how I organize my music. I do use Spotify in other contexts though, so I don't plan to cancel my account.
Great sound, easy to use.

This is a terrible product. It sounds great but is it's a nightmare to use. Unless you are a streaming service junkie you should probably invest in a simple bluetooth speaker by Bose (or another company but Bose hasn't let me down yet). The Sonos only works through a proprietary app, Audiobooks simply don't work and Podcasts are so difficult to deal with it's just not worth the trouble. In addition, music doesn't pause when your phone rings. I works at home and I just want to listen to podcasts and radio and audiobooks without going deaf from using headphones 24/7. It would be nice to play music from my phone and be able to pause music when a call comes in so client's don't have to hear 2 bars of "Raining Blood" before I can pause it. This is a classic piece of over-engineered crap by a company that's worrying about tomorrows applications instead of today's basic needs. You can't even plug a jack into it, it HAS to go through the wifi or bluetooth and only through it's proprietary app. I know this is a rant, and I'm sure some people love it as much as my family does, but I don't see the selling point.

Absolute garbage. The largest of their speakers can't even handle the bass from an RB song. The speakers are less than 10' from the wifi, and it's CONSTANTLY buffering and unable to connect. I honestly don't understand the high ratings.. even the sound quality is crap. A WASTE OF MONEY.

I bought two 5s. They cost $500 each. I spend my time on SONOS forums trying to figure out why one keeps not working. Very frustrating for such an expensive product. I would like my money back and would not recommend this product to anyone.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great concept but waste of money.
reviews.reviewText:
Only works from my phone (a new phone this year) about half the time. Always says can't find Sonos system even when sitting on top of my Google fiber router. Having to turn your phone off multiple times to get your $500+ speakers to work just isn't worth it. I end up listening on my phone over have the time because it is not worth the frustration.

We bought this Play:5 and the smaller cans, but not much use when the controller (i.e. iPhone app) only works randomly.

Great concept but waste of money.

reviews.reviewTitle: At around five hundred price tag, it under-delivers.
reviews.reviewText:
I am truly surprised to see how the reviews on here overlook the lack of Bluetooth and wireless feature. At around five hundred price tag, it under-delivers. Sound is good but nothing exceptional at this price point.

- Unlike most of the Bluetooth speakers, this is not really wireless. It requires power cable connected. It is W-Fi only or wired AUX. so you cannot just take it to the pool side or beach or anywhere where you plan to play music wirelessly as you would do with rechargeable Bluetooth.

- Songs play for a minute or so and then suddenly restart from the begening. Happens a lot.

- No Bluetooth option. Unlike Bluetooth, You cannot play whatever you want from whichever app you want.

- Requires paid accounts from music providers to connect the accounts to Sonos. This means you need to pay $40-$90 per year per account for service provider just to stream on Sonos. The free TuneIn didn't really impress me. And Amazon Prime has limited collection.

- You cannot stream from YouTube

- Phone has to be connected to the the same frequency of the WiFi router connection as the Sonos otherwise you get device not found.

- it does not have the WiFi connection to support AC frequency. I think it connects to Wireless N (way older technology)

- Mine is going back. Even at hundred buck I won't clutter my house with it.

So here is what I think Sonos can do to change our minds (at least mine)....

- offer 2 years for pro service from at least 2 music providers of our choice.
- supply a plug in Bluetooth accessory to make it work with any music I want
- Supply a portable rechargeable power source so I can use it anywhere.
$500 and no power switch. Ever hear of energy conservation? Not a very smart device.

reviews.reviewTitle: You CANNOT easily play sound coming from your computer to this speaker
reviews.reviewText:
Do NOT buy this. While you may think it's a speaker, it's not. You CANNOT easily play sound coming from your computer to this speaker. It requires you to have a paying subscription to a music system or buy extra bulls***. This is corporate greed right now. The sound is good, but what the hell is the point of a speaker if I can't play netflix or youtube. Sonos will counter that you can play with audio files on your computer. But who still has audio files on their computer?
I don't normally write reviews but this was dissapointing
Please do not buy these speakers! Sonos has a terrible interface, requires a separate app to work.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Speaker, But Poor Software Makes It Worthless
reviews.reviewDate: The manufacturer commented on the review below
reviews.reviewText: BEWARE! Loved it for a couple of years. Made the mistake of updating their app, and now it does not work. Poor customer service. I want my old version of the app. It was clunky, poorly designed, sure, but at least it played music over the speaker. Now my 'smart' speaker is worthless.

Because it wasnt clear that I wont be able to stream anything i hear from my computer.
If something like a speaker says it plays high quality sound, I made the mistake it assumed you can play any sound that came from my computer.
And besides that, the music player is comes with is cumbersome and confusing. Do we really need playlists and Queues?

reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent sound but not for everyone
reviews.reviewText:
Pros:
1) Excellent sound quality.
2) Excellent App to stream music
3) Fantastic base without any saturation or distortion.

Cons:

1) 1-2 second delay to output sound. This is the biggest problem. The video on the TV is always ahead of the sound (lipsync issue). You cannot use this for DJ or Karaoke either. Tried the uncompressed mode but did not help.
2) No remote
3) No blue-tooth
4) Cannot be mounted on a wall
5) No batteries. So need power source (not portable)
6) Requires premium streaming service from most vendors

reviews.reviewTitle: POOR MANUFACTURING AND POOR CUSTOMER SERVICE
reviews.reviewText:
The speakers look nice but after spending an hour on the phone with a customer service rep, I must advise you that it's not worth spending your money on this. In my opinion you should look for a speaker system from a brand name that has a lot more history and quality of manufacturing for the price you are paying. In my experience the quality of the product and customer service do not come with the expensive price tag. After seeing those cool commercials with the colors spreading in rooms where the sonos speakers were playing, I spent several thousand dollars on several Play:5 speakers and a home surround system (sub, playbar and a other speakers) and here's what I learned.

I bought my speakers all together 2 years ago. Now one of my PLAY:5 speakers do not work and all it does is flash a blinking red light. Here's what you are supposed to do when it flashes a blinking red light: call customer service as per the link on their webiste. [...]

So I did. I learned that my speaker is out of warranty (sadly the warranty ends after 1yr) and that they cannot do anything to replace it. However, the customer service rep said he could sell me a used/refurbished one. They would ship me a working refurbished speaker and I would need to send them back my defective speaker in exchange for a discounted price.

Why on Earth would I pay for a used / refurbished speaker after one that I bought only two years ago went defective on me. Let me get this straight. Customer buys a new speaker, after a year it breaks, customer is supposed to send back the broken speaker and pay for another used speaker that was refurbished and fixed. Another year passes by and it breaks again. The customer is supposed to send back said broken speaker and pay for another used speaker that was refurbished / fixed...and again and again and again. I don't believe this is good customer service. I think this is a scheme to make more money by making customers pay for manufacturing defects.

Customers who spend top dollar for a product demand excellent service. This to me seems like a scheme to generate more revenues from second hand faulty speakers. WHY ON EARTH WOULD I PAY FOR AN OLD REFURBISHED SPEAKER AFTER THE ONE I BOUGHT ONLY 2 YEARS AGO HAD A MANUFACTURING DEFECT??!?! Oh, and the best part that I forgot to mention - the refurbished speaker has a 90-day warranty. Yes, N-I-N-E-T-Y. Good luck with that.

Nice commercials but go find yourself something better. I'll wait till my speakers are run into the ground and then I'll get myself something else that will last longer.

reviews.reviewTitle: I went to best buy and bought Play 5s they are incredible
reviews.reviewText:
THE SELLER IS A CROOK!!!
I went to best buy and bought Play 5s they are incredible.

reviews.reviewTitle: We loved the idea of this speaker
reviews.reviewDate: The manufacturer commented on the review below
reviews.reviewText: We loved the idea of this speaker, and when it works the sound is first rate. But, for reasons we cannot understand, the connection drops out regularly without reason or warning. Sorry to say that we'll have to return this and try another brand.

reviews.reviewDate: The manufacturer commented on the review below
reviews.reviewText:
nice concept however not a mature product.
setting up can be an extremely frustrating experience and require customer support intervention. whenver you change modem/router/internet provider, you will lose all your settings, saved stations etc!
i had to do that several times and every time something else was not working. i got a straight forward set up with 2 speakers connected to the same router but even that runs into all kind of troubles.
the software on the PC has never been able to properly connect to the system and equally can't play the itunes library as it claims it does.
therefore i don't recommend for anyone who does not have a high tolerance for a frustrating set up experience

I love my Sonos system and cannot imagine my home without it! I'm not sure why the person above has such a harsh view of Sonos products due to Spotify! In fact I also use a houseful of Sonos with Spotify and have had NO issues like described! In fact, Sonos just released an entire update just to enhance the Spotify experience through Sonos. You can read about it here if interested.[...]
I also use Tidal and Google Play with my Sonos and enjoy making playlists that pull songs from all of the services into one jam session :)

YOU NEED THIS!!

reviews.reviewTitle: Do nothing but cut out all the time. Horrible product!!!
reviews.reviewDate: The manufacturer commented on the review below
reviews.reviewText: Good sounds. True tune can be a pain to get set up. I own 5 play 5, 2 subs, and a play 3. 2 of the 5 just stopped working one day. Got about 2 years of use from them. Very expensive so are they worth it for 2 to 3 years of use.

reviews.reviewTitle: Sonos customer service representatives refuse to release how many watts are included in this product.
reviews.reviewText:
I was curious about the wattage of the Sonos speaker. Usually speaker wattage provides, at least, a small indication of how far the speaker sound will carry in a room. I understand that technology is evolving, but I still wanted to know the wattage.
Sonos customer service representatives refuse to release how many watts are included in this product. The email response I received was:
"As it stands, SONOS does not release that information."
Sonos 5 may or may not be a good product, but I will not buy from companies that will not release information just because it might or might not make them look bad.

When it worked it was great, but as soon as it did not Sonos tells me that it's my wireless and my problem. They SUCK. Don't buy this product unless you want a ton of problems that the manufacturer will not help you solve. They have created a product that fights with other wireless equipment in your house (and your neighbors) and CANNOT be resolved! AVOID THE PAIN.

reviews.reviewTitle: but of poor design and quality
reviews.reviewDate: The manufacturer commented on the review below
reviews.reviewText: Somewhere between the latest upgrade to Win10 AND Sonos recent software upgrade, my system became unusable. Electrically, everything appears functional - green lights on, etc. However, it has been IMPOSSIBLE to have Sonos sync to iTunes. I've reported it to Sonos, they suggested it was firewall related (i.e., not our problem). So far, they've sent thoughtful, but totally WORTHLESS follow-ups. I have 4 Sonos speakers (and network link) which are COMPLETELY unusable due to this software problem. CAREFULLY consider whether you have the patience and skills to serve as a middleware specialist to their software. If I could rate their product (s) ZERO stars, I would (one-star would seem to be for products that are usable/functional, but of poor design and quality. Since I can't get their product to work, that would suggest ZERO stars...).

reviews.reviewDate: The manufacturer commented on the review below
reviews.reviewText: SONOS SUCKS!!. SOUNDS GREAT WHEN YOU CAN GET IT TO WORK FOR THAT 5 TO 10 MINUTE PERIOD THEN THE DROPOUTS START. MESSAGES APPEAR ON YOUR TABLET OR PHONE SAYING YOUR SYSTEM CAN'T BE FOUND OR YOU DON'T HAVE A SPEAKER CONNECTED TO YOUR SYSTEM THEN YOU ALWAYS HAVE TO REINSTALL EVERYTHING. THE OPTION TO LISTEN THROUGH THE AUDIO PORT MEANS YOU HAVE TO ACTIVATE IT THROUGH THE SONOS APP HOW STUPID. YOU SHOULD BE ABLE TO SIMPLY PLUG IN THE BACK OF THE SPEAKER. VERY UNSATISFIED WITH SERVICE REPONSE. ALWAYS TOLD IT MUST BE INTERFERENCE WITH OTHER DEVICES OR PHONE SERVICE. FUNNY HOW THEY DON'T INTERFERE WITH ONE ANOTHER ONLY SONOS HAS THE PROBLEM. MONEY AND TIME THROWN DOWN THE DRAIN. I HAVE NEVER BEEN SO UNHAPPY WITH A PRODUCT IN MY LIFE.

Right after the one-year warranty expired, my Sonos turned into a brick. It won't light up, it won't turn on, it won't do anything. It is completely dead. When I called to see what my options were, they told me I could send back the dead one and pay to get a refurbished first-gen Play 5 for $129. The catch is, it only comes with a 30-day warranty. So if this new one turns into a paperweight again, I'm up a creek without a paddle. Two stars because the customer service representative was friendly, despite the fact that he didn't offer a solution I was happy with.

I was given a Sonos Play5 (gen1) as a gift last December. The only wish I have is that there would be a Linux application made available. The Sonos itself runs on Linux. It would be GREAT if Sonos would add Linux to its existing support for Windows and Mac. Sound is GREAT, and these things are really quite loud. We use it outdoors and indoors. I already have plans to utilize Sonos in a fully wireless surround sound setup for a home theater.

reviews.reviewTitle: Spotify customers beware >> Sonos users can longer access their Spotify playlist folders
reviews.reviewText:
Spotify users beware -- Sonos users can no longer access their Spotify playlist folders, and makes it very hard to access one's Spotify playlists.

Sonos's recent upgrade to its interface eliminated access to user's Spotify playlist folders. So Sonos users can no longer view their Spotify custom folders, and all Spotify playlists are now listed individually in a random order, which makes it near impossible to browse through one's Spotify folders to find the playlist one is looking for. Many longtime Spotify users have hundreds of playlists sorted into dozens of folders and subfolders -- using Sonos, one can no longer access those folders.

reviews.reviewTitle: this is better than the previous PLAY
reviews.reviewText:
If prices didn't matter, almost 5 stars. However, SONOS is actually increasing the price of their products. Yes, this is better than the previous PLAY: 5. But these are overpriced products to start with...Nothing they've developed in terms of speaker technology warrants an $100 increase. Good speakers aren't a new thing. Stop overcharging...
(I own the P:5, P:3, the amp and the bridge)

I have a smallish home and this fills the place with the best deep, rich sounds I've ever heard. I have a couple of Sonos Play:1's as rear speakers and a Sonos Play: 3 in the bedroom. Everything works extremely well. The quality is unfathomably good and I have it under control from my iPhone, iPad, Mac and Windows 10 laptop. I am very, very impressed (hence I got more).
Use it every day. Great sound
High quality
The sound this speaker puts out is phenomenal. It was expensive, but definitely worth the price.

This speaker is awesome and thumps. I have every sonos made and this is my favorite. It is in large bathroom and I can bump while showering but I can hear down stairs if I turn it up. It's Kent for a much larger room for sure. Very happy

reviews.reviewTitle: Wonderful system, with amazing sound and so easy to ...
reviews.reviewText: This is the third sonos play 5 I have bought. One for each of my homes...Wonderful system, with amazing sound and so easy to hook up.

Love the whole SONOS system. Don't understand people who have problems with it. I have a 1 in the kitchen, 3 in the master bedroom, 5 in the living room, and bar for my TV in the den. Fantastic sound, easy to use, and nice looking. I've never had a second of trouble in the 4 years since I bought my first one.

The only issue I see is that the software for my phone/IPad changes every now and then and you need to get used to navigating a bit differently. Not a big deal and all vendors change their aps/websites periodically so I think anyone complaining about that needs to get a new life.

Can't wait for the supposed release of the integration with ALEXA.

DO NOT BUY unless you are committed to spending money on a monthly music subscription service for the rest of your life. For some reason Sonos has decided it is not enough to spend hundreds or thousand of dollars on speakers to outfit your home. Now you can no longer play music that you have purchased from your phone. They have sold out to the subscription music services so now in order to play music on your very expensive speakers you also have to subscribe to a monthly music service!!
Home

Bought the Play 1, and immediately bought the Play 5. Terrific sound, easy to set up, was listening to music in 5 minutes. Finally time to retire the old receiver and huge room hogging speakers. Update 3/25/19. About a month ago went to play some music off my IPad and the playlists I have meticulously collated over the years, like I have done for years. Played a couple songs and quit. Started it again, did the same thing. I was playing the music to be background for a card group, so found a radio station instead, and would look at it later. A few weeks went by, and I forgot. Another card group, same result. Again I forgot, until last night again, another card group, and I was pissed.

Today I googled what’s up, and Sonos advises folks there is a problem playing their units with IOS devices. WHAT!! That has to be more than half your customers. Until this is fixed, save your money and frustration level, if you plan to use an Apple device to control these units, they DO NOT WORK!

reviews.reviewTitle: Make sure you aren’t connecting to 5g
reviews.reviewText: I bought Sonos 5 two years ago then another one and a pair of sonos 1. I have had no issues at all. Sounds great. Plays seamlessly off of my iPhone. At one point a couple of years ago I was having connectivity issues. Turns out 5g WiFi doesn’t work as well (I can’t remember why), make sure it’s connected to the plain WiFi option, not the 5g one from your router.
